text: Sussan Ley is a class operator and correct when she says this is a once in a generation opportunity for reform. I would expect the government to adopt most if not all of the final recommendations later this year.
author: TimOfAltona

text: A good friend friend of mine who lives in QLD tells me Newman has tried to do too much too quickly - changing the world overnight and he has managed to leave some people behind with some decisions. I suspect he will slow down the pace of change to better reflect community expectations.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Time for the Labor/Greens cheer squad to take stock of their crass insensitivity to people dying and being killed just so they can try and land confected blows against the government.

text: Good to see Abbott taking a world leadership position on pressuring Russia to allow access to the crash site. Abbott and Bishop are leading the charge on behalf of the relatives of the murdered Australians as well as all the other nationalities - exactly what we expect of our PM.

text: Can't see that happening myself, still over 2 years to go before the next election and plenty of time for the polls to turn around which they undoubtedly will as Abbott's policies gain traction and Labor's mismanagement of our economy is reversed by the new government.

text: What a load of crap. Your greatest fear is that Abbott gets the recognition he deserves for doing all he can to bring the dead Australians' home - you put your cheap political point scoring ahead of the deaths of Australian men, women and children and the grieving of their relatives.

text: The Greens already have enough power - they keep the Labor party afloat - in fact without the Greens, Labor would be lucky to cobble together a dozen seats in the Lower House.

text: Gee Bob, maybe it has something to do with Labor blowing all our cash reserves and we have to borrow money from overseas to fund foreign aid programs and then pay a billion dollars a month in interest payments.

text: Yes, the absolute cruelty of preventing perhaps a thousand more deaths at sea since last September is unfathomable - just can't comprehend how cruel that policy is...all those lives saved.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I don't think Mr Bean gets it - Australia does not have the ability to keep borrowing money  overseas only to send it  overseas as foreign aid and be left standing with an interest bill of a billion dollars a month to cover it.

text: Labor may have looked good for a while with their smoke and mirrors budgets, but sooner or later we have to actually pay that money back that Labor kept on borrowing and reduce the debt.

text: The current group on board the customs vessel did not have a man with a gun at their head when they departed for Australia. They came from the relatively prosperous Tamil state in Southern India. They were not escaping fearing for their lives or escaping persecution - 70 million people live happily in Tamil Naidu... they were coming to Australia hoping to tap into our welfare system and perhaps get a job and perhaps give their families a better head start in life - there are tens of millions queued up behind them wanting to do the same thing.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The other news is that the Tamil Governor of that state is attempting to legislate for Sri Lankan Tamil refugees to be granted Indian citizenship to help them integrate and give them equal rights for employment, health care & education.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Yes - people smugglers do exist in the  world and yes, people hoping to bypass the UNHCR program and get to Australia by illegal boat do pay people smugglers for the service.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The people 'crewing' the boats are not the people smugglers - they are being paid by the people smugglers to do the job - the people smugglers have made millions of dollars and a % of this goes to the corrupt police, military and assorted Indonesian government officials who are also on the payroll to facilitate the safe departure of the boats from Indonesia.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Also, many of the people paying people smugglers are not genuine asylum seekers - they are economic migrants looking to tap into Australia's welfare system and with any luck get a job here.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You pretty much have to go back to the Labor government under Kevin Rudd that opened up our borders and got the people smuggling industry back on it's feet. Tens of thousands of people climbed into people smuggler boats and headed for Australia, many hundreds drowning along the way.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The new government came in to fix up Labor's mess and is making good progress - the ultimate aim is to close down all processing centres, on and off shore. This will be achieved by stopping the boats - so far so good on that front - much to the annoyance of the Labor cheer squad who wanted the boats to keep arriving just so they could come into the Guardian threads and proclaim yet another Abbott promise broken. Good to see that little piece of enjoyment has been denied.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Thank you Longers - at last a Labor supporter who acknowledges that the government is doing the right thing in it's efforts to bring our dead home to their families.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Pretty much all the other's are attacking Abbott and Bishop with confected abuse over the handling and response to the tragedy. I guess their key issue is that they want it to be a  PM doing all this, not a Liberal and they can't bring themselves to acknowledge that Abbott and co have done a bloody good job so far in doing everything we can to help the families and bring their deceased loved ones home.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Funny thing is though, you have to stop the boats to achieve that - otherwise, as we saw under Labor, the detention centres keep on filling up, even having to open up new ones to cope with the thousands arriving by boat each month.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Now come clean with the Australian people Crowey - you know as well as all of us here that had Abbott left the country to attend a meeting in Palau, you and the rest of the cheer squad would be up in arms attacking him for running away and leaving the the families of the victims of MH17.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Best to give up on your attacks over Abbott and MH17 - he is doing what we expect the Australian PM, Labor or Liberal, to be doing and that is firstly - doing everything humanly possible to help the families & to bring their loved ones home and secondly doing all the Australian government can to to assist in bringing the perpetrators to justice.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Some events transcend domestic politics and this is one of them - follow the lead of your Labor party who have thrown their weight behind Abbott to help him get this job done.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I think the Labor supporters give Murdoch way too much credit - whilst he was a useful distraction for them away from their internal disunity and dysfunction - I suspect he holds little if any sway over Australian domestic politics. Ask former PM's Rudd and Gillard, they 'consulted' with Murdoch over dinners and lunches whenever they were in NY - I doubt they would support the conspiracy theorists active in these threads today (aka Labor cheer squad) that Murdoch influenced them one way or the other.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Who cares if Abbott discussed the PPL with Murdoch over dinner, he probably discussed a lot of things going on at the time - the PPL scheme was on Abbott's radar years before any dinner with Murdoch - it was out in the public domain back in 2010.
author: TimOfAltona

text: They all beat a path to Murdoch's door when they to NY- Hawke, Howard, Rudd, Gillard, Abbott all have lunches and dinners with the News Corp chairman. Shorten will be working his way to meeting him as soon as he can swing it - if he holds onto the leadership that is.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The truth can be hurtful at times...we have all been there. Don't give up though - there  a place for Labor - it's just that this is not the time.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Most are living in denial that Murdoch was calling a bad government for what it was, a bad government. At any examination the Rudd-Gillard-Rudd years were not the best for Labor - dysfunction, back stabbing and leaks were a daily occurrence.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Even the ALP's internal report on last year's election failure stated it was down to internal dysfunction fueled by intense and very public rivalry between the Gillard and Rudd camps.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The ALP's current leader, Shorten, was a key player/contributor to all the unfolding dramas and has, thanks to the unions, been rewarded with a temporary seat at the head of the table. He will not survive in that role if Labor is to have any chance of forming a government in the years ahead.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I gotta say...no matter how many hundreds or thousands of times the Labor/Greens cheer squad type "Election now' or 'DD now' it will NOT bring late 2016 any closer or faster than the normal passage of time - just a tip.

text: Save your key boards and keystrokes for working out how the ALP are to reform themselves and sort out their dysfunctional leadership debacles and future direction. This may assist the ALP one day, perhaps a couple of terms away, being a viable alternative government.

text: The PM is doing what we expect of our PM - doing all he can to get the dead Australians home to their families - clearly this does not sit well with you. How many family members did you lose on the flight?

text: Shorten is trying his best to reignite the "Light on the Hill' rhetoric - but this will fall largely on deaf ears - Australia has moved on from all that working class romanticism crap largely because so many more of us are much better off than we were 20 or 30 years ago.

text: Shame the cheer squad can't throw their support behind Abbott and Bishop's efforts to bring our dead Australians home to their families - in fact they are outright criticising them for doing what we expect them to be doing and achieving. From what I see and hear, the PM is being praised around the globe for his leadership achievements after the tragedy.

text: Abbott has been surviving off minimal sleep since the MH17 disaster - he has been working during different time zones to discuss/coordinate the situation with various world leaders and our team on the ground - typically Europe between 2 and 4 in the morning and then going on to do a full days work. You choose to comment on his eyes as 'evil'. Try tired comrade.

text: is why Labor are out of office for the next 2-3 terms - the disconnect from reality blinds their judgement to the point that they live in a parallel universe from mainstream Australia.

text: Exactly - I have been saying this for some time but keep on being shot down in flames by the Labor cheer squad....seriously, if Labor are to have any hope of forming government over the next 6-9 years they need to refocus on reform - Labor and their supporters banging on about the evil Tony Abbott & hoping that will be enough to get them over the line is pure delusion and will ensure they stay in opposition for years to come.

text: A quick check of the betting markets shows me you are wrong and will blow your thousand bucks - the bookies have Abbott and the Coalition as outright favs to win... understandably so, Labor have no hope until they sort themselves out... years away yet.

text: This interview confirms everyones suspicions that she is way out of her depth when it comes to that shadow portfolio. Foreign Affairs aint Tania's strength, in fact she is a liability.

text: Her inability to differentiate between the ADF and the AFP was astounding - she kept referring to the federal police as the ADF....the interviewer did not pull her up on it and made Plibersek look like she had no idea what she was talking about (which she didn't).

text: If this is the best Labor can muster and with the hapless Shorten as interim Labor leader, the Coalition are looking at perhaps an extra term in government, on top of the next two coming up.

text: God forbid that the ABC has the  to allow LNP guests onto the Drum, we  want left wing guests on the Drum. It is very important that we only hear the views of the left on the Drum, the last thing we want is to hear the views of our government...that just won't do will it comrade?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Smart move by Morrison...the message is still loud and clear to people smugglers ....this government will deny you a product to sell...you will have to wait until a Labor/Greens government is back in power before you can start up your insideous trade again.

text: You seriously need to clean your key board...the caps lock key keeps sticking and makes your comment look all disjointed...don't they have a budget down at Socialist Alternative admin to buy a few cleaning products down at the local Woolies?

text: The left are on the wrong side of public opinion on this one and lost the argument a long time ago...this government is to be congratulated for delivering on what they promised and what we voted for last September. Labor were just not up to the task...how many PM's did they go through and how many Immigration ministers did Labor churn through - was it 5 or 6? None of them up to the task - all failures.

text: The Labor/Greens cheer squad, all 150 of them, would taking to the streets with their pitch forks, flaming torches and burning effigies of the PM - oh wait a minute - they are already doing that. LOL

text: The government has not been forced to send these people to the mainland, they are doing it out of humanitarian compassion whilst it is determined where they will ultimately be sent - India, Nauru or Manus.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The turn back the boats policy has been highly successful - no boats have made it through from Indonesia, where 99% of departures were occurring. This was not being done way up in Southern India for obvious reasons and if it was, this boat would not have made it this far.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The policy of labor and the Coalition has been highly successfully and has effectively saved perhaps thousands of people from drowning, something unimaginable back when K Rudd was running things.
author: TimOfAltona

text: These people needed to be removed from the boat while the high court proceedings are ongoing. It is the right thing to do to bring them ashore temporarily until the High Court judgement is handed down and then they can either be returned to Tamil southern India or over to Manus or Nauru for processing. It is fairly likely these are economic migrants simply looking to improve their lives in Australia so either they return to India or their original homeland. Those determined to be  refugees can be resettled in a third country such as PNG, Nauru or Cambodia.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You seem to be confused .the police are there for security dutiescrash investigators and forensic teams will be doing the work on the wreckage and human remains. The police are there because it would be too problematic for ADF or any troops from any country to be on the ground in that situation.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Julie Bishop and her Dutch counterpart are making good progress in Kiev to bring this about with Ukrainian authorities whilst Abbott is dealing with Putin on the Russian side to allow unrestricted access for the multi-national police contingent to provide security whilst the forensic and recovery teams do their vital work.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Correct, the same occurred in 9/11. The key to this is forensic examination of the various crash sites to occur as quickly as possible before too much evidence or remains are lost...hence the government pushing for a security team to assist with this process.
author: TimOfAltona

text: If he were to say or do nothing you would be on here attacking him for just that - so when he is proactive, as a PM should be, you attack him for just that.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The crash zone is 50 sq km, the multi national police team will comprise Dutch and Australian and perhaps other countries. Australia's contribution is 50, the Dutch may have hundreds there....you talk as if Australia is the only country sending police....providing the MOU with the Ukraine works out and the Russians agree to support it, the police will be on the ground in the Ukraine within 24-48 hrs and the search and removal of human remains can continue.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Shame the Labor/Greens cheers squad are more concerned about a lift in the polls for the PM than they are for the families of the victims of MH17 -it's clear the government is doing a fine job and all decent Australians applaud their efforts to get our dead home to their families.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Good to know this is the best talent the ALP can muster - the Coalition are staring down the barrel of 4 terms with turkeys like this batting for the other team.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Bishop and Houston, along with the Dutch Foreign Minister, are in Kiev this afternoon arranging for a MOU with the Ukrainian PM which will allow a multi-national police force to attend the site so that the remaining bodies can be located and removed and the investigators do their work unhindered. It looks likely the Russians will assist with this process in dealing with the Donekst rebels - but how that eventuates remains to be seen.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The Dutch have the lead on this, having lost the majority of citizens and are likely to make up the majority of the police securing the 50km wide zone.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Good on Abbott for being proactive on this - not supported of course by those who fear the prospect of the government getting a boost in the polls out of this tragedy, but supported all the same by all decent Australians who want to see every effort made to bring our dead home.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Angus Houston is in Kiev with Bishop getting the memorandum of understanding sorted with the Ukrainian government to allow a multi-national police force into the area to protect the crash site so the remaining bodies can be located and crash investigators do their work - clearly that prospect of success in this area frightens you, but the majority of Aussies applaud what is going on and only a few sad and sorry people like you object.
author: TimOfAltona

text: It is a real shame that the Labor/Greens cheer squad are more concerned about the PM getting a lift in the polls than they are about bringing home our dead.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Clearly none of them have lost a loved one in the tragedy - if they had they would be praising the government's efforts as I'm sure those affected are at this terrible time.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Abbott, Bishop and all the others working on this are to be congratulated not condemned by the faux and confected outrage emanating from a sad and sorry bunch of people concerned the PM may actually come out of this looking good.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Forget the Greens, they will oppose anything and everything - let's hear from Labor on this - the Labor cheer squad have jumped in early on this before hearing what their party line is - Labor may well support the decision too.
author: TimOfAltona

text: What a load of crap - Gillard was the most detested PM in a generation - had she gone on to lead Labor to the election they would have been lucky to come away with 30 seats in the lower house - such was the feeling of animosity towards her - not only from mainstream Australia but within her own party. The only reason her and Combet were bosom buddies was because they were both marionettes for the powerful unions who dictated ALP policy through the PM placed into office..
author: TimOfAltona

text: The 'Gillard' experiment crashed and burned for Labor and they will never ever repeat that mistakenot if they ever want to return to government in this country. Gillard was a disaster - nearly destroyed her own party.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I turned on the radio in my car earlier today and , it was that unmistakable drone of Gillard's voice - I thought we as a country had cleansed ourselves of that auditory pornography assaulting our shell-likes without any prior warning.
author: TimOfAltona

text: But no - it was indeed Gillard assaulting the airwaves pushing some book by, like her, another failed Labor politician who is best remembered for under achievements than any over achievements or for that matter  achievements full stop.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I sat there wondering if she was reading from a McTernan script as she did for most her Prime Ministership or perhaps she was channelling K Rudd, her replacement, given he enjoyed significantly more support and respect from both the country and her  party than she could have ever dreamed.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I'm writing to the ABC today to ensure they next time they are thinking of putting Gillard's voice to the airwaves, that it is preceded by a health warning to give us all plenty of time to switch stations.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Gillard (McTernan) started this whole confected sexism row as a tactic to try and prop up Gillard's failing leadership and now everyone has to be careful what they say as a result.

text: Re QT - it has developed into a bit of a circus with the Labor MP's acting like recalcitrant school children deliberately baiting the headmistress (Speaker) to see who gets to be thrown out the most. In fact Labor have turned it into a sport.
author: TimOfAltona

text: This is as much a reflection on Shorten's leadership as it is on the inadequacy of the Labor opposition - Australians have noticed this and will mark Labor's scorecard accordingly.

text: I suspect your comments have just lost any credibility that may have been left - I doubt even your own side can see that this is a bullshit concoction of yours with no basis whatsoever except a deep hatred of anything to do with the PM.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Funny old thing politics - in the months leading up to last years election the Labor/Greens cheer squad went into hiding when it came to discussing or reflecting on the polls and if they did it was all about how they are all fake and rigged to help Abbott win.

text: the polls have transformed from being highly dubious and a totally unreliable tool of a giant media conspiracy against Labor into a highly credible and accurate source of how voters feel about the government.

text: Don't worry about that comment - it's the Labor/greens cheer squad worried that the PM may look good for what he's done following the tragedy - they can't stand the thought that he may actually have made a major contribution to bringing our dead home and will receive praise for it - none the least from the relatives of those tragically killed.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Goodness, you are  shit scared that the PM may look good out of this that you want all pollies banned from saying or doing anything in relation to MH17 - suck it up Longers - too late - Abbott's already been hailed around the world for his leadership over this tragedy.

text: 32 Australians dead, Foreign Minister attends a memorial service for the dead dressed appropriatly in black and all you can do is attack her for wearing a hat and make some banal comment about the Melbourne Cup.

text: Time the Labor/Greens cheer squad pull their heads in and accept that they lost the last election and no amount of baseless confected attacks on Julie Bishop will deliver you back into government - in fact the opposite.

text: The Labor/Greens cheers squad can't stand to see Tony Abbott get any credit for his leadership and achievements in bringing home our dead Australians. It worries them that he may just be successful.

text: Suggest you go back, read it again, perhaps two or three times and then come back with something that resembles fact and then maybe your credibility stakes will improve. IMHO.

text: You are on a loser trying to condemn the PM for doing what we expect our PM, Labor or Liberal, to be doing - your greatest fear is that he will receive recognition for it - which he has.

text: According to some elements of the Labor/Greens cheer squad,  disaster, war, famine, plague, earthquake or flood anywhere in the world is Tony Abbott's fault - none of them would occur if a  government was in power.

text: You guys need to get out more instead of living in your own squalid world of left-wing delusion - take a look at the latest ABC fact checker on pre-election promises delivered by the government so far - impressive list.

text: If you think Christmas Island has the infrastructure to handle the sheer numbers of people who would attempt the journey by sea then you are mistaken....I reckon conservatively half a million people would attempt the journey over the next 2 or 3 years if they believed Australia was taking in all people who could safely make it to our territorial waters. All the current detention centers on the mainland would need to be opened and new ones built.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I understand your sentiment - however, how will we deal with hundreds of thousands who would seek to make this journey if they believed Australia will take in all comers who wish to claim refugee/asylum status?
author: TimOfAltona

text: How many processing/detention centers would need to be built on top of the existing ones. 5, 10, 50, 100? Where do all the people go when they are released into the community - there is a shortage of public housing now - remember most of these people have no way to support themselves so will rely on taxpayer funded programs government welfare and charities to survive. You only have to look at some European cities to see the effects of open borders - migrant ghettos springing up because the state has no way of providing for the sheer numbers of people flooding into the cities.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Where are the jobs? There is already an undersupply of jobs for Australians let alone migrants - will these people be consigned to a life on government welfare with no housing to accommodate them?
author: TimOfAltona

text: How many thousands of families will perish at sea trying to reach Australia - we have already seen what can happen when the Rudd government gave the green light for boat arrivals in 2007.
author: TimOfAltona

text: ....but there are millions of people in this region who would want to be taken in if they can reach Australia by boat - how many can you accommodate before you say this is too much?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Bottom line is Australia's best hope for providing for a safe and humane asylum seeker program is for a  migration program that can cope with the numbers and ensure the safeguards are in place to allow people to successfully assimilate into the community and start a new life for them and their families.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Placing our refugee program into the hands of the people smugglers is not good policy, has been tried before by the Rudd Labor government and failed in so many ways and disadvantages those who genuinely apply to come to australia through the UNHCR front door program.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The Labor/Greens cheer squad can't stand the government's win at stopping the people smugglers and saving hundreds if not a thousand plus lives along the way, so they resort to personal abuse directed at those who celebrate the government's success.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Good to see the government is not wavering on it's policy - this is the only way people smugglers will be shut down - they no longer have a product to sell.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Prisons are places where people are held either following  or have been charged with a crime and are held if it is deemed they are a danger to other people, themselves or are a flight risk.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You are correct Jim, western military intervention is not a long term solution - it is a band aid - but if it means in the short term saving perhaps tens or hundreds of thousands of people from a horrific death at the hands of IS it is definitely worth going for.

text: I hear your point, but I doubt IS fighters have much interest on who is the PM or which political party is in power in Australia while they go about their jihad - this same situation could have easily arisen when Labor were in government and Labor would be grappling with the same conundrum.

text: Labor supporters can argue amongst themselves all they like over whether it was Rudd or Gillard who brought the party to it's knees in the lower house last September , but the 3 key issues still exist that will keep them out of government for the next two terms at least, namely -

text: 1. Leadership dysfunction and factional infighting. The ALP go to great lengths to keep a lid on these two corrosive ALP attributes, but they are always just below the surface bubbling away. Disunity is death.
author: TimOfAltona

text: 2. The stigma of being viewed as nothing more than an extension of the powerful unions, some militant (Gillard was tainted by this). I get that Labor are the political arm of the union movement and all that but you only have to look at the makeup of the Labor senate and you pretty quickly see where all the old union hacks end up. Parachuting into the senate is a favourite pass time for ex-union officials looking for reward for their union stewardship.
author: TimOfAltona

text: 3. The ALP's reliance on the Greens to both get them into government and then staying in government. You only have to look at what happened across the Tasman last Saturday to see what mainstream voters think of Labor/Greens governments - Australia is no different. Everyone can see that the Greens having helped the ALP then hold them hostage to Greens policies (again - Gillard and the Carbon Tax) and we really don't want to go down that path again.

text: You seem to forget the Cayman Island tactic Labor tried to use early on in the piece was dropped like a hot potato when it backfired spectacularly on Shorten.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The R/G/R Labor years saw tens of millions of tax payer (borrowed) funds propping up the ALP propaganda machine. Gillard spent something like $20m alone on advertising her carbon tax broken promise. Gillard also spent around $73m tax payers money on ALP (government) advertising for the 2010 election.
author: TimOfAltona

text: They are all trying to be the first to report that the government is going to a DD election - hence government ministers are holding their cards close to their chest.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Abbott went to an election promising a RC into union corruption if he gained government. Last I looked, he had a landslide victory and the ALP were left with a handful of seats in the lower house - so Abbott delivered on what we voted for - a RC into union corruption.
author: TimOfAltona

text: If Shorten can do the same with the promise of a RC into the B&F sector then good luck to him. I don't think he can pull it off now that the government look like increasing resources and legislative powers for ASIC.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Supporters of the Labor/Greens party are quick to hop on board their leader's focus group initiated and populist call for a RC into the banking and finance sector - for no other reason than they think that by joining two themes, a Royal Commission and Banking and Finance Sector, it will equate to more votes for their beleaguered party.
author: TimOfAltona

text: With no terms of reference offered, no time frames, no money allocated and no idea who would run it, it all sounds and looks like a focus group thought bubble of gigantic proportions.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I think you are correct. The Turnbull government will be returned with a reduced majority in the lower house. Let's hope the senate is cleaned out of the preference whisperer senators which also will give the government clear air in the senate to do what we elect them to do - govern.
author: TimOfAltona

text: However, with such a long campaign and the media watching every word and gesture and hoping for a stumble by the key players, particularly Shorten and Turnbull, anything can happen along the way, but you'd have to surmise Turnbull will prevail and be given another term.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Fair to say, the ALP engage in crass and gutter politics . It has been their MO since the drubbing in 2013 and we have seen this played out in various formats since and clearly evidenced in their crass behaviour in both houses of parliament.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You need to speak to the unions about why vehicle manufacturing is almost extinct in SA - they know a thing or two about forcing manufacturers to abandon Australia in favour of lower cost overseas markets.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The question is - can Plibersek even hold her seat? The Greens look like they will steam roll over her - unless the Libs come to her rescue with their preferences.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Cash is spot on regarding the CFMEU and the way it props up the Labor Party - their latest attack ads on TV are a great reminder for Australians why we don't want another CFMEU controlled Labor government in office for another few terms.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Please explain when the polls show the government ahead they are nothing more than a media conspiracy to protect the government, yet when the same polls are favourable to Labor/Greens they are a true indication of how voters are feeling?
author: TimOfAltona

text: They have never delivered on their promise of reform and rebuild and clearly it will take another election drubbing for them to seriously sort out what they stand for and what direction they want to take the party - starting with ditching Bingle Bill and the hapless Plibersek and starting afresh.
author: TimOfAltona

text: C'mon Daisy, you know Cash was referring to national numbers, this was a rally in Camberra where only a few hundred attended. It's difficult for most of them to attend such a rally because the ALP and the TWU have all but driven their businesses to the wall so they have to work 7 days to keep their heads above water.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Don't be taken in by TWU (and Labor) propaganda. Nothing to do with safety it's all about artificially inflating road transport costs to the benefit of TWU members and to the detriment of owner drivers and consumers.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Labor are so hobbled by their union masters, TWU in this case, that they will go limping to the election with Turnbull's Truckies vowing support for LNP candidates - that's how many hundred thousand voters?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Always good to see you have such a big interest in the Wayside Chapel - you should do some volunteering work down there then you can rightfully claim you and the Australian PM have something in common.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Nonsense, she could have left all the Labor MPs who were flouting standing orders in the house and it still makes no difference to voting, Labor have such a piss poor number of seats in the lower house after the R/G/R debacle.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Plenty of people sympathise with her when she was speaker.Certain labor MPs were carrying on like primary school children - fully deserved to be thrown out for flouting standing orders.In fact it looked as if some of them were going for the all time ejection record so they were baiting her. Not a good look for a party who are supposedly the alternative government.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Not at all. Reality is Malcolm Turnbull's government is strengthened by this generational change. Perhaps that what has Labor and its supporters so vocal about the outcome. You would suspect they were all hoping Bronwyn would be contesting the next election but have had the rug pulled out from under them. Hence a big win for the government.
author: TimOfAltona

text: She will be remembered as a powerhouse politician and a formidable Lower House speaker who had to deal with the childish antics of a Labor opposition reeling from the devastating drubbing at the 2013 election who were intent on causing disruption and mayhem by systematically flouting standing orders in order to gain attention for their wounded party.
author: TimOfAltona

text: This was reflected in the sheer number of recalcitrant Labor MPs thrown out of the house . It was clear what Labor tactics were and in some ways Bronwyn could be criticised for showing too much restraint in disciplining regularly offending Labor MPs. These MPs turned the House of Reps into a circus and did their party and the parliament no favours - hopefully their constituents will remember the childish antics and vote accordingly at the next election.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The Greens by and large represent the nation's social conscience - this does not always fit in too well with the competing agendas of the two major parties, particularly where fiscal policy is concerned.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I think she knows in the back of her mind that Labor have to serve at least one more term, perhaps two, in opposition and she has yet to decide if she wants to part of all that.
author: TimOfAltona

text: When the PM is out of the country it is customary for the Deputy PM to take over as acting PM to keep the business of government ticking over.
author: TimOfAltona

text: This is despite the fact that Bingle Bill is about as popular as Michaelia Cash would be if she were to drop in and bang out a few verses of the Liberal Party hymn for the boys at a CFMEU picket line......
author: TimOfAltona

text: Despite the fact that Australians have little interest in watching the prime ministerial revolving door popping out yet another Australian PM (how many is that in the past 9 years?).......
author: TimOfAltona

text: Despite the fact that voters are weary about installing yet another Labor/Greens government after the trainwreck of last time around that left Labor/Greens with a paltry 55 + 1 seats vs 90 for the government in the lower house.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Now  has got it wrong and I think we all know the reality is the ALP are well and truly the underdogs here and providing Turnbull doesn't stroll into the chamber sporting a top hat and smoking an expensive Cuban over the next few weeks , Labor are set to remain the underdogs for another term at least IMO.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Clearly the ALP tactics committee decided to have this smoke and mirrors hollow 'announcement' broadcast on the very day the PM is up in China securing Australia's trade future with an economy 4 times larger than Australia's.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Well, we all know that 'free range' has wildly differing interpretations, we know that 'barn laid' are god awful conditions for the chickens and then at the bottom of the rung are just 'normal' eggs - what cruel and tortuous conditions are those chickens in?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Problem is railfreight is considerably more expensive than road freight and guess who ends up paying for the increased transport/supply costs - standby for massive price hikes on the supermarket shelves.
author: TimOfAltona

text: It certainly worked for my Dad, we knew almost to the minute when he would pass based on the dose of morphine the nurses had administered to ease his suffering.
author: TimOfAltona

text: This is akin to the robots working the assembly lines which used to be manned by skilled workers in car manufacturing - investment in technology increases production, improves efficiency and reduces cost and the robots rarely go on strike over job security.
author: TimOfAltona

text: My, hasn't the former darling of the Labor cheer squad, based for no other reason than at some point he took on the Liberal Party has fallen from grace.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Distinctly recall commenting at the time that Clive was in it for Clive and nothing else, yet so many Labor supporters had him up on a pedestal like their new messiah.
author: TimOfAltona

text: How about a RC into how it came to pass that Biff Teacup was 'inserted' as ALP leader ahead of the bloke who pretty much everyone voted for to lead the party?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Uber are probably providing a great public service here - a cunning way to let people know they are actually arseholes and giving them an opportunity to lift their game by improving their net rating.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Certainly Shorten's dealings with EastLink over the AMW member ripoff was not a good look, nor were the 100 or so pending prosecutions emanating from the TURC, nor were the Health Services Union crash and burn a good look.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Not sure what will bring on the demise of the reef faster, climate change or people, mainly tourists, destroying parts of the reef each day by standing up on the coral in their flippers in the shallower water.
author: TimOfAltona

text: These are mostly the thousands of amateur snorkelers who travel out on tour boats to sections of the reef each week and swarm all over the reef inflicting irreparable damage.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The tour companies will deny that is the case as they warn their punters not to stand on the coral, but on the two occasions I've been out I've seen plenty of amateur snorkelers standing up and breaking the fragile coral formations.
author: TimOfAltona

text: It means as a nation we should not be spending more than we are earning or borrowing more than we can afford to repay - simple fiscal responsibility seemingly lost on Bill Shorten as he travels around the country throwing (promised) money at anything that moves to buy votes for the ALP ahead of the election.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Something tells me that if you had been fortunate in life like Turnbull and had amassed personal wealth and then entered politics and and became a minister of the crown and eventually Prime Minister you would be doing exactly what Turnbull has done - keeping his investments which may include Australian businesses at arms length where he can't be accused of conflict of interest but still pay Australian taxes.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I can see the roar of disapproval from the Labor cheer squad now if Turnbull in his capacity as PM was seen to knowingly personally benefit from government policy or actions within a certain sector or enterprise.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Well comrade, I think you will find that Turnbull knows a thing or two about being an underdog. You have no idea about the work he's done for decades with homeless and disadvantaged people have you?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Shorten got the name 'Bingle Bill' when he drove around a quiet Carlton Street early one Sunday morning smashing into parked cars - he claimed he spilt hot coffee in his lap.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Shorten and the ALP's tactic seems to be promise cash to anyone who holds out their hand and worry about it later if they happen to fall over the line.
author: TimOfAltona

text: As opposed to living outside our means which seems to be the Labor party mantra this election, if Bill's promises of cash splash for all is anything to go by.
author: TimOfAltona

text: My money is on the left faction to get up and install Albo, but that could be complicated if Plibersek holds her seat, which means she'll have to be shafted for someone from the right to replace her as deputy. No idea who that could be but. Your guess as good as mine.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Turnbull is not alone in thinking the Gillard years were a dud - ask Bill Shorten, he thought Gillard was so much of a dud he stabbed her in the back and installed Kevin Rudd.
author: TimOfAltona

text: So desperate is he to win government he must be furiously watering that magical ALP money tree growing out the back of Trades Hall, for that's about the only way he can deliver on all these cash giveaways.
author: TimOfAltona

text: With the nations money pool rapidly evaporating due to lower commodity prices and the slowing economies of our major trading partners, not all requests for increased government handouts can be accommodated.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The hundreds of thousands of drivers who use the Monash each day don't care where the money comes from, they just need it fixed and will probably give cudos to the government that achieves that for them.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Firstly, congratulations on managing to post a comment without referring to the Cayman Islands and secondly, all these funding for road infrastructure improvement announcements are music to the ears for anyone who has to drive the Monash peak hour carpark each day.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Not at all Daisy - purely pointing out the bloody obvious that it is not only Liberal party politicians who claim back expenses attending Liberal Council meetings as this Dragon dude is alluding - Labor pollies claim back their expenses when attending Labor Council meetings - it's part of their job description to attend.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The previous Liberal government initiated plans for an airport rail link to the city but the Andrews Labor government came in and threw them out, preferring a widening of the Tullamarine freeway to ease congestion.
author: TimOfAltona

text: No wonder the Victorian government have welcomed this announcement as will anyone who has to drive on the Monash each day, that's a few hundred thousand voters right there.
author: TimOfAltona

text: When you guys break for play lunch, have a bit of a brainstorming session amongst yourselves on how you can perhaps bring some facts to the table instead of relying on a few of Shorten's old zingers to prosecute your argument.
author: TimOfAltona

text: This 'event' was a Shorten inspired con, err..I mean 'Town Hall' meeting where he got to spruik focus group inspired rhetoric with no way of showing how he will pay for everything.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I urge you to hand over all your factual information to Guardian editors and the Federal police at the earliest opportunity so we can all share in your knowledge on these matters and legal proceedings can commence.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Classic ALP electioneering focus group driven stunt by Shorten - tell everyone what he thinks they want to hear along with all the associated promises on what he will do with not a hope in hell of funding this stuff.
author: TimOfAltona

text: In all seriousness it may not be a bad idea to put Tony back into the cabinet in the next term of government. He has proved himself to be head and shoulders above the Labor party when it comes to the Immigration and Border Protection portfolio and is generally credited here and abroad with shutting down the insidious and deadly people smuggling industry in this part of the world.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Given The Guardian are right in the action here, if there is anything damning relating to any Australian individuals or businesses we will be hearing all about it don't you think?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Ahhh...the usual bullshit manoeuvring tactics being trotted out by the hapless Tony Burke trying to both disrupt and score cheap political points in an election year. Fools no one what he is up to.
author: TimOfAltona

text: When you have finished that, come back and explain how naval shipbuilding is still in limbo given the Abbott government confirmed last year the next generation of surface vessels will all be constructed in SA along with a boost of billions of dollars to the local economy.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Taking into consideration the leaders of the two major parties plus the Greens, which leader would you be most likely to welcome into your home for dinner and conversation, Turnbull, Shorten, Di Natale or none of them
author: TimOfAltona

text: I see all the resident fiscal wizards from the Labor cheer squad are giving free advice to the PM on how he should be managing his personal financial affairs.....it's very noble of them to give the PM a few pointers on how to maximise his already considerable wealth, but something tells me he's doing just fine without their misguided yet well meaning suggestions.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Bottom line is Turnbull's personal financial affairs are no ones business except his own - if he is breaking the law, which he is not, then that's another matter.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Yes, global warming is real and yes average temperatures have been slowly rising on the planet for the last 100 years or so (when reliable monitoring was first in place), although Camden outside Sydney recorded a 50C day in 1896 which has never been repeated since.
author: TimOfAltona

text: At any examination, Australia with our paltry 1.8% contribution to the planet's greenhouse gas emissions is not the problem here, that would be China (by far), United States, India, Russia and Japan.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Australia keeping it's coal in the ground is not going to restrict China and India or other high emission countries from continuing with an insatiable appetite for cheap coal powered energy, they will simply source from elsewhere if Australia denys supply.
author: TimOfAltona

text: So for now the economic benefits for Australia (just ask the QLD Labor government re Adani and the thousands of blue collar Labor voters and their families dependant on coal exports in Newcastle) outweigh the moral and perhaps scientific argument for keeping our coal in the ground.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Too simplistic? Perhaps but I don't think Australia can keep looking the other way when the topic of nuclear powered energy comes up. We probably have the best environmental conditions on the planet to operate nuclear power stations in a safe and sustainable way.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Capricornia has been a safe Labor seat since Federation. It has only been after the landslide defeats of Whitlam, Keating and Rudd that the LNP took control of the seat.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Just as the government's honeymoon period was unsustainable, so is the opposition's current poll driven sugar hit seemingly getting them over excited...even Mr Bean (Sam Dastyari) came out yesterday announcing that Labor are almost certain of a victory.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I think we can all agree that Turnbull's initial 'honeymoon' burst of popularity was unsustainable - it was so far up in the stratosphere vs Shorten's being below seabed level that we all recognised it was artificially high.
author: TimOfAltona

text: That said, Turnbull can't sit back and relax thinking he will have a comfortable win...he has plenty of hard work ahead of him before the election and the winning formula for him is to revisit the 'fairness' he spruiked on becoming PM.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The issue at hand is where the funding comes from. He proposed the states fund their own public education via state raised taxation, whereas the premiers didn't want to go down that track because they are made to look like the villains of the piece in raising taxes - they want the commonwealth to take the heat on that.
author: TimOfAltona

text: No one could disagree with your 4th paragraph, but it is where the money comes from and given it is an ever shrinking pool of funds, it's how it is distributed that is in contention here.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Labor have a bad habit of promising way more than is available in the pool and then they promise to distribute it where they think it will garner them most votes - placing the interests of their party ahead of the interests of the Australian community.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Now come back and explain to us how a senior government minister and now the PM can invest his personal funds in Australian businesses and then not be accused of passing legislation that benefits himself financially?
author: TimOfAltona

text: There are clear double standards here - many of the Labor cheer squad are labelling private school education as being 'elitist' and not worthy of public funding and some are even advocating closing them down altogether.
author: TimOfAltona

text: It's a funny thing, the bloke who is their leader and they are campaigning for so hard to be the next PM is himself the product of a very exclusive and expensive private school education.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The same applies to the daily demonisation of the 'evil' IPA. The bloke who is the leader of the Labor cheer squad and they are campaigning for so hard to be he next PM is himself a close personal friend of the IPA chief and worse than that was also best man at his wedding.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I've been to Cuba on three occasions now and each time it is looking more run down and more people living in about as close to poverty as you get without the starvation. Large swaths of the capital Havana have no running water and electricity cuts in and out on a daily basis.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Until then it's more of the same ALP smoke and mirrors - just like the billions Gillard promised which, surprise surprise, the bulk of which were only due to come to fruition beyond the then forward estimates ie: the money promised was an aspiration, it was never there in the first place.
author: TimOfAltona

text: No way could you ever trust Labor with their hollow claims on public school education funding, it's all a case of telling you what you want to hear with no way to actually deliver on the promises IMHO.
author: TimOfAltona

text: It would be great to hear from you on what more can be done today that has not already been done to rectify injustices and assist indigenous Australians to share equally in Australia's prosperity?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Felt sorry for Amanda last night, she was sent in there to try and prop up Labor's great con on the $30bn dollars 'promised' for education that never existed and could not be funded in the first place.
author: TimOfAltona

text: This is something I can't understand. You claim to idolise Gillard yet the very person who delivered the final backstab to toss Gillard out of the top job and essentially assign her to the political scrap heap was Bill Shorten.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Bill Shorten came out and categorically stated there is nothing to see at all with Malcolm Turnbull's personal financial affairs - geeze, I'll even find the link and post it for you - he said Turnbull has done nothing illegal or untoward with his tax arrangements and conceded he was correctly paying his Australian taxes on overseas investments.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Your constant efforts in trying to build an imaginary bridge between the Panama Papers and the PM are doomed to crash and burn, a bit like the Labor party at the next election IMO.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Not ONE comment today how Newspoll is nothing more than a Murdoch conspiracy to keep the LNP in government - that is both refreshing and a giant step forward for the Labor/Greens cheer squad.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Now, let's keep that lack of accusations against Newspoll going when the next poll to come out showing the government has regained the lead and Turnbull's popularity has increased.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I go where the bookies go and also with yesterday's Fairfax Poll which shows the government would have a comfortable win if an election were held today.....why? Because all the polls consistently show that Turnbull is preferred PM over Shorten by 2 to 1 (there's a trend for you) and given that Australians are sick and tired of revolving door PM's (on par with Italy) there is little prospect of the door spinning again and out pops Bingle Bill for his turn.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Mind you, yesterday's Fairfax poll had the government comfortably ahead of Labor on a 2 PP and Turnbull streets ahead of Shorten as preferred PM, so hang in there Albo and Labor's left faction, there's still hope for you yet!
author: TimOfAltona

text: In many ways you make a lot of sense with that comment. The same applies to the revolving door of Australian PM's for the past 10 years - I think we're ahead of Italy in PM turnover of late. A bit of a laughing stock at any examination. How many Australian PMs' has Obama hosted at the White House during his presidential term?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Precisely why voters are in no mood to see yet another change in the PM. Turnbull will get at least another full term to implement reform and bring stability to government. Even better if he doesn't need to herd cats in the senate anymore to get legislation through.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Here's a tip.......Shorten tried and then crashed and burned with that tactic when Turnbull ascended to the top job. In fact he he realised it had backfired on Labor he came out and said the PM has done nothing wrong, illegal or underhanded in his personal financial affairs.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Yes we all know that Turnbull both facilitates and pays Australian taxes on his investments through the Cayman Islands, just like tens of thousands of others, including superannuation funds.
author: TimOfAltona

text: This is in part because of potential conflict of interest pertaining to his role as both a senior government minister and then PM. He needs to keep his local investments at arms length and have them managed for him, much like we all do with superannuation funds.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Largely off the back of falling global commodity prices - it's how this conundrum is handled which sits at the core of which party is best equipped to guide the country through falling revenues and increased government spending on health and education.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Not at all. Dio Wang understands that the government is not going to individually negotiate with all 8 cross benchers - consensus will never be reached - akin to hearding cats.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Running to The Guardian to accuse the government of not negotiating your amendments is not going to work out too well for your political future or your amendments Dio. Just saying.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Something tells me Dennis Jensen's fury is nothing compared to the Labor/Greens cheer squad who like to dine out on the notion that it is only the LNP who like to roll around in coal mines.
author: TimOfAltona

text: It'll be a shame in a way if the cross benchers cave into self interest to protect their skin and give the government the numbers to pass the legislation.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The DD will in all probability deliver government back to the Turnbull administration so he can get on with enacting the necessary reform measures plus enjoying an internal mandate to boot.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I think Aussies get it that Turnbull needs a strong win to consolidate his position for the next 6 years or so. In the meantime the ALP can go about arranging their promised (never delivered) reform and rebuild under a new leadership team.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Let's get this straight, it was never there to fund in the first place. It was an aspiration borne out of a fractured COAG meeting that had most premiers scratching their heads over who/what/where was the money ever coming from in the first place.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The states have no right to demand increased taxation from the Commonwealth to fund their schools and hospitals when they are unwilling to implement themselves to try and safeguard their own electoral viability.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Labor turn their back on Australian naval shipbuilding during their 6 long years in government and Bingle Bill has the audacity or should we say hypocrisy to accuse the government of doing nothing to support Australian shipbuilding.
author: TimOfAltona

text: By the looks of most of these comments, it seems the key concern is not that the way these donations found their way to the Libs, but that the funds went to the Libs and not Labor.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Fairly safe to say Lenore will be the Labor cheer squad darling today......which will all change as soon as she reports on a negative about Shorten or the ALP, then she will morph into a News Ltd apologist.
author: TimOfAltona

text: On the surface it looks like it may not be a bad tactic for Labor - unless of course they have skeletons they don't want aired or uncovered in which case it's highly unlikely Labor will go down that track.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Of course the Labor premiers had to follow Bill's scripting for every word they uttered, so putting their comments aside as irrelevant, it was a pretty good outcome today IMO.
author: TimOfAltona

text: So how come with 6 years of Labor government with Swanny telling us umpteen times he was going to deliver us a budget surplus with Gillard looking on nodding away in agreement that none of this was addressed?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Australians are not interested in rewarding the ALP with another turn at government after the disaster of the Rudd/Gillard/Rudd years. On top of that the ALP union controlled factions went ahead and put their chief faceless back stabber in as leader over the person Labor members wanted - Albo.
author: TimOfAltona

text: This is exactly why Shorten has a popularity rating wallowing around somewhere on the ocean floor and unlikely to surface, something the Labor cheer squad seen totally oblivious to in their haste to demonise their arch enemy, the LNP.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Voters will give the Turnbull administration another term in government to sort out the mess labor left us with and meanwhile Labor can go ahead and start their reform and rebuild with another leader.
author: TimOfAltona

text: It was the logical step and until that happens, all governments, Liberal or Labor/Greens, will be struggling to get any sort of traction when it comes to funding health and education not to mention all the other worthwhile social services needing attention.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I keep harping on about NZ and I know it's a smaller population base etc, but they very successfully increased GST in two stages, 10 to 12.5% then 12.5% to 15% and have never looked back. Also, in NZ it's broad based (on everything) and John Key even went to an election with a policy to increase GST to 15% and had a very comfortable win.
author: TimOfAltona

text: No getting away from the fact that Gillard bluffed her way through that coag meeting which claimed $80bn in funding was headed to the states and was never there except in some pie in the sky unrealistic Labor party produced forward estimates.
author: TimOfAltona

text: A positive outcome considering the Labor premiers are clearly being coached by Shorten relating to any statements they make (it is an election year after all). Turnbull was right to table the revised tax plan for evaluation and discussion - every option needs to be explored to fix the looming revenue shortfall.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The funny thing about political polls in Australia, the Left only accept/believe polls that show Labor/Greens improving or ahead and instantly dismiss any poll showing the opposite as bogus or a media conspiracy.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Presumably Bill has already got to the Labor premiers warning them not to publicly praise any aspect of the proposal (he was too late with the ACT Chief Minister) but the premiers are the best ones to decide if this has merit. There are certainly elements which will benefit the states, but some smaller states may feel disadvantaged.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Important as it is to many, it is not the main game in town for mainstream voters when they consider who is best equipped to take this country forward.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Working on the valid assumption that SSM will be legislated for whether an LNP or ALP/Greens government is in office, it's all in the timing from here, it is management of the economy that is the main game right now.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Who is best equipped to guide Australia through the rough and tumble of falling commodity prices and the weaker economies of our major trading partners - an ex-union hack who's only claim to fame is (apart from backstabbing two sitting Labor PM's) his performance in front of the cameras at the Beaconsfield mine disaster or a successful global businessman, lawyer and philanthropist turned politician taking this country down a centrist political path very similar to the long term government of John Key in NZ.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I think it's fair to say that any and all policies tabled by the government will be instantly consigned to the waste paper basket by the Labor cheer squad, irrespective of it's merits.
author: TimOfAltona

text: It will be ratings winner for Sky. Even the Labor cheer squad will be signing up for Foxtel so they don't miss out on what promises to be unprecedented and riveting political debate.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Overseas readers may be a little confused over this story - it appears for all the world like the Greens are in the running to form government after the next election and implement these policies.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Perhaps not at strange as it may seem given the former Labor government invited the Greens into bed with them during the Gillard experiment coining the phrase a 'Labor/Greens government'.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Bottom line here, the ALP can never win government in this country again without being propped up by the Greens and the Greens will have little or no political clout, in the Lower House at least, without hopping back into bed with Labor.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Expect to see the foreplay commence once the election date is set with Bill Shorten sending a bunch of red roses and a box of Cadbury Favourites over to Di Natali's pad with a note saying 'Let's catch up for a coffee - all is forgiven'
author: TimOfAltona

text: Suggesting that persons over the age of 65 are senile is not a good look for the ALP supporters trying to grapple with the notion that Sophie may return to parliament.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Let's hope Sophie has a solid win in Indi. The parliament has been poorer for her absence and she was a good performer for the LNP and the government will be richer if she returns to the front bench next term IMO.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Kathy McGowan has been a fairly solid advocate for her seat but nothing beats the experience of Sophie and particularly if she returns to the inner sanctum of the government as the Member for Indi in addition to increasing the female representation in senior government ranks.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I'm with you on the defence spending. Seems way over the top when those billions (on the submarines in particular) could be channeled back into social services such as hospitals, schools, suicide prevention and the like.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The mere fact that Windsor is the darling of the left, graphically illustrated within this thread, pretty much sums up his chances in NE against the Leader of the Nationals and Deputy PM.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Barnaby Joyce is probably correct. Why else would Tony Windsor put himself through all this at his age? In the event Windsor wins he won't have the same clout he enjoyed whilst propping up a Gillard Labor government, he'll just be a single independent sitting up the back with zero influence on how the lower house votes and he won't be showered with benefits like he was by Gillard in order to keep her in government.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Barnaby has actually done a pretty good job in his new role as National's leader and deputy PM....he's fairly safe in his seat you would think up against a proxy for the ALP in Windsor?
author: TimOfAltona

text: New England have not forgotten what Windsor did in defying his conservative voter base and hopping into bed with the disaster of a Gillard government. No wonder he bailed out before the voters of NE could throw him out in 2013.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Most people know the ALP is a product of and largely controlled by the unions, so Billy boy has to choose his words very carefully else he be accused of running a protection racket for corruption and criminality within the union movement ( a bit like Julia Gillard blatantly protecting Craig Thompson during the Health Services saga). If Shorten brings on a DD because he fails to support the ABCC re-instatement I know which way the votes will go and it's unlikely to be good news for Labor.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Your article is music to the ears of the Labor cheer squad Kristina. It feeds directly into their narrative they have been trying to erroneously string along about a 'do nothing' PM.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I thought all the panelists were great to listen to last night. Ed Husic was solid as usual, Holly Ransom brilliant and Wyatt Roy probably surprised a lot of people unaware of how articulate and informed he is across his portfolio.
author: TimOfAltona

text: It's stating the bleeding obvious Wyatt would not be critical of the government's NBN rollout - he's a junior minister who hopes to one day be a senior minister and no one expects him to destroy his career by being openly critical of the government's NBN rollout policy on Q&A particularly in an election year.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You watch the ABC more and learn something. As with Sky news, ABC have plenty of platforms representing opinions from the left and the right. You seem to want all the news broadcasts to offer up anti-government propaganda on a daily basis.
author: TimOfAltona

text: In other words you want to see a constant barrage of everything negative about the LNP government - if you don't see a healthy diet of this on a daily basis the ABC are somehow pandering to the right.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Open your eyes, all the issues you list have been reported and at times discussed on the ABC in various formats - the fact that each news broadcast does not lead with a negative piece on the Liberal Party places them in the 'enemy' bin in your narrow mind.
author: TimOfAltona

text: If you want a left leaning media outlet look no further than the Guardian, which I guess is why so many of you flock to these threads for group support.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The ABC is not here to pander to the narrow and biased views of the Labor/Greens cheer squad, it is here to represent the views and interests of ALL Australians and they do a pretty good job producing some excellent content given their budgetary constraints.
author: TimOfAltona

text: All former PM's like to protect their legacy....name one PM who does not think he/she did a great job whilst in office. Gillard reckons she did, Rudd reckons he did and Abbott likewise believes he had some achievements chalked up on the Prime Ministerial tally board.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I suspect you have your PM's all mixed up. Abbott was liaising with the Sri Lankan PM over boats, it was Julia Gillard cosying up to the Malaysian PM over her failed 'Malaysian Solution'.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Of the thousands of Bronwyn Bishop images the Guardian have access to, they stick one of the most unflattering ones you can think of at the header to the article.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Actually I didn't mind Bronwyn in the Speaker chair - she did a pretty good job of keeping an undisciplined and often childishly incalcitrant Labor opposition in check, but probably should have been firmer at times to maintain the decorum of the parliament.
author: TimOfAltona

text: There is a cavalcade of Labor pollies lining up to be interviewed each day alongside their Liberal/Nat counterparts and even those two Labor stalwarts Richo and Keneally have their own shows.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Personally don't have much time for Cory, but have even less time for leftie activists who fabricate emails, destroy other people's property and maliciously attack those who have differing views &/or opinions.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Many large corporations run this way - not a bad idea at all - although many also have 'Company' Amex Cards, but with strict boundaries and guidelines as to their use.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I'm willing to bet the most severe cases are in corruption riddled regimes where corruption at all levels fleeces millions or billions of dollars in money that should be channeled into infrastructure for these communities ends up in the hidden overseas bank accounts of high ranking officials.
author: TimOfAltona

text: If I were Turnbull, I'd be going down the DD route. Clean out the senate of all the imposters who gamed the system to snatch a seat at the table and potentially give the government control of both houses.
author: TimOfAltona

text: This may be the only way to break the toxic antics of the past 8 years and let the government elected by the people do something we haven't seen in a long time - govern.
author: TimOfAltona

text: If the government stuffs up we go to another election in 2019 and Labor it they are good enough, will have every opportunity to retake the government benches and have their turn again.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I think voters all get it that a strong win for Malcolm will end the Abbott era and Turnbull's next term government will have both a mandate from the people and clear air within the party to resolve many outstanding issues and implement more centrist policies that will cement MT into a long serving Australian PM.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Australians are sick and tired of revolving door PMs - time for some government and political stability. NZ have lead the way in this respect for years under the John Key administration.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Dais, I can just picture the Turnbull cabinet sitting around the table with Malcolm leading off the discussion with "how can we keep ourselves in power to the detriment of all Australians?".
author: TimOfAltona

text: The other problem you have is your "Light on the Hill" party all but snuffed out the light years ago and left you with a rump of a Labor Party a mere shadow of it's former glory. Some say Shorten is further to the right than Turnbull.
author: TimOfAltona

text: A good strong win to Turnbull will cement his administration into government for years to come - why? Because he will have the internal mandate to depart from the Abbott years and move forward with his centrist vision for Australia encompassing climate change, SSM and tax reform.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The prospect of a DD election is too tantalising to pass up, especially when it looks like you will do very well out of it and not only retain government but remould the senate makeup to reflect the wishes of voters, unlike today's mish mash of odds and sods.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The only major concern is the length of the campaign. Long campaigns are notoriously dangerous with a media hanging out for candidates to trip up and trip ups there will be, on both sides.
author: TimOfAltona

text: FDOTM has regularly thrown Ricky Muir's favourite projectile at the LNP and equally copious amounts at the ALP, but can't for the life of me remember him targeting the Greens.
author: TimOfAltona

text: We can well understand why Labor under strict instructions from their union masters want to block it....but the Greens and the cross benchers should be guided by what the majority of Australian voters called for - a body to root out corruption and criminality in the Australian building industry.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Just waiting for the philandering Greens to jump back out of the 'royal blue' bedsheets into the ALP bed resplendent with its 'socialist red' satin sheets, Eureka Flag Queen size bedspread, 'Solidarity Forever' CD sensuously wafting across the room as a viagra substitute, third party parked car insurance policies on the bedside table and a bearded Karl Marx portrait looking down creepily from the wall whilst CFMEU heavies block the door to prevent any further escape.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Labor and its supporters have been screaming for an election for years, yet when an election date looks likely all Penny wants to do is run away and hide and hope it all goes away so the dreaded date can't happen. Clearly they are happy to remain in opposition for as long as possible.
author: TimOfAltona

text: In some ways it may not be a bad thing...clean out the old dead baggage laden wood and start afresh with the promised but never delivered reform and rebuild under a shiny new leadership team.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You have to feel a bit sorry for Georgina, there was not much in it at the end. She has plenty to offer the parliament so hopefully may pop up in another seat. A good pedigree counts for plenty in politics.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Always dangerous thing to rub the crystal ball too much, but provided he does not blot his copybook, Tim is a certain candidate for future Leader of The Liberal Party and therefore PM.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I suspect you are talking a very tight knit closed shop in this thread who would rather chew off their left arm at the shoulder than Vote Liberal 1.
author: TimOfAltona

text: An interesting aside to this. I was at a McDonalds for lunch in Bangkok a couple of years ago and there was a table of secondary school 'girls' about 15 or 16 yrs old at the next table all kitted out in school uniform dresses, makeup and jewellery and makeup. They were not girls of course, but boys dressed as girls and obviously identifying as transgender at that age. Interesting because they were joined by other school students who were dressed in uniforms appropriate to their gender, boys and girls, and it looked like any other group of noisy school kids enjoying themselves at lunch at McDonalds.
author: TimOfAltona

text: It was explained that the buddhist religion is tolerant of children dressing to their identified/chosen gender and was common at most Thai high schools and regarded as quite normal. Some high schools had transgender toilets and change rooms for those not wanting to go into the male or female facilities.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Gimme a sec and I'll let you know what the Gillard government spent on Labor party propaganda disguised as Government advertising in the lead up to the 2010 election - it was in the multiple millions of taxpayer money.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Time you gave up your obsession with Tony Abbott. He is not here to rescue Labor Dais, as much as you and your cheer squad cohorts want him to return like a knight on a white horse to rescue the hapless Shorten, it just ain't going to happen.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Problem with your assertion that this is a government the Greens voters can't stand - perhaps yes, perhaps no, but what people do know is that we have in Turnbull one of the most enlightened PM's this country has had in decades.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Leaving the DD option on the table is a good thing. The Turnbull government needs clear air to take this parliament forward after the toxic environment of the past 8 years - providing they can obtain full benefit from a DD election of course.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The crazy thing about all this is that Labor were originally supportive of this senate reform bill but decided they wanted to prop up the micro party senators who gamed the system on a handful of primary votes to get into parliament.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Do you really think the ABC would deliberately block Shorten's speech and realistically who would be interested in listening to his election propaganda? Boring as bat shit and of little public interest.
author: TimOfAltona
