text: A little off topic, but the conservative government in the UK have passed a 'sugar' tax on sugar laden soft drinks - will raise significant revenues for the government.
author: TimOfAltona

text: It takes a fair bit of patience to deal with the Labor party in the House of Reps - started when Labor were tossed out and they haven't learnt yet that flouting standing orders is detrimental for them. Shorten needs to exercise more control over his rabble.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Pyne is a pretty sharp operator, one of the better performing ministers. Turnbull goes about it with a different style which seems to resonate with voters as far as I (and the polls) can see.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Let no one forget that under Labors watch, tens of thousands of people were sent to detention facilities on and offshore in Australia and 1000+ people perished at sea - why? Because Labor lost control of the borders.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I don't think the red satin sheets with the Eureka flag bedspread and Solidarity Forever playing on the CD with a portrait of Karl Marx staring down from the wall will cut it any more.
author: TimOfAltona

text: For gods sake give it a rest. Your hundreds of daily posts attacking journos and the media is starting to sound unhinged. I know we need to protect free speech and all, but I think you made your point about the media a few thousand posts ago.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I dunno, seems to me if people protest peacefully and within the law they have nothing to worry about - it's when they step outside the law and start doing stupid things like damaging equipment and wilfully trespassing and obstructing people going who are about their lawful business then these laws are a good thing.
author: TimOfAltona

text: No, they are one on one only. She asked Shorten for two during the election campaign, he agreed then she said she would ask the same of Turnbull next time he is on 7.30.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Bottom line here - no one votes for a local candidate if they don't like or trust the leader of his/her party (OK perhaps occasionally) and herein lies Labor's biggest hurdle.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Not sure what the answer is for Bill, but maybe if he had embarked on the much promised party reform and rebuild when he came into the role instead of sitting back, doing nothing and thinking all he had to do was be there to beat an unpopular PM in Abbott, the ALP may find themselves in a much stronger position today.
author: TimOfAltona

text: When Sales asked how in the world can an opposition leader be confident when his popularity is around a third of that of the PM he obfuscated so fast his head was spinning.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Bill is going to have to work a hell of a lot harder if voters are going to see him as a viable alternative PM - so far and as the polling indicates, he just is not up to it. I don't think he has a hope in hell to be honest.
author: TimOfAltona

text: It can only strengthen the Turnbull government with Fiona Nash as our new Deputy PM ( a very good look) and probably make way for more women in Turnbull's front bench for the next term.
author: TimOfAltona

text: It means that if a journo reports on something and the content sits outside the narrative of one particular group, they attack him/her and try to bully or threaten him/her into skewing the report/commentary to fit that group's narrative - just as you have done here.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I reckon Katharine is miles above that crap and will continue to report and call it as she sees it which is calling out both sides if they stuff up. Too bad if it does not fit your narrative.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Cleanevent and Shorten springs to mind here. Some 5000 Cleanevent workers were allegedly dudded out of $400m in entitlements out of the dodgy deal Shorten did with the management to try and boost AWU numbers.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Be a good chap and stick your head over into next cubicle where David is and arrange for the two of you to meet at the water cooler next break and get your stories about the Greens aligned.
author: TimOfAltona

text: After watching QT today, you can easily see why Turnbull is favourite to take himself and his government into another 3 year term (better if it were 4 years) at this year's elections.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Labor cannot win with Shorten (Mr record unpopularity) as leader. People don't like him or trust him given his track record in stabbing a succession of sitting Labor PM's in the back to reach the same job for himself.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I hope she is being carefully scripted before she opens her mouth because her ignorance on foreign affairs issues is telling. I'd almost bet she would be hard pressed to point out Iran on a map, let alone wade into complex and sensitive global issues of which she has little understanding. Foreign Affairs is hardly her forte.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Perhaps the Libs should preference the Greens ahead of Labor in Sydney and put her out to pasture and give Labor the opportunity to renew it's leadership team? Same with Albo.
author: TimOfAltona

text: It seems no one likes the ALP anymore, yet here they are, riding on the path to glory striking down anyone who gets their way lead by their illustrious (no parked car is safe) leader Bill Shorten, the most unpopular opposition leader since federation who will single handedly on his way up the mountain to reignite the long gone 'light on the hill' whilst totally eliminating unemployment and deftly destroying the housing market along the way.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You and I both know Labor haven't a snow flakes chance in hell of winning an election without being propped up by the Greens, so your feigned attack on DiNatale fools no one.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Curious move by Smith - this is all about the numbers and Smith must have been advised he had the numbers when in fact they were never there in the first place.
author: TimOfAltona

text: This was always going to be a risky tactic by Labor, going early on such a massive issue which has been a no go area on all sides of parliament for decades.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I think Katharine is on the money here, I also think that a strong win to Turnbull will see a  of drawn out contentious issues sorted during the next term...if Turnbull has a convincing win that should see him gain a much needed internal mandate and win some party room battles over the remnants of the the far right in the party.
author: TimOfAltona

text: He will also be in a unique position to engage with both the Greens and Labor to arrive at acceptable compromises to push some of this stuff through the senate so we can all move forward.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Australians are sick and tired of revolving door PM's - we are currently beating even Italy in that sphere...let's stick with the one we've got and give it a red hot go.
author: TimOfAltona

text: In all fairness I think the whole of Australia got QLD wrong, including most of the Labor party themselves - have you ever seen such a stunned look on the face of a newly elected Premier before? Palaszczuk could not believe what had just happened.
author: TimOfAltona

text: To be fair to her also, she has not done such a bad job given her minority government status...not sure what the voters in QLD think of it all now though.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Always a good idea to take a look at the latest betting odds during times of people arguing over poll results - they are a reasonably accurate indicator of the state of play...so today we have
author: TimOfAltona

text: So I say to all the of posters in these threads posting hundreds of times (finnigans here's looking at you amongst others) announcing that Labor are in for a landslide win and Tony Abbott is about to replace Turnbull as PM before the election - go for it!!!!!!!!
author: TimOfAltona

text: Last I looked we have a new PM, a new deputy PM, a new Treasurer, a new Health Minister, a new Defence Minister, a new Small Business Minister, a new Trade Minister, a new Education Minister, a new Agriculture Minister etc etc etc...
author: TimOfAltona

text: I'm picking if Turnbull get's the strong win in the election, he will have the mandate to take the party back towards the sensible centre and probably even occupy some space a paniced Labor gave up to chase the popular vote whenShorten came on the scene.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I think Turnbull's small target strategy has worked pretty well, it's certainly got the ALP and it's supporters off balance because they want something tangible to try and tear apart - in the absence of that they need to make things up to try and keep the anti-government narrative going.
author: TimOfAltona

text: That said, the budget will be the 'do or die' moment for the government. I'm picking they will go for a more centrist model and there will be winners and there will be losers. Providing the winners are mostly mainstream Australians, the government will be on a winner and Labor will have nowhere to go (except out the door again).
author: TimOfAltona

text: I think one thing we can all agree on is that Howard's stand on gun control in Australia was a true measure of leadership and strength and he passed on all counts.
author: TimOfAltona

text: One her biggest events fast approaching is hosting the Iranian Foreign Minister Javad Zarif in Canberra later this week. Australia may be a relatively minor player on the world stage but from time to time punch above our weight - this is one such occasion.
author: TimOfAltona

text: It is a little curious. I guess Abbott has a huge fan base in his electorate who were pissed when he lost the prime ministership. Does not mean they won't vote Liberal though. They want to see Abbott stay in parliament, even if it's on the back bench.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Turnbull remains the peoples' choice for PM of this nation. He holds a commanding lead over his nearest rival, Bill Shorten. In fact Shorten's approval rating indicates he is the exact opposite to Turnbull ie: people don't want him as PM (Labor take note).
author: TimOfAltona

text: The LNP hold a 2PP lead over Labor - if an election were held today the Turnbull government would be comfortably returned. The other hidden danger for Labor is that if the Greens direct preferences away from Labor in certain seats, both Plibersek and Albo could be thrown out of parliament. The ALP stand to lose it's current senior team at the next election and with Shorten certain to stand down, it may be the catalyst for Labor to start it's promised but never delivered party reform.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Trust me, whether Barnaby holds his seat or does not means zip to the outcome of the election. Spinning your wheels over trying to prop up Tony Windsor is a fools game. The seat of NE will not determine the outcome of the election - your biggest problem is you have an unelectable leader in Bill Shorten. Until Labor face that fact a Labor/Greens government is but a wet dream for Labor supporters.
author: TimOfAltona

text: PS - In a way it would be a win for the LNP if Barnaby were to lose his seat - it would deliver the country a deputy PM in Fiona Nash.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I'm talking about polling - there is a definite pattern here - denounce any poll showing Labor falling away as fraudulent or a conspiracy and praise any poll that shows Labor improving. Either you believe in polling or you don't.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I bow to your knowledge and experience and undying loyalty to the ALP...but here's a tip....denouncing Turnbull as a bag of wind isn't going to get Labor across the line this year nor is the fact that some of the Labor front bench have been around the block a couple times (those that survived all the knifings and resignations during the R/G/R train wreck) as many of them carry baggage especially your leader and deputy leader - saddle bags very full indeed.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Smith trying to make a power grab in WA - he'd be better served going for Bingle Bill's job - couldn't be any less popular with the electorate and you never know he may give the ALP a boost in the polls.
author: TimOfAltona

text: A vote for Windsor is a vote for Labor. I think the conservative voters of NE won't want a fellow who pushed a toxic Gillard Labor government onto this country and then bailed out before he was pushed in 2013 to be rewarded with a seat.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Well, in 2013 we all thought we had put Labor out to pasture where they belonged, I guess this year gives us the opportunity to ensure they stay there - putting Labor candidates last will achieve that.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Pretty safe to say a vote for Joyce is a vote for Labor - so you don't have too much to worry about there - unless of course you reside in New England.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Good on him. He's in wth a good chance - it's not as if the minority Labor government have endeared themselves with voters - in fact the opposite. He would make an excellent MP for Queensland IMO.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The problem for them all is that government turned out to be the most unpopular government with the most unpopular PM the nation had ever experienced in Julia Gillard - the voters of New England will not forget that.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The other issue for Windsor is he bailed out when everything went pear shaped for Labor he knew he didn't have a snowflakes chance in hell of holding his seat in the 2013 election so he jumped before he was pushed.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The prospect of the Greens hopping out of the marital bed with Labor and having a few passionate dalliances with the Liberal party has Labor in a tail spin.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The danger of course is that if the Greens think the Libs performance in bed is better than that of their tired and worn out conjugal partner, then Labor will need more than viagra to entice the Greens back between the red satin sheets with the Eureka flag bedspread and the Solidarity Forever tune playing like an aphrodisiac in the background.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Delicious isn't it - the prospect of the Greens and the Libs declaring their passion for each other and poor old Labor stuck loveless like a shag on a rock with no friends, no preferences and no hope of returning to government for a decade or more.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Hang on.....you are quoting Newspoll as a reliable barometer to back up your assertion Labor are about to win the election, yet when the very same Newspoll shows Labor drifting away it is nothing more than a Murdoch conspiracy to help the Libs stay in government and should be totally ignored.
author: TimOfAltona

text: July is looking good, the sooner that is done and dusted the sooner we can move forward with Abbott playing little or no role as a backbencher in the next Turnbull government and Malcolm with a mandate to move the government back towards the sensible centre.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Despite the bleatings and vitriol directed at him by the left, he calls a spade a spade and if he does not like the look of something he speaks his mind and has been extremely critical of some LNP government decisions in recent years.
author: TimOfAltona

text: So let's drop this focussing on her hair or voice or gender as a way to score petty and childish political points and focus on her strengths as a smart, articulate woman who's policies or performance you may or may not agree with.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I thought Michaela Cash was very impressive last night. Great personality and intellect but unfortunately for her, as a strong and powerful woman from the right side of politics, attracts criticism from misogynists on the left who cowardly target her appearance and voice because to them she is an easy female target.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I thought Josh Zepps portrayal of Penny Wong as a wounded gazelle thrashing around at the watering hole when she came on a previous Q&A supporting Julia Gillard's position on 'no' to same sex marriage was brilliant.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The ALP who you have long been campaigning to return to government whilst totally ignoring their abject failures in both leadership and and looking for all the world as a mere proxy for the worst elements of the trade union movement.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Time to admit that Labor have done precious little to implement party reform after their crushing defeat in 2013 and they have not yet earned the right to wiggle their way back into government purely off the back of a seemingly unpopular former Liberal leader in Abbott.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Turnbull needs clear air to prosecute his centrist vision for government and I reckon Australians will give him the chance to deliver on that in his next term in government.
author: TimOfAltona

text: In the meantime Labor can resolve their leadership conundrum, get rid of Shorten and replace him with a leader who can lead the reform and rebuild and take the party forward.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I can understand why you dislike him - Tony was largely responsible for one of the most crushing defeats of any political party in the history of the country - it was a shellacking of Labor of the highest order and they'll take years to recover.
author: TimOfAltona

text: True, but their membership numbers (GetUp) show they would qualify as a registered political party if they chose - would have thought the senate would be an ideal environment for an activist organisation.
author: TimOfAltona

text: There is a very good story in the Guardian today how much the Islamic community appreciate the change Turnbull has brought to the nation's rhetoric about countering extremism and fostering Islamic community inclusiveness in the fabric of Australia.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Time you stopped alluding to speaking on behalf of Australia David....reality is you speak for a minority grouping from the disaffected left who assemble in Guardian threads. Mainstream Australia, the majority of voters, have a very different view to yours.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Abbott is a sideshow to the main game and I hope Labor end up spinning their wheels over what may or may not have occurred while Abbott was PM and give Turnbull clear air to head to an election.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Their beloved Labor Party PM's were never capable of fronting up to the Mardi Gras over all those years in government and it's taken a Liberal PM to be the first to achieve that feat.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I disagree, people know Turnbull's position on equality and same sex marriage - he has not wavered from that position - if anyone can legislate federally for same sex marriage during the term of an LNP government, he can - and will.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Welcome to the world of the Labor cheer squad, all hiding behind anonymity to see who can post the most salacious and grubby comment and get away with it. It's par for the course.
author: TimOfAltona

text: If it said something like - I don't like reading and thinking about Julia Gillard's vag*** - when stories were coming out about her previous personal life, how long do you think it would last on here?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Makes no difference one way or the other apart from giving the usual salacious gossip mongers material to propagate more hate against the former PM - as if extra-marital affairs only ever happen on the right side of politics.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I think Abbott's primary audience at the moment, apart from a media thirsty for headlines, are those around him who keep telling him he should stay and fight and win back Liberal leadership.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Go back and examine what Shorten said when he saw his Cayman Island tactic crumbling around him - "I accept that Malcolm Turnbull's tax affairs are in order and he is paying his Australian taxes according to Australian taxation laws" - or something to that effect. Go back and Google it to find it.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Persisting with the fantasy that Turnbull is somehow avoiding his Australian taxation obligations does not do your side of the argument any favours. He pays significant amount of tax on his overseas earnings and investments.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Dais, we can always count on you to paint the worst possible scenario with a bit of your own imagination and creativity thrown in to spice it up a bit.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I doubt he was the individual behind the leak - too politically smart for that - it will be someone else and I think a certain former defence minister may know a bit more about it.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You keep saying that, but we have yet to see a single poll anywhere that says Labor will win if an election were held today, in fact they say the opposite. In my view an election brought forward is in Turnbull's best interest and an election held later in the year won't favour the government so much - particularly if Tony Abbott continues to present himself as the defacto leader of the Liberal party.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Malcolm is now experiencing exactly what both Gillard and Rudd went through - a hardcore support base for their political 'rival' remained in government making outright criticism/discipline a difficult path to go down.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Either way - as Labor learned the hard way 'party disunity is death' and admittedly they have disciplined themselves fairly well under Shorten to present a united front - they know only too well to do otherwise disqualifies them from forming government for years to come.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The only way to knock this on the head for the Libs at least, is for Tony to do an Albo and come out and publicly give his unqualified support for his leader and do it quickly.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Still maintain that a strong win to Malcolm will pretty much see the sun set on Abbotts political career and I think Australians will still deliver him that strong win.
author: TimOfAltona

text: After watching Tony Abbott on Sky this morning addressing the Tasmanian Liberal function with Abetz, his speech sounded for all the world as if he was still PM and going into election mode vs Shorten - this is not helpful to Turnbull and someone needs to let Tony know that the leadership of the Libs is beyond him now - he had his turn, achieved some things but the baton has been handed to Turnbull to take the government forward for the next few years.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The Labor cheer squad seem obsessed with the notion that Abbott is about to topple Turnbull and retake the Liberal leadership - ala Kevin Rudd and Labor in 2013.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You see, the reason Rudd was successful in retaking leadership was that the whole world could see Gillard was leading the Labor Party to perhaps it's greatest defeat ever, would have been lucky to come away with 30 seats in the lower house if she was still there on Election Day and she had lost the support of the majority of her party, including Shorten who delivered the final blow to metaphorically put her out of her misery.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Now contrast that with Malcolm Turnbull who's popularity as preferred PM remains up in the stratosphere, whilst his nearest opponent Shorten remains somewhere down in the gutter. It is true that the last few polls have cut back the government's 2PP lead, but that was to be expected and no one can predict for sure where it will head in coming months.
author: TimOfAltona

text: In this environment and given Abbott's extremely low popularity whilst he was PM (granted was still higher than Shorten's) but in particular the Abbott government's consistent bad polling, there ain't a snowflakes chance in hell of Abbott successfully removing Turnbull - not now not ever.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Confusion reigns down at ALP campaign HQ - could someone let David know that Howard and Costello are not even in parliament therefore ineligible for the PM or Treasurer gigs?
author: TimOfAltona

text: You forgot to mention the locust plagues, tidal waves, earthquakes, starvation, asteroids striking the Sydney CDB and every ones first born girl is barren. I'm pretty sure I also saw the sky falling in this morning - all as a result of a Labor/Greens government not being in power.
author: TimOfAltona

text: They can't believe their luck with the Abbott thing, but they are still well behind the eight ball when it comes to forming a government out of the next election so they don't have the luxury of playing around with political mind games. They have only one shot and it's do or die for Bingle Bill.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Clearly the ALP are enjoying the post-Abbott settling in of the new Turnbull government and so they should, they went through the ringer themselves not that long ago in the post-Rudd settling in of the Gillard government and then the post-Gillard settling in of the Rudd government.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Not easy for any new PM when the person he/she defeated is hanging around in the background and has the media following them around hanging off every word.
author: TimOfAltona

text: In some ways Gillard had it tougher with Rudd because she had elevated him to the cabinet to hopefully buy his silence but that backfired on her big time.
author: TimOfAltona

text: He did - now name us a Labor PM who managed to enjoy the confidence of the Australian people equal to or longer than John Howard. In fact any PM will do, Labor or Liberal.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Some would argue he loses his ability to work with all sides of politics, one of the keys to his success thus far. Labor are a very partisan mob in the senate and Dodson may find himself shackled to the Penny Wong party machine which won't be to his liking.
author: TimOfAltona

text: That's all well and good. Wait until he finds himself shackled to the Penny Wong partisan Labor machine in the senate and he has to vote yes or no on something he personally disagrees with.
author: TimOfAltona

text: All this infighting within Labor is not a good look for Shorten who's been left holding the short straw to lead Labor to a highly probable loss at the election. (DD or otherwise).
author: TimOfAltona

text: The roots of all this discontent goes back to the inability of the Labor party to set a reform agenda when they were smashed after the R/G/R civil war.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Bill promised it when he became leader (also under controversial circumstances) but has done little or nothing to resolve the deep seated factional tensions - if anything they may have escalated, surfacing in the past few days with Bullock, Gray and now the nomination of Dodson (not even an ALP member) to the senate ahead of the widely respected Louise Pratt.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Only the Labor cheer squad are pushing that barrow hoping it can save Labor from defeat -  stands a better chance of returning to lead the Labor Party than Tony Abbott has of leading the Libs again.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Already causing problems. Louise Pratt has a strong following and significant support within the ALP and Shorten's rushed tactic to try and shore up the indigenous vote has ruffled feathers.
author: TimOfAltona

text: This has all the hallmarks of the Trish Crossin debacle in the NT where Gillard made a 'Captain's Pick' and dumped the highly respected Crossin in favour of Nova Perris.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Shorten always saw Abbott as his free ride to The Lodge - all Bill had to do was hang onto his position and 'be there' when the election came around and all would be rosy in Labor/ACTU land.
author: TimOfAltona

text: When he had his perceived 'free ride' so cruelly ripped out from under him, courtesy of the Liberal party room, he realised he had better do something and do something quickly before everything went down the gurgler for the Labor Party.
author: TimOfAltona

text: He panicked and tried to label Turnbull as 'different' from the rest of us because he had been successful in life and had accumulated personal wealth...hoping it would resonate with voters not so fortunate...well it backfired within a couple of days as it evolved voters admired Turnbull for his success and pretty much everyone saw through what the hapless Shorten was attempting. Labor dropped the 'Cayman Island' tactic like a hot potato.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Knowing he was unable to beat Turnbull in the popularity stakes and with Albo and the left faction of the ALP bearing down on him, he embarked on a bold tactic to announce a contentious taxation policy around tinkering with the hitherto 'no go' area of negative gearing.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Interesting because as we learned from Scott Morrison yesterday, Chris Bowen had been secretly concocting this 'policy' without the knowledge of Shorten for up to 12 months. Then we discover Bowen's modelling had holes in it - it adversely impacts mum and dad investors attempting to enter the established home property market as well as downward pressure on values of existing investor properties.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Never fear though Labor, this afternoon Abbott is sure to cross and uncross his legs and the moment will be captured by a photographer and it will be a headline story by this evening.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Your Labor Party have already tried that confected tactic David and it crashed and burned within days so they dropped it like a hot potato - suggest you do the same or suffer the same fate (crashing and burning).
author: TimOfAltona

text: Your Labor Party have already tried that confected tactic David and it crashed and burned within days so they dropped it like a hot potato - suggest you do the same or suffer the same fate (crashing and burning).
author: TimOfAltona

text: HaHa..only a few days ago the Labor cheer squad were saying bring on a DD to get rid of the government and look how things turn around in a matter of days - suddenly it's all about running away from a DD and making the the government serving out it's full term.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I love watching the Labor cheer squad get all excited when a poll shows Labor improving - the same polls of course are instantly dismissed as media conspiracies when they show support for Labor or Shorten dropping. LOL.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Polls come and go comrades. Did none of you hear the CEO of Roy Morgan Research last night on Q&A (this is the real world now) explain how if an election were held today, the Turnbull government would be comfortably returned?
author: TimOfAltona

text: As I've said many times , a strong win to Turnbull (and that's looking increasingly likely) at the election will cement his authority and therefore his reform agenda on the party and the government as a whole.
author: TimOfAltona

text: My view is Australians want to give him that strong win to allow him time to implement reform and give Australia that much needed political stability absent for the past 8 years or so.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Yes, the more Turnbull speaks, the more of what he is saying is resonating with voters - best to try and stop that happening as soon as possible or Labor stand zero chance of winning an election with Turnbull around huh?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Take a backseat, enjoy the ride for the next three years and work out a way the ALP can better present themselves as an alternative government in 2019. Starts with the leadership.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I know precisely how our legislature works. What we need to change is the situation where some bozo with a handful of senate primary votes somehow gets to be a senator ahead of candidates who received thousands of more primary votes and ends up threatening to block all government bills if he doesn't get his way.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Labor are not in government, going by the size of the LNP majority in the lower house, people did not want labor in government - then why should a party with a handful of reps in the lower house have the ability to block a government's ability to govern.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Voters rightly expect the democratically elected government (ie the government the majority of voters want to govern the nation) to actually govern. When a recalcitrant senate blocks bills thus disallowing the duly elected government to govern, then we have the shambles of the past 2.5 years occurring.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Australians are yearning for stable government and a government that actually 'governs' - fixing up the senate will assist with that, whether it be a Liberal or Labor government in office.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Last I looked we elect a government to govern the nation for the following 3 years - it is a ludicrous situation when some bozo attracts a handful of primary votes and works his/her way into the senate via a series of complex preference deals - hardly representative of the people and then goes onto blocking government bills and good governance of the nation.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The Labor cheer squad would share my opinion on this if it were their party in government and a mishmash of blow ins in the senate were frustrating Labor's ability to actually govern the nation.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The sooner the voting reform bill goes through and the sooner a DD is called and we can get down to electing a government and senate to actually govern the nation and provide political stability for at least a term - something we haven't seen for the last 8 years.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Bit difficult with a recalcitrant senate - the sooner the senate voting reforms are passed, the sooner we can see the government duly elected by the people to, well, err.........govern.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Clearly the tussle over senate voting reform indicates Labor have fallen way short of winning the hearts and minds of the electorate and are not expecting to win any federal elections any time soon otherwise why would they want to stand in the way of the ALP both being in government and potentially having control of the senate (in partnership with the Greens) aka known as leftie utopia?
author: TimOfAltona

text: I thought one of the most interesting comments of the evening came from Michele Levine CEO of Roy Morgan Research - that if an election were held today, Malcolm Turnbull's government would be safely returned.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Perhaps a DD is the way to go, clean up the senate so the elected government can actually govern and give Turnbull a further 3 years to implement his reform agenda.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Hey you never know what may happen. I know for a fact West Papua is on his radar and hopefully on his 'to do' list if he is rewarded with another term.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I'm probably the last person you want recommending your comment, but I have. It is a fair and reasonable summary and a refreshing change from most of the partisan tripe posted on this thread. Tonight we saw why Turnbull is probably the leader to effect positive change/reform - he needs a strong win whether it is via a DD or a general election at the end of the year to gather the momentum to achieve that positive social and fiscal change.
author: TimOfAltona

text: In my view the leaders of the two major parties, Shorten and Turnbull are both decent people but there can only be one of them in The Lodge for the next 3 years and by what I saw on Q&A tonight most Australians are backing Turnbull to stay the course and deliver the political stability absent over the past 8 years.
author: TimOfAltona

text: All it achieves is to attract the usual rusted on Labor mob peddling grubby and offensive comments, perhaps to compensate for their own inability to express emotion or just the usual hate filled comments directed at anyone who presents a threat to Labor's chances of winning back government in the next few years.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Interesting that the little 'engagement' Shorten had with Corey during the presser the other day actually started with Shorten commenting to Bernardi as he walked past in the corridor - then Corey responded and Shorten shot back with the homophobe remark.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Fortuitously for Labor it was somehow 'lost' under piles of papers on the desk of one Anthony Albanese so did not see the public light of day until the new administration came in.
author: TimOfAltona

text: So...anyone can hop on the GetUp site and start a petition - great, I may hop on and start a "Let's re-elect Turnbull at the next election" petition....see how long that one survives.
author: TimOfAltona

text: A GetUp endorsed candidate, even with the support of the Greens and their Labor partners, winning the highly conservative seat of New England held by the sitting Deputy PM of the nation has about as much chance of getting up as Gough Whitlam has of returning to lead the Labor Party.
author: TimOfAltona

text: They were about to vote him out last election as payback for the disastrous Gillard years. Not too sure the electorate will want the same bloke back who this time is linked to the far left anti-everything activists in GetUp.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Polling in New England prior to the 2013 election had the Nats at 67% primary vote vs Windsor's 25% - hence you can see why Windsor did the big bail out.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Any chance you can explain how Windsor would have held his seat in the 2013 election when polling showed the Nationals had a primary vote of 67% to Windsor's 25%?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Not too sure New England voters want a GetUp front man representing them, plus he carries enormous baggage from the failed Gillard administration which wasn't all that long ago.
author: TimOfAltona

text: All I saw was he was about to be given the royal boot from his seat at the last election as payback for his support for the deeply unpopular, almost reviled Gillard administration.
author: TimOfAltona

text: GetUp! appear further to the left than the Greens. A key platform encourages opening up of Australian borders and accepting all who want to come to Australia claiming asylum - under GetUp policy Australia would become a magnet for the global people smuggling industry.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Well it seems the tables they had booked at the Mauka Subway to celebrate the 20th anniversary to office of this country's second longest serving PM fell through, so they had to book a room at Parliament House at short notice.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Anyone else get the impression from this morning's Insiders that Albo is priming himself to take over the reigns of the ALP immediately after the election? (In the likely event of a coalition victory)
author: TimOfAltona

text: I think we can all agree he will be a much more formidable adversary to take on the Turnbull government next term. His deputy will be interesting...I don't think he'll want to bring Plibersek over, she has not been a strong performer and carries baggage from the failed Gillard/Rudd years, but I guess the usual Labor factional arm wrestles will determine the Deputy.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The Labor front bench talent pool sort of drifts away beyond Chris Bowen and perhaps Dreyfus, so in his reshuffle Albo needs to bring in talent like Ed Husic and perhaps the screaming banshee (in QT at least) from the seat of Griffith.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Conservative governments have a habit of being around for longer periods. The signs are good for Turnbull provided he has a solid win next election and settles into his first full term as Australian PM.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Is it just me or isn't it better to see the policies of the government before passing judgement and deciding who gets your second preferences? Otherwise how can you compare?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Nothing more than a mix of Labor propaganda and wishful thinking. Claiming Abbott will do a "Rudd" is delusional. Rudd "stepped in" because Gillard was about as popular as a liberal MP at a CFMEU bbq.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Turnbull on the other hand enjoys the confidence of the majority of Australian voters as evidenced by both the polls, the bookies and mainstream voters - hardly the climate to replace him as leader.
author: TimOfAltona

text: There is an element of truth in what you say. That said, a strong win for Turnbull will give him the clear air he needs to implement reform. It's whether Australia wants to delver him that strong win or face the prospect of a 6th PM in almost as many years.
author: TimOfAltona

text: This piece is a fair and measured observation of things as they stand today and summarises the challenges facing both Shorten and Turnbull along with their respective strengths and weaknesses.
author: TimOfAltona

text: If you were to do a good old fashioned SWOT analysis on Shorten and Turnbull as who is most likely to win at the next election you would arrive at the conclusion that the election is Turnbull's to lose.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Something fairly catastrophic would need to occur for the LNP to fall short and if you examine things objectively Labor's two biggest threats remain - they simply have too many seats in the lower house to make up and their leader carries exceptionally heavy baggage and a has a constant low popularity rating, hovering around the death zone.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Turnbull on the other hand enjoys the complete opposite, a massive majority in the lower house and a popularity rating up in the stratosphere. No wonder the bookies have the LNP as firm favourites with Labor as rank outsiders.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I think the 'Chinese' are a bit smarter than you give them credit for - they will know more about what's going on with Abbott than most which means they will not be linking Abbott with the current Australian government.
author: TimOfAltona

text: With Gillard voters had no idea why she topped Rudd & with little or no justification given it came back to haunt her, whilst with Turnbull pretty much every man and his dog knew why Abbott was removed with plenty of fanfare and high fives from the left I might add - except the ALP themselves who wanted Abbott to stay PM to help get their lame duck leader over the line.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Won't happen - a strong win by Turnbull will all but see the end of Tony Abbott in the parliament thus snuffing out Labor's hopes of an Abbott return IMO.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Turnbull is banking on a strong win at the election to consolidate his authority, silence agitators in his own party and give himself a mandate to progress reform along the lines of his stated vision for Australia.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Yes, that includes same sex marriage, yes that includes transition to renewables, yes that includes resolving the current impasse over Manus and Nauru ( and shutting them down) and yes that includes fiscal reform to head off the guaranteed global economic turndowns ahead.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Your biggest problem is that Shorten is 'famous' for being one of the Labor Party's faceless men who on his way to the leadership role not only stabbed two sitting Labor PM's in the process but was also 'inserted' into the role ahead of the man the majority of the party wanted, Albo.
author: TimOfAltona

text: People don't forget this and is largely viewed as a union apparatchik parachuted into the role who has since been grilled at a Royal Commission into Trade Union thuggery and also has had his personal past very publicly raked over.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I maintain for these reasons he is all but unelectable and his polling reflects that fact. I seriously doubt anyone listens to him anymore - you only need looks at some of the First Dog on The Moon cartoons to gauge what people are really thinking about him and it isn't great.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Here's the thing - you and pretty much everyone else in this thread have already passed judgement on government policies before they have even been released and irrespective of the merits will wholeheartedly condemn them.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Was not suggesting she did. Lenore has been critical of the government and of Turnbull's apparent inaction for some time now. This column is her summation of where she believes the state of play is now based on Lenore being close to the action.
author: TimOfAltona

text: In he meantime labor can focus on their own party reform, fix up their leadership conundrum and fashion themselves into a viable alternative government for the 2019 or 2022 election IMO.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You only see and hear what you want to because it suits your political agenda yet there is a whole other world out there with a very different point of view, some call it main stream Australia.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Since then we have seen next to nothing occur. My theory is Shorten 'shelved' party reform when he believed Abbott was going to hand him the prime ministership - all he had to do was 'be there' for the election and nature would take it's course.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Now with Turnbull's arrival he's been caught short, no pun intended, and doing his darnedest to try and build a negative story around the man most Australians want to see as PM.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Shorten sat back thinking an unpopular Abbott would be his keys to The Lodge and now he has the man more Australians want to see as PM than any other politician to contend with.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Lenore is correct, not an ideal start by the PM on tax matters following Labor going (bravely) early on negative gearing. Parkinson can add some depth and expert knowledge to advise the PM and re-set the trajectory prior to the election.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Unless there is better representation of people from diverse cultural and ethnic backgrounds in the union movement, there is no chance of Labor improving their stocks in this area.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Can't see too many on here complaining the seeds for Dick Smith's demise happened long before the current government came to power - they started during the 6 years of Labor government.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Looks and sounds like the same faceless man who back stabbed two sitting Labor PM's to get into this role, settling into his scare campaign groove surrounded by the usual Labor head nodders.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Labor are incredibly sensitive to voters perceptions that they are soft when it comes to national security and border security - hence there was bi-partisan support for Abbott's Stop the Boats policy.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The Guardian's exposure, in Australia at least, lies in it allowing it's political content and CIF to be hijacked by the often extreme Labor/Greens left wing mob who by and large do not represent the views of mainstream Australians.
author: TimOfAltona

text: In the UK and US editions I see the political commentary and CIF participation is more balanced in nature with better representation of views and contributions from both the left and right. Not so in Australia where it risks being seen nothing more than a left wing mouthpiece along with the associated irrelevancy.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Who can forget Bill camping out in supermarket aisles for days waiving around wet lettuce leaves and announcing the sky was falling because this 'evil' government included GST in a tax reform review.
author: TimOfAltona

text: He just fell short of proclaiming Armageddon was about to hit but ultimately made a complete fool of himself in the media who saw through his GST scare tactics and reported as such.
author: TimOfAltona

text: He had a great win in that last question. Made Labor look stupid after that interjection from Dreyfus. Notice how the entire Labor front bench stared down at the floor it was so embarrassing for them.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Party Reform. CROSSReliance on The Greens to win an election. CROSSIdentifying a future direction for the ALP. CROSSClearly articulating Labor values. CROSReducing toxic Union control over the ALP. CROSSCopying successful LNP Stop the Boats policies TICKCopying data retention policies TICK
author: TimOfAltona

text: Remember, for every opinion there is an opposing opinion. Your's is not necessarily the correct one. Expecting the Guardian to push your views whilst disregarding the popular centre and right of centre is delusional.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Just having a bit of fun with the teal ties. Main point was that part of the reason Labor's vote has collapsed is due to Shorten's penchant for copying government policy on contentious issues such as border protection/refugees and data retention. It's all political opportunism and not core Labor values.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I've heard they are useful for keeping merchant shipping lanes secure, but since the end of WWII have not seen much evidence of Australia's shipping lanes under threat from enemy subs?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Can't see why Australia needs 12 submarines. What useful and practical purpose do the billions they cost to manufacture and operate deliver for the country? The existing 6 sit dormant at docks a lot of the time because the navy can't attract enough submariners to crew them (a very different skill/training set from crewing surface vessels) so crewing 12 sounds like a lost cause.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Labelling people 'morons' who exercise their democratic rights and hold an opinion contrary to your own is not the best way to get your Labor party in to government. In fact it reflects on the Labor party overall and is not a good look in an election year IMO.
author: TimOfAltona

text: We are all familiar with Bingle Bill's penchant for copying government policies in keys areas, but today is bizarre. Sending out his spies to check on what tie the PM is wearing so he can emulate is taking the me-tooism a little too far.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Perhaps you are confused on the difference between new properties and existing properties. Under Labor's proposal the demand and therefore cost of the former goes up and the market valuation of the latter goes down. Fairly simple economics.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The defence white paper will be interesting. Labor's quandary is they have to find a way to attack it without being seen to be soft on the nations defence. It's no secret our defence forces do not receive the same level of funding when Labor governments are in power, in fact they tend to slash defence spending , so it will be interesting to see how Labor play this one.
author: TimOfAltona

text: O'Dwyer was spot on. Under Labor's rushed negative gearing policy new property pricing will increase due to higher demand, whilst existing home owners will see a reduction in their property value.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Perhaps the Turnbull hyperbole was a little too strong but when you consider Shorten's efforts with waiving wet lettuce leaves and scaring young children around supermarket aisles over the GST faux scare mongering I don't think Turnbull's effort in QT today was anywhere close.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Why does one get the impression that had the Turnbull government proposed Labor's negative gearing changes Shorten would be on his ideology soapbox accusing the government of bashing mum and dad investors and trashing house prices?
author: TimOfAltona

text: He has one shot at becoming PM and he knows he's the least preferred of all the political leaders (hell even Abbott had a higher popularity rating than Bingle) so it's do or die time for him.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Don't discount Labor doing another Hawke at the last moment - or perhaps a better comparison is doing another Rudd - Albo coming in to save some Labor furniture at the election.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Your best hope is once Shorten 'stands aside for the good of the party', most likely immediately following the next election, Albo will come in and take up the reigns to try and make Labor competitive in 2019.
author: TimOfAltona

text: How much time have you donated to go down to the Wayside Chapel and help out the homeless and destitute? I don't mean once or twice, I mean on a regular basis for the past 20 years or so. If you don't know what it's like to do that, ask the PM.
author: TimOfAltona

text: If you ever want to see the PM in person, head on down to the Wayside in Darlinghurst this Christmas Day, you'll see Malcolm and Lucy setting up tables, serving up food and chatting to people struggling with life as a result of domestic violence, drug or alcohol addiction, mental illness and the like.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Weak attempts such as yours to portray Turnbull as some kind of wealthy elitist individual falls flat on its face time and time again. Even your beloved ALP tried hat fake tactic and ran away from it very quickly. Suggest you follow suit.

text: Right now it looks like they are for it when it shows Labor improving, just like yesterday, and they are against it any time it shows the government improving, like today.

text: Nothing to do with race or class. The allegation is that a 'band of kidnappers' attacked him. Kidnapping foreigners is unheard of in Vietnam and even if a 'band of kidnappers ' did exist, with thousands of foreign tourists milling around the streets of Saigon day and night there are significantly easier targets than this bloke.

text: Whether they formally adopted her or not is not the point of the story. It was their totally selfless act of human kindness and compassion towards an unidentified dead and abandoned baby girl that is the point. They 'adopted' her to give her a respectful and dignified funeral.

text: You only have to look at the individual story around each of the recent Labor MP bailouts to see that barefaced factionalism is rife within the ALP and look no further than the Labor make up in the senate to see it is nothing more than a factional 'reward' gig for worn out union hacks towing the party line and sucking off the public teat before retirement.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Right here is one of the key reasons the ALP are struggling for relevance and struggling in the polls, they promised party reform following the nightmare of the Rudd/Gillard/Rudd period which resulted in the ALP becoming a rump of their former self in the lower house, yet they go ahead and place a key factional 'faceless man' player in as their leader against the overwhelming wishes of their membership to insert Albo.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Labor will never get ahead and never feel the warmth of the green leather seats on the government side of the house again until they ditch Shorten and implement much needed party reform which reduces the power of the Union factions over the party and also come up with a way to win government without having to rely on deals with the Greens to get them over the line. Both are electorally toxic.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Whilst the lefties keep labelling the processing centres thus they get little or no sympathy from mainstream Australia and will always remain on the fringes of the debate. They are not concentration camps in the sense you erroneously claim them to be. Get real.

text: As an activist for this issue, why don't you come up with a  plan that both prevents people smuggler boats starting up again thus preventing people perishing at sea whilst increasing Australia's intake of genuine refugees?

text: The weakness in your argument is that Labor have done nothing to earn back the trust of voters. They promised party reform and nothing has happened. Their leader is about the most unpopular politician in the country and Labor MP's have been bailing out left right and centre over the past couple of weeks. Not a good look for a party hoping to present as a viable alternative government.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The LNP have a massive seat majority in the lower house, I doubt even the most ardent Labor supporters such as yourself realistically believe Labor can overtake the government in an election any time soon, particularly with a leader who hovers around 14% in the preferred PM stakes vs 65% odd for Turnbull.
author: TimOfAltona

text: It's clear Shorten and the ALP are in a weak position currently and I don't think the LNP will have too much trouble getting comfortably over the line if an election were held soon.

text: Australia's contribution to 'plasticising' the oceans and waterways is miniscule compared to other parts of the world. Australia as a developed nation is not a contributor to large scale plastic pollution in the ocean.

text: Go and look at the coastal areas and waterways in many Asian countries and that is where the global problem lies. Australia legislating locally against microbeads, whilst a nice thing to do, means diddly squat.

text: Answer the question Daisy. Nice piece of avoidance there.The people getting into people smuggler boats in Turkey trying to get to Greece are not the ones heading to Australia. They are trying to reach Germany. Although that avenue seems a little difficult now. I drove through one of the Austrian/Germany border crossings early last week and the German police had road blocks up were stopping and searching any vehicle that could be carrying migrants - not sure what they were doing with any migrants they located but it looks like Germany has toughened up on it's original 'all comers welcome' position.

text: It really shits me the way the left just whitewash that from the history books and pretend it never happened and think it will never happen again if the borders are opened.

text: If Stuart Robert has deliberately breached ministerial standards then he should face the consequences of that decision just as any other minister, Labor or Liberal, have in the past.

text: Here's the thing - you see Turnbull never said he was increasing the GST, that was Labor Party contention which formed part of their scare tactics to try and give Shorten some much needed traction - quickly adopted by Labor supporter supporters such as yourself. Politics 101.

text: Labor's problem was in the execution - Bingle Bill waiving around lettuce leafs in highly staged supermarket visits meant it was doomed from the start and just like their hapless Cayman Island tactic it fell flat on it's face before it had hardly begun.

text: Labor and their supporters desperately need you to talk up a GST increase so it fits in with their scare campaign narrative, otherwise they have nothing left to bitch and moan about.

text: Unlikely SSM is the catalyst for a change of government, as much as you want it to be. There are bigger issues to address. Part of your problem is you still have an unelectable ALP Leader floating around.

text: Suggest the entire Labor cheer squad check out what a Plebiscite is and the obligations a government has to act on the outcome. They may not like it, but it is what it is.
author: TimOfAltona

text: He's not personally polling his electorate. The Plebiscite is held under the auspices of the AEC and votes are counted along electoral roll lines, meaning Hastie can see whether his own electorate supports it or not.
author: TimOfAltona

text: What your entire diatribe omits is that these 3 prominent issues, climate change, same-sex marriage and Republic are front and centre in the Turnbull administration,they are not going away like they did in the Abbott/Rudd/Gillard/Rudd administrations (climate change excepted). These things won't change overnight but as far as I see the groundwork is being put in place to enact change.
author: TimOfAltona

text: What a load of rubbish. All I hear around the place is that Labor under Shorten are washed up and Turnbull is the preferred PM...you must surely hear that too or do you block your eyes and ears when that regularly comes up?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Feel free to look it up, but you will see that it it is an advisory poll to the government. The government is not automatically required to enact the outcome. It still goes through the same process as a bill in the lower and upper house.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The big difference now is that ALP and LNP MP's can vote to their conscience or in Andrew Hasties case he thinks the wishes of his electorate come first, which is fair enough.
author: TimOfAltona

text: There is huge difference here - previously the LNP were bound by the party line on this issue as were the ALP. Providing the national plebiscite is in the affirmative, MPs can all vote according to their conscience or if they choose, what their constituents want (they are after all only in parliament because their constituents placed them there to represent them). Providing enough Labor and LNP MP's vote in the affirmative it will go to the senate where the same rules apply.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Allow these processes to take their course - a Plebiscite is the first step to legalising same sex marriage, providing it gets up and the majority of MP's vote in the affirmative with their own conscience or constituent wishes vote
author: TimOfAltona

text: That is too risky for this motion - with Labor seemingly about to lose and with bugger all Labor seats in the lower house, it will always be up to a Coalition government to sort this out.
author: TimOfAltona

text: A plebiscite by definition is a vote by citizens on an important issue but the outcome is advisory only and does not compel a government to act on the outcome.
author: TimOfAltona

text: If the outcome of a national plebiscite for legalising same sex marriage is in the negative, then the matter is unlikely to go to a vote in parliament, for now at least.
author: TimOfAltona

text: If the outcome of the plebiscite is in the affirmative, the parliament will have a vote. The LNP will need to allow a conscience vote, as will Labor, which is not something that has been permitted before on this issue.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Providing Australians vote in the affirmative in the plebiscite you then need to go back to the individual views held by MPs in both houses , and given the high LNP numbers in the lower house particularly, you need to hope that more Liberal MPs support the bill if it is to have any chance of success.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Labor agitators in this thread are correct about one thing....Turnbull metaphorically speaking still has his Prime Ministerial training wheels on and yes because he's new has to tread carefully around a few issues at odds with the small and potentially dangerous Abbott clique in his government.
author: TimOfAltona

text: In my opinion that will dissipate in the event he has a strong victory in the election this year. A strong win is needed to silence any internal critics Turnbull may have.
author: TimOfAltona

text: He will have considerably more authority to implement reform within his party and take the next LNP government on that road to the popular centre, possibly even occupy the ground Shorten and Labor vacated in their haste to copy the Abbott government way off to the right.
author: TimOfAltona

text: This will be a thrilling couple of years in Australian politics and you can't help get the feeling Turnbull presents as a moderate long term PM taking the whole country with him. The polls so far indicate that is the case.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Labor have no alternative but to initiate full and thorough reform and rebuild to try and win back a heartland that is rapidly abandoning them for the Greens, the Libs or Independents. Can't see any of that happening until after the next election, if the various factions allow that to happen at all.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The Labor cheer squad should be backing Turnbull on this one..he knows what he's doing and he is absolutely correct...this is a decision for the people, not a political party.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I distinctly recall Labor being in power in this nation for 6 years recently and not a single thing was done about a Republic....so the cheer squad need to cut Malcolm a little slack here as your party did zip.
author: TimOfAltona

text: He speaks from good experience having lived and breathed the last referendum in 1999...this is all about the timing and the current popular opinion being once the current Queen has either stepped down or has passed away.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I support a Republic and I'm excited at the prospect of Turnbull going into the history books in a few years time as the PM who transitioned Australia into a Republic.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Shorten - not so much. The problem there is you have to actually win an election first and that is where it all goes pear shaped for Shorten and Labor.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I'm with you. I vote we all just live miserable lives and hating who we are and what we stand for as a nation. No one in this country deserves recognition for anything so let's get rid of Australian of the Year awards completely.
