text: Did you Lynlylo? Just the same as Rosie Batty and Adam Goodes the year before that. Highly militarised Australians of the Year appointments those two. Not sure what your point is.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Explain to us again how Rosie Batty is an example of a Liberal government (under Tony Abbott to boot) using Australian of the Year to show off the military??
author: TimOfAltona

text: Right here is why Labor will remain out of government in this country for years to come. Absolutely no acknowledgement that they were the authors of their own demise in 2013. Blaming the media for Labor's civil war is delusional.
author: TimOfAltona

text: It's not like successive Liberal and Labor government's have not poured billions of dollars over the past few decades into Indigenous health, welfare, education, housing and employment in part as a reflection of the wrongs that were inflicted on many by some during the 19th and early 20th centuries.
author: TimOfAltona

text: First it was lettuce leaves in a supermarket stunt that fell flat on its face the same day and now the ALP focus group squad reckon this Republican thing will resonate with voters.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Immigration and Border Protection Minister after the next election should keep all parties happy - except the ALP who were shown to be wanting and hopelessly outclassed when it came to border protection during the failed Rudd/Gillard/Rudd years.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Is this the same Michael Moore who lobbied for the legalisation of cannabis, which some experts say is 20 times more likely to give you lung cancer than tobacco?
author: TimOfAltona

text: If I were a Labor/Greens supporter I wouldn't be focussing all my energy on Tony Abbott in the hope he may be able to save Labor from the looming defeat at the polls - I'd be more interested in how to transform the Labor Party into a viable alternative government - starting with sorting out a deeply unpopular and inept leader who has about as much charisma as those wet lettuce leaves he was waving around in a supermarket the other day.
author: TimOfAltona

text: General consensus is it's the one area he succeeded in. He sorted out the almighty mess Labor left behind after they totally lost control of Australia's borders by allowing the people smugglers to dictate Australia's immigration arrivals.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I doubt the 'rest of the world' even know who Rudd or Abbott are...if anything Rudd may be identified as the PM who kick started the Indonesian maritime people smuggler industry with tens of thousands of people incarcerated and 1000+ deaths at sea and Abbott may be identified as the Australian PM who stopped all that happening - apart from that they would be relatively unknown.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Don't want to be the bearer of bad news for anyone excited at the prospect of Rudd having a tilt but I think you'll find ex NZ Labour PM Helen Clark is streets ahead of him or any other contender.
author: TimOfAltona

text: As chair of the UN Development Group she is currently ranked number 3 in UN seniority after Ban Ki Moon and Jan Eliasson and sits within the top 20 most powerful women in the world.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I have locked away some gems from the past few days ready to roll them out after the election result. So much nonsense has been sprouted recently (usually after another poll showing Shorten & Labor are all but finished) it's difficult to differentiate between what is genuinely held beliefs and just outright leftist propaganda.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Exactly what happened in NZ and then the current PM John Key went to an election with a 15% and cruised home to victory against the NZ Labour Party.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Good luck trying to keep that one alive. The only ones who want to talk about that are the Labor Cheer Squad clinging onto something, anything that gives them hope.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Before you jump the gun with your assumptions on the GST (don't listen to Shortens confected scare campaign) wait and see how the GST and compensation is sliced and diced., You never know you may be pleasantly surprised and join all your mates and vote LNP!!
author: TimOfAltona

text: It'll be interesting to see if the Labor tactics squad in their desperation try and resort to this message as the election gets closer - a vote for Turnbull is a vote for Abbott. Nothing like a good old Labor confected scare campaign.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Even the ALP strategists can see that they have little prospect of a win next election if Turnbull remains leader of the Libs. If they can see it so can the rest of Australia.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Looks like they are stuck with him until the next election, after which he will stand aside 'for the good of the party'. The BIG question is who will they find to replace him?
author: TimOfAltona

text: The good old media conspiracy theories abound when Labor are seemingly on the ropes. Ever considered there may be other reasons why the polling is what it is - like Shorten is genuinely not liked or trusted by the majority of voters?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Shorten &Labor back the government's offshore processing policy - in fact it was the ALP who opened these places and sent thousands of men women and children to them. So I suspect your comment about a different polling outcome is not necessarily correct.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Labor's current dilemma stems from the fact that they have never recovered from the Rudd/Gillard civil wars. Reform was promised but next to nothing has happened - voters can see that.
author: TimOfAltona

text: In addition the factions inserted a bloke who many say was the architect of the aforementioned civil wars and he carries so much negative baggage from all that no one likes him or trusts him - voters can see that
author: TimOfAltona

text: In addition Labor are influenced too much by the unions and their power brokers and not only are unions not particularly held in high regard given all the dramas surrounding them in recent years, they only represent a tiny portion of the Australian workforce - voters can see that
author: TimOfAltona

text: In addition Labor have not resolved their association/affiliation with the Greens. This is a negative. People clearly recall Bob Brown and Julia Gillard fawning over each other in their new found love in which everyone interpreted as Bob Brown installing himself as the defacto Deputy PM. The Greens are seen as a party of activists by mainstream Australia and Labor need to think seriously about standing on their own two feet to win an election instead of cuddling up to the Greens on preferences - Voters can see that.
author: TimOfAltona

text: In addition, people don't know what Labor stand for anymore. They have abandoned their traditional turf and under Shorten have moved over to the grass traditionally occupied by a moderate Liberal Party. Their biggest threat now is that Turnbull brings his party back to that turf and they have no where to go. They are caught in no mans land and irrelevancy- voters can see that.
author: TimOfAltona

text: My interest is in who will replace Bill when he stands down. I reckon very discreet jockeying in the factions has already begun and there will be an almighty shit fight between the left and right. It's fascinating stuff.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Personally my gut feel is they will opt for the favourite Albo believing he is the only one who can take the fight up to a Turnbull lead government, but in reality can you REALLY see Albo as PM material? Huge question marks over that.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The image at the top of this story pretty much confirms what everyone suspected or knew for a very long time - Bill Shorten, a faceless man of the Labor Party!
author: TimOfAltona

text: Not for me to defend the Guardian but in fairness it's true to say they are pretty quick off the mark when the government stuff up or a minister makes a controversial comment etc. I think it's referred to as 'Holding them to account'
author: TimOfAltona

text: Keep that up sunshine, burying your head in the sand and pretending all is rosy down at team Labor is called delusion and is sure to keep them out of government for a very long time.
author: TimOfAltona

text: It is the extent of that win that will determine Turnbull's ultimate authority and therefore mandate to continue his push to return the Libs back towards the popular centre.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I want to hear from Finnigans - we need our daily dose of "It's all over for this Turnbull/LNP/News Ltd government" and "Shorten and Labor will win in a landslide victory" and my personal favourite from Chippendale - "Australian's are queuing up in their millions with baseball bats to rid this country of Malcolm Turnbull and his government".
author: TimOfAltona

text: If parents with children are afforded passage to Australia then the people smugglers have a business model they can work with and the boats laden with families will start departing Indonesia once more with the hope/expectation the children are the passport to bypass the UNHCR queues and get into Australia by boat.
author: TimOfAltona

text: This is a good thing. Having said that the sooner the facilities are closed down permanently on Nauru the better. The Howard administration achieved that before the Labor government got them up and running again when they lost control of the borders after Rudd gave the people smugglers their business model back.
author: TimOfAltona

text: As far as you can see, the current government are working to reducing the number of children in immigration detention with a fair bit of success thus far and eventually the centres will be shut down - for good.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The only people touting him as next PM are the Labor/Greens cheer squad desperately hoping someone, anyone can replace Turnbull so Labor have some chance of contesting the next election.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Multiple contractor reports stating that there was cause to suspect that STC staff were engaging in 'coaching' asylum seekers to protest self harm were making their way to the minister's office. Morrison rightly called for, amongst other things, an independent inquiry to confirm the voracity of the claims. In the meantime the contractors deemed the STC staff were a risk to the good management of the facility with a recommendation they be removed whilst the inquiry and report were under way.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Morrison has not been Immigration Minister for some time now and it's up to the current minister to respond if he chooses - this falls squarely in his area of responsibility.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Doesn't work that way. There are greater welfare benefits in the UK plus low paid cash work is easier to secure than in France. As far as I can see these are mostly economic migrants trying to enter the UK illegally.
author: TimOfAltona

text: This is almost a non-story - there are thousands of muggings perpetrated around the world each day. It could be in Rome, it could be in Manhattan, it could be in Birmingham, Mumbai or Sydney. The fact this occurred in Calais and happened to be in a migrant camp is fairly non-remarkable IMO.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Possibly a slow news day, but I agree with you. Condolences to the fellow who lost his partner, but this particular story can only be hammered to death so many times.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You have a problem right there. Half or more of the people on here are hoping and praying for his return as they know Turnbull is just too strong for Labor to have any hope of winning anything under Bingle Bill.
author: TimOfAltona

text: If the Labor hecklers on here don't like Tim Wilson because they suspect he is from the 'right', then surely all is good down at the HRC, what with Gillian Triggs strongly suspected to be from the 'left' and seemingly enjoying the full approval of the cheer squad (Australian of the Year I hear them cry).
author: TimOfAltona

text: David, I think it safe to bet my house on the fact that you agree with Tim Wilson's comments as well. Be a little bit weird if you didn't.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Given that Morrison was not actually living and working in Nauru himself to witness what was occurring, it's a fair bet he was relying on reports from others on the ground. It's not the first time a Minister has been provided erroneous information and in this case it came from multiple sources.
author: TimOfAltona

text: That said, yes I agree with Wilson that an apology and even compensation is in order if any of those sacked workers suffered financial penalties. They may well still be employed by STC and assigned to other duties.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Can't wait for Paul Bastian and Dave Smith from the AMWU to come out and applaud Pyne's efforts and how they will work with the minister to bring about the best outcome for their members.
author: TimOfAltona

text: People seem a little, no very, upset at the prospect of a big win for the government - I mean a really big win not only for Elizabeth and SA but also Australia.
author: TimOfAltona

text: If Pyne can reverse Holden's decision to exit Australian manufacturing, not by propping them up with tax payers money but by involving an interested and proven 3rd party investor and allocating budgeted funds from the existing ATS.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The unions should be backing the Turnbull government to the hilt on this one and I suspect they will be. We await their endorsement of this proposal, c'mon Bill you can do it!
author: TimOfAltona

text: The reality is that your bloke will never be warming that chair in the Oval Office, so instead of trying to drum up manufactured stuff against Turnbull, best to sort out what you're going to do about Bingle Bill and his quest to lead Labor over the electoral cliff next federal election day IMO.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Let's hope the incumbent is here for the long haul - indications are he will be, but who knows, Labor may change their leader and anything could happen. Unlikely to though the way things are going.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Fair to say Lenore that the Kevin Andrews comment has been dealt with and is done and dusted...it's now old news...not sure why you keep rehashing it when reporting on Turnbull's visit to Washington. It's not like the Americans were offended that Turnbull politely told them to go away with their request for more Australian combat troops on the ground, if anything Turnbull came out of that with his head held high and credibility in tact with both Australians and the US.
author: TimOfAltona

text: As far as I can see, Turkey was their first safe haven country. Some of these people have been living and working there for years in some cases. Turkey is a 1962 signatory to the 1951 Convention relating to the Status and protection of refugees.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Instead of inviting them all to come to Germany, Merkel would have been better to pour millions of aid euros into Turkey to assist with the refugee camps by building infrastructure like schools, hospitals and the like to care for the refugees without them trying to make the dangerous boat trip to Greece and then trekking halfway across Europe to reach Germany.
author: TimOfAltona

text: They would have been better to remain in their own part of the world which would also make the return to their homeland, mainly Syria, considerably easier when it is eventually safe to do so. Too simplistic? Perhaps, but I think preferable to the massive shit fight that's going to occur in Germany and other parts of Europe in the coming years and decades.
author: TimOfAltona

text: As far as I can see, Turkey was their first safe haven country. Many of these people have been living and working there for years in some cases. Turkey is a 1962 signatory to the 1951 Convention relating to the Status and protection of refugees.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Instead of inviting them all to come to Germany, Merkel would have been better to pour millions of aid euros into Turkey to assist with the refugee camps and the well being of the refugees without them trying to make the dangerous boat trip to Greece and then trekking halfway across Europe to reach Germany. They would have been better to remain in their own part of the world which would also make the return to their homeland, mainly Syria, considerably easier when it is safe to do so. Too simplistic? Perhaps, but I think preferable to the shit fight that's going to occur in Germany and other parts of Europe in coming years/decades.
author: TimOfAltona

text: If that's the best the Labor cheer squad can come up with in trying to manufacture some kind of anti-Turnbull sentiment whilst their own leader is not only on the ropes but pretty much down for the count, I suggest you try another tactic, cause that one is inane and childish and fools no one IMO.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Turnbull used the speech to the Centre for Strategic and International Studies to warn leaders against unwittingly aiding Isis, by blaming Islam or all Muslims for the groups actions or accepting Isiss own overblown rhetoric about its power and achievements.
author: TimOfAltona

text: That is pure Labor propaganda. The ALP did plenty more damage to the NBN roll out through mismanagement of NBN Co and massive cost blowouts than the current government have done in trying to clean up the mess.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You only had to look at Albos desperate attempts to hide the critical NBN progress report from voters in the lead up to the 2013 election to know things were being mismanaged.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I'm with you on part of your comment - I heard the same when Abbott was around and no question the government were up against it, but I hear the opposite now Turnbull occupies the big chair. Majority of voters (Labor cheer squad excluded) want to give Malcolm clear air to prosecute his case and bring in the reform the country desperately needs so another term or two in government is on the cards.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Your biggest problem is not Turnbull, it's the fact that your bloke Shorten will never occupy the big chair. Until Labor find their own Malcolm Turnbull the ALP will remain on the sidelines in the Lower House never able to form a government, even with the assistance of the Greens IMHO.
author: TimOfAltona

text: There was an interesting piece the other day, also in Fairfax, how Obama and Turnbull have immediately struck a close rapport and Obama was keen to invite him to Washington for further discussions. Interesting because they hail from opposing political camps but Obama it seems is of the opinion they share common values , objectives and road maps to achieving those objectives.
author: TimOfAltona

text: This is a extremely positive start for Turnbull on the world stage and is good for Australia IMO. The media reports out of Washington on Turnbull's first visit will make compelling reading for those interested in politics.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The far left lost this argument a long long time ago - hence we have the government we have and will have for a very long time whilst the left keep banging on about permitting people arriving by illegal people smuggler boats into Australia.
author: TimOfAltona

text: It's been tried before under Rudd and what a monumental mess it caused - thousands drowning in the ocean because Rudd, to quote the Indonesian President at the time, "Put the sugar out on the table".
author: TimOfAltona

text: It would be a shame to see Bolt Report gone. Yes it was generally a plug for the Liberal Party and often took a swipe at Labor's shortcomings, but it also had interviews with Labor Party figures to give them the opportunity to showcase the argument for the ALP position.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I do miss Sarah Hanson Young standing in a park pontificating how evil the Australian government are for turning away the hundreds of thousands of people trying to reach our shores by leaky boats and having the audacity to shut down the people smugglers business model which facilitated the uncontrolled mass migration of people wanting to claim asylum in Australia with not a mention of the 1000+ people who drown along the way.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Perhaps after the Merkel experiment in Germany which is ongoing and the resultant looming social, cultural, fiscal and political upheaval, the Australian Greens too get the sense that opening up borders to allow the uncontrolled mass migration of millions of people is not the most popular 'policy du jour' right now.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Antony's piece is missing a vital and humanitarian ingredient - acknowledgement that Abbott's policies, continued by the Turnbull administration and adopted by Labor, have prevented countless drownings in the ocean, perhaps thousands of lives saved.
author: TimOfAltona

text: No one can argue that is not a worthwhile outcome yet the Greens and the far left of Labor always seem to look the other way when these boats sink and people drown like they pretend it does not happen.
author: TimOfAltona

text: It happens because their policy of welcoming anyone and everyone who can reach Australia by any means possible to claim asylum ensures the maritime people smuggler industry thrives and people drown as a result.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Good to see a senior Labor leader publicly contradict Shorten over GST by supporting Morrison and the government's line that nothing should be off the table when it comes to tax reform and state funding.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Shorten and his election strategy team were banking on GST being their 'hill to die on' in this year's election but now thanks to Weatherill it seems Shorten may die on that 'hill' before the election campaign even starts.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Good to see a senior Labor leader publicly contradict Shorten over GST by supporting Morrison and the government's line that nothing should be off the table when it comes to tax reform and state funding.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Shorten and his election strategy team were banking on GST being their 'hill to die on' in this year's election but now it seems Shorten may die on that hill before the election campaign even starts.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Luke Foley in NSW was recently rebuked and then silenced by Shorten for suggesting a GST increase, providing it was fair, should be one of several options available to assist states with funding shortfalls, thus echoing the government's position.
author: TimOfAltona

text: This is a good move. Those lucky enough to have travelled in or visited Iran know it's people and Persian culture to be amongst the most welcoming and hospitable in the Middle East.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Let's hope inbound tourism increases as a result of sanction lifting. The stronger the ties with the west the better the prosperity and stability for the country and the region. Trade and tourism will lead the way.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Stephen, ever harboured thoughts of running for the Labor Party in a federal election? I'm sure they could find you a nice safe seat to ensure you get into the Lower House and from there the sky's the limit for you.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Seriously, the ALP need fresh talent to take them forward from the current malaise and given the unions are on the nose lately the fact you are not an ex-Union hack like most of them is a definite plus.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Easy to see why he has your lot worried. Shorten on the ropes with little prospect of a recovery any time soon. Labor should not have just sat back expecting Abbott to hand over the keys to The Lodge - Turnbull has caught the ALP flat-footed and they will pay the ultimate price - a very long stint on the opposition benches.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Even the rabid Labor supporters have to admit that the country feels significantly happier with Malcolm Turnbull representing us overseas than his predecessor. Abbott had his strengths, but also weaknesses and Turnbull is breath of fresh air.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The next round of polls will be interesting. If the Labor vote continues to collapse the ALP should really bite the bullet, take the pain for certain gain and insert Albo - he is really the only hope Labor have of being anywhere near competitive at the next federal election IMO.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Your comment makes no sense at all. The polls ALL indicate the Turnbull government will returned easily and support for Shorten and Labor is tanking faster than you can belt out a couple of verses of 'Solidarity Forever'
author: TimOfAltona

text: They are there, along with the Kiwi's, to train Iraqi armed forces. They are not in front line or combat roles. This is a worthwhile contribution which both keeps our boys and girls in a relatively low risk environment whilst providing expert training support for Iraq to rid the country of IS. Everyone wins.
author: TimOfAltona

text: IS are not stupid and know that, apart from hollow rhetoric, any direct attacks on Israel or its citizens will unleash the powerful Israeli war machine and that is not something they could cope with.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Your'e entitled to your unusual view on things, but most of us remember Gillard gushing like a giggling schoolgirl next to Obama and then getting stage fright and mixing up her words. I remember the press and the comments about it at the time.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The reality is Turnbull and Obama have already hit it off very well and Obama was keen to get Turnbull to the Whitehouse for discussions on how we move forward from here. Very interesting piece in Fairfax the lother day about the warm affinity between the two and common values shared despite being in separate political camps. This is a good thing for Australia in the years ahead despite Obama stepping down soon and Turnbull only starting out as a long term PM for Australia.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You guys need to get out more. Purely relying on the Guardian as your news source means you are missing out on what's happening in the real world.Turnbull's in Iraq.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Don't know about you, but I sense that the baseball bats will have Bills name on them, not Malcolms ,with many being carried by Labor supporters if he polls are anything to go by.
author: TimOfAltona

text: This is a fairly good and balanced synopsis of the budget situation and how it affects both the government and Labor..worth a quick read. No doubting this is a major challenge for Turnbull but you get the feeling the country want it to work out with him as PM, so he has that head start at least.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I think it is a fairly safe bet to say that those children in the header image did not write those slogans on their t shirts nor did they write the signs they are holding up nor did they stage manage the photograph on their own.
author: TimOfAltona

text: No one disputes the great work, goodwill and good intentions STC have in caring for and protecting children in need but when that support transitions into political activism problems will arise.
author: TimOfAltona

text: If their objective is to get these children and their parents/carers into Australia then they are playing right into the hands of the maritime people smugglers who share the exact same objective and no one can dispute the sheer human tragedy that ensues should the people smugglers start placing men, women and children onto leaky boats again.
author: TimOfAltona

text: It's due to the current government's strict border protection policies, with bi-partisan support from Labor, that we no longer see mass drownings and any hint whatsoever that those policies will be relaxed will see the deadly boats start up again - guaranteed.
author: TimOfAltona

text: We all want to see Nauru and Manus facilities closed, but the only way that can happen without initiating hundreds or thousands of more deaths at sea, is for the majority of asylum seekers who came by boat to relocate to countries other than Australia or NZ.
author: TimOfAltona

text: None of that however excuses the governments of Australia and Nauru from their duty of care when it comes to the well being and welfare of the people housed in the facilities which is where STC can do what they do best without resorting to activism and protest.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Both major political parties receive negative media coverage when they stuff up - Labor have had a particularly bad run in recent years because of the corrosive Rudd/Gillard/Rudd years tearing the party apart.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Interesting that the Labor woman involved painted a very different picture about a culture of misogyny in the Labor party that Penny Wong and Tania Plibersek would have us believe.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Luke Foley already has an approval rating of 15% or lower, around the same territory Shorten enjoys, his silence on this has almost certainly ensured NSW Labor another term in the wilderness.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You don't know what Briggs did Daisy, it's all speculation. Perhaps it does not warrant him being ejected from parliament. Thanks to Turnbull he's gone from the ministry and I'm sure the voters in his electorate will decide if they want him to remain as their MP at the next election.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Stop waffling - Turnbull asked for and received Brigg's resignation once the two investigations were complete and the findings handed down. It's called taking action.Not sure why I'm even responding to your childish nonsense accusations.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Careful on your accusations Dais, this matter has been swirling around NSW Labor internally for some time and with Shorten's knowledge...he was forced to make a statement by the media today because it's all come out in the open.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Complete silence from the ALP on this - presumably the tactic boffins will have been up all night preparing Bingle's response script for today - let's see what he comes out with.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Irony is, had Turnbull committed further Australian fighting assets following the US request, Bingle is likely to have come out in support for fear of being seen as weak on terrorism.
author: TimOfAltona

text: While Bill is swanning around the supermarket aisles tomorrow, media in tow, trying to locate a damp lettuce leaf to wave about and accuse Turnbull of buggering up our Australia Day salads with a 15% GST, hell it may have even gone up to 50% by tomorrow, I hope he pauses to reflect on Turnbull's decision re not increasing Australian combat troop numbers in Syria/Iraq.
author: TimOfAltona

text: It ultimately backfired on her and Labor, but Plibersek was very vocal at the time (remember the handbag hit squad label attributed to her, Roxon and Wong) trying to publicly prosecute the misogyny tactic.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Like Shorten, Plibersek carries way too much baggage from the disaster of the Rudd/Gillard/Rudd years. The Gillard 'experiment' nearly tore the Labor Party apart - I doubt the faceless men of either the left or the right will risk a repeat of that debacle.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Plus, like Shorten, she has personal skeletons in cupboards....her husband's convictions and imprisonment for drug dealing/trafficking may be a bridge too far for a person the ALP/unions hope to insert in The Lodge IMO.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You may be confused, Turnbull has been volunteering at the Wayside Chapel on Christmas Day to help out with Christmas lunch and talking with and listening to Sydney street people for many years.
author: TimOfAltona

text: If you are suggesting that he should stop that volunteering work because he is now PM and you don't want any positive images of him entering the public domain, then can I suggest you go down to the Wayside Chapel next Christmas to take his place in serving up food to the homeless so that his spot is covered.....you need to take someone with you because Lucy Turnbull does the same thing each Christmas Day as well, has done for years.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You were wishing and clamouring for Abbott to go and your wish came true courtesy of Turnbull, you want Tones back again because Labor are no match for a Turnbull led government.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Wishing for an early election will almost certainly backfire on you - but at least it will assist Labor to get rid of Shorten and look to the future under new leadership.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Seems to me all he is doing is talking it up - even before anything has been decided - clear and obvious scare tactics and the media have already picked him up on it.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Some say Shorten is further to the right than Turnbull - sounds a little weird given he is ALP Leader, but when you look back at his career, friends and acquaintances they could be right.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Funny you should say that, someone was suggesting the exact same thing the other day about Whitlam and the current day Shorten led Labor Party - they should bring Gough back to save the furniture.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You were saying exactly the same things about Abbott when he was PM, which means it's not the individual you detest, it's they represent the fact that Labor were tossed out of government in 2013 and will probably remain there for many years to come.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Given what Shorten did to your delectable Julia Gillard by terminating her political career in the greatest of Labor traditions - the proverbial knife in the back when she was still PM, I thought you would not be too pleased to see Shorten rewarded for that with the Prime Ministership in any case.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Don't put it past the Labor tactics squad to even put fake 'customers' in front of Shorten to ask him pre-prepared questions or make scripted favourable comments in front of the media about Labor.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Not only does that sum up beautifully the comments from 98% of the people posting in Guardian political threads but also Labor's failed attempt to play the man and not he ball when Turnbull arrived on the scene and all but destroyed any hope Shorten and the unions had of turning the key in the front door of The Lodge any time soon.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Interesting because highly decorated ex-military types cum political wannabes traditionally hoist their flag to the LNP flag pole and given Kelly's much publicised personal involvement and by his own admission, support for the judicial execution of a Somali warlord in Mogadishu, he does not exactly fit the standard Labor Party mould.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Interesting that whilst Abbott is generally not a great public speaker on his feet, he actually performed very well vs a far more eloquent Rudd in the 2013 debates. In fact I think from memory Abbott was given line honours by political commentators in one maybe two of them.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Not too sure you can point the finger of blame for the economic slowdown in China nor the share market rout in the US on the Liberal Party in Australia.

text: That said, I think we all know the constraints Turnbull, as communications minister was under at the time. text: My take on what I saw at Cronulla that day, I was there and witnessed perhaps some of the worst of it, it was more to do with too much booze being consumed on a hot day by a bunch of guys too young to know better.
author: TimOfAltona

text: There were a couple of older stirrers draped in Australian flags (clearly pissed) with megaphones geeing up the younger ones and most of the trouble makers were kids in their teens carried away by too much alcohol and the more they drank the louder it got as more and more joined in.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Yes, what they were doing was wrong - but what started as a kind of carnival type atmosphere in the morning soon developed into out of control mobs fuelled by alcohol, mainly made up of no more than high school kids walking around with 24 packs of stubbies under their arms and few older ones who should have known better.
author: TimOfAltona

text: There is no question in my mind that if it were not for the alcohol, the day would have ended up very differently and most of the younger ones, who made up the majority of the crowd, would never have participated and the subsequent alcohol fuelled rampaging violence directed at anyone with Middle Eastern appearance on the beach, the trains, the fast food restaurants or in the park would never have happened.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I personally don't view Q&A as having a particularly left wing leaning..although the review summarised correctly that the majority of overseas guests tend to be from the progressive side of politics.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I would like to see more shows with only 2 guests - a senior minister from the government with his/her shadow equivalent. We could get some really good meaty debate around policies happening and give both sides an opportunity to showcase their respective arguments...and yes, in fairness the Greens should probably get a look in on the panel too...if only to demonstrate not much separate the Greens and Labor.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Likewise Shorten should stop commenting on Abbott's comments. No doubt he thinks he's getting some kind of political mileage out of reminding people that Abbott used to be PM, but ultimately despite Abbott's shortcomings, his approval rating was always higher than Bill's.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I suspect The Guardian have achieved their objective - you only need to have the words 'Tony' and 'Abbott' in the headline, no matter how inane the story and the Labor/Greens cheer squad all flood into the thread to submit their usual anti-Abbott confected rhetoric.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Kristina, fair to say no matter what becomes of Brough, stay whether he stays, goes or nothing changes it at all makes zero difference to the final outcome of the next federal election.
author: TimOfAltona

text: We all know Labor are up against it at the next election and if they don't discard Shorten probably the one after that too..let's see Labor at least attempt to initiate the promised reform instead if pretending it is no longer needed - until they do they can expect to wither on the opposition benches for years to come.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Abbott could have turfed him out in 2013, given Washington is regarded as the second highest diplomatic posting after the UK and usually reserved for party apparatchiks, at least Abbott did the right thing by leaving Kim in Washington.
author: TimOfAltona

text: They are neither gulags or concentration camps - go back and look up the history books to see what happened in both those places - no resemblance whatsoever to either Manus or Nauru.
author: TimOfAltona

text: On Nauru for instance, no one is 'locked up' - everyone can come and go from the facility as much as they like and free to roam outside at their leisure.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Of course nobody wants to see people held on Manus or Nauru - the sooner they are emptied and closed down the better - just like back in the Howard Government days before Labor opened up the flood gates and reopened the offshore centres after losing control of our borders.
author: TimOfAltona

text: If FD can suggest a way we can release these people (who choose to stay in Manus or Nauru above relocating to another country on offer not Australia) without restarting the last Labor initiated debacle of tens of thousands attempting to reach Australia on hundreds of people smuggling boats accompanied by the inevitable tragic mass drownings along the way, then we are all ears.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I'm with you, we only want media outlets and publications to spread the word on how great life is under a Labor/Greens government - anything else is just toilet paper and should be dismissed as trash journalism.

text: I want to know what India is doing - far more relevant to the topic of global warming than anything Australia will ever need to do or indeed achieve in a hundred years.

text: A person no one wants as ALP leader let alone PM of this country (see latest FDOTM cartoon) and a party that promised reform and rebuild after the disaster of the Rudd/Gillard/Rudd years and nothing done about that.

text: In all seriousness little point in holding out for Shorten to reach the Lodge - never happen - so the LNP is all we've got for the foreseeable future, may as well work with Turnbull on this.

text: Give him time. He needs a strong win at the next election to consolidate his leadership and take the party back towards the highly popular middle and keep them in govt for years to come.

text: You need to go back and look at his history.....classic faceless man of the Labor party...destroying not one PM but two Labor PMs on his way to the top....plenty more too when you delve into his distant past.

text: Damn First Dog - saves his best cartoon of the year until I am ensconced in deepest darkest Southern India where the internet fails faster than an Australian Labor leaders popularity...that said brilliant piece and reinforces pretty much everything I have said since Sept 2013.
author: TimOfAltona

text: On another subject - being in India and seeing first hand the effects of coal burning, particularly in the acutely impoverished rural areas brings into question the whole issue of coal and it's detrimental effects on people's health and well being.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The problem is cost and renewables are just too expensive for the Indian government to invest heavily in, particularly rural areas where everything is coal powered because it is dirt cheap and accessible to everyone.
author: TimOfAltona

text: How much Australian coal I've seen burning in the villages of Southern India I have no idea, but one thing is clear, if Australia pulls supply, the Indians will certainly fill the gap with coal from other nations.
author: TimOfAltona

text: It looks more like a weak attempt by Labor to create mischief when they should be working out how they can reform and try and win back government in the next 2 or 3 terms.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Those crafty Labor tacticians and their Dreyfus mouthpiece - desperately searching for something, anything that will give the hapless Opposition some kind of vague hope of a short term tactical win over a highly popular government.

text: Can someone tell them that apart from their own cheer squad, no one gives a toss about Mal Brough and what he may or may not have done all that time ago. Won't change the outcome of the next federal election one iota.

text: Not sure what all the fuss is about - apart from Labor trying to stir the pot following Obama raising the issue about something that had been in the public domain for months - perhaps the ALP should subscribe to the NT News as well and not wait until Obama mentions it before they start their feigned scare tactics.

text: I don't think even Labor are suggesting this presents a threat to national security - more to do with trying to create mischief for the government off the back of Obamas comment at APEC.

text: It will be good to hear Katharine's summation of Turnbull's first outing on the big stage. She has been travelling with him for days and will have formed a good opinion on how he handled himself. By all accounts so far, Australia's rookie PM has gone pretty well given the sensitivities and turbulence swirling around some of the issues he has had to address on behalf of Australia.

text: Something tells me that had the Paris attacks occurred in say Melbourne or Sydney and the GM response was the same, it would be more than just the Telegraph having a go, I reckon even First Dog would emerge from his ideological bunker and have a crack such would be the collective grief and anger of the nation.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Compare the public statements from Australia's Grand Mufti and those of the French Muslim leader, the Rector of the Great Mosque of Paris regarding the Paris terror attacks and play spot the bleeding obvious difference.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Given this horrific event occurred not in Australia but on the other side of the planet, it gives First Dog and his followers a little leeway to play around the edges and launch into their old News Ltd nemesis who did nothing more than to call it for what it was - a piss poor response from a man who is supposed to be leader and spokesperson of the Australian Muslim community.

text: Lol... If he says that about the person the majority of Australians actually want as our PM...imagine what he would say about Bingle Bill...the man no one wants as our PM.

text: At any examination a great first outing for Turnbull on the world stage. Given he has only been PM for figuratively speaking 5 minutes this would have been a great learning curve for him.

text: On his return he needs to do some serious work on domestic policy framework. Presumably his ministers have been working on that during his absence. We've seen a few glimpses in recent days.

text: Their tacticians had them attempting for 2 or 3 days to play the man only to discover it had backfired spectacularly on them and achieved nothing more than to further boost Turnbull's popularity coupled with a rapid decrease in Shorten's approval rating. Labor dropped it like a hot potato and have avoided it ever since.

text: If only the factional warlords and union puppet masters would allow some of that talent into the front bench then it could be the beginning of a new era for Labor.

text: I think Katharine is right, it is not only world leaders who like what they see in Malcolm Turnbull, Australian voters are also impressed by what they see so far and the polls reflect precisely that.

text: Consider this - whilst Turnbull was rubbing shoulders and in meetings with Obama, Putin, Abe, Merkel , Cameron and others, Australia's 'alternative' PM was randomly smashing into parked cars in a Carlton street after, according to Labor spin merchants at least, spilling coffee in his lap. The same spin merchants proclaimed that this was 'reported' to police yet funny thing, Victoria police advised they have no record of that. Can Shorten become any more of a liability for Labor?

text: At the end of the day, we are all hoping to see an end to the revolving door of Australian PMs and unfortunately for the increasingly hapless and directionless Labor party, Turnbull is looking like just the person to deliver on that.

text: Whilst our PM is in high level talks with Obama, Cameron, Abe, Merkel, Putin et al, Australia's 'alternative' PM is smashing into parked cars in Carlton allegedly, according to ALP spin merchants, due to 'spilling hot coffee in his lap'.

text: She carries considerable baggage from the failed Gillard era plus her husband is a convicted former drug criminal - Australians are not ready to embrace that sort of heavy baggage IMO.

text: Whilst the PM is rubbing shoulders and in high level talks with Obama, Merkel, Cameron, Abe, Putin and others, our 'alternative' PM is driving around Carlton early Sunday morning smashing into parked cars due, according to ALP spin merchants, spilling hot coffee in his lap.

text: Further more, despite claims from the aforementioned spin merchants that this random smashing into parked cars was reported to Victoria police, the Victoria police say that they received no such reports.

Some will be going to Greens and Independent's but there are an increasing number who are switching to Turnbull for no other reason than Shorten is widely seen as a man who will never be a PM in this country.

text: To the Labor/Greens cheer squad I say this - the current government is in for the long haul, Australians are sick and tired of revolving door leadership. Turnbull pretty much represents the best in leadership for the country and it's starting to become pretty evident as the days/weeks go by.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The Labor/Greens cheer squad are finally getting what they have been clamouring for after the current government had to come in and clean up the people smuggling disaster left behind by the failed Rudd/Gillard/Rudd regimes.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You seem to forget that they were closed down by the Howard government - only to be reopened by the Labor government after they lost control of the borders.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Nice try TomTit, the Rudd/Gillard/Rudd years almost destroyed the Labor party - she is the reason why Labor only have a handful of MPs left in the lower house.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I don't know about anyone else, but constant pieces in the Guardian about Julia Gillard and Tony Abbott are all about the past and not a particularly attractive past at that.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Labor's solution is and always has been that they have this secret magical money tree that funds all their policy promises - Plibersek was at it again today saying Australia should increase it's overseas aid spend back to the levels when Labor were in government - no idea how it will be paid for, but gee, it sounds really good Tania.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Very interesting article in Fairfax press today where Rosie Batty has applauded a transition to a Turnbull lead government saying we now have strong political leadership in this country compared to the recently departed Abbott administration.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Good to see Julie Bishop representing Australia so well on the world stage and this is even before PM Malcolm Turnbull has started his overseas forays for meetings with global leaders.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Contrast this with the hapless Plibersek who had trouble differentiating between Syria and Iraq in an interview from NY (why is she even in NY?) the other day. A complete novice when it comes to global affairs. Embarrassing for the ALP.
author: TimOfAltona

text: This is a good thing - when it comes to fiscal reform everything should be on the table for consideration by any government. The productivity commission's report should lead the way here.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Had Saddam Hussein not been ousted, along with Gaddafi in Libya we would not be in the current environment we are in the Middle East with tens of thousands people killed & millions of people on the move.
author: TimOfAltona

text: As difficult as it is, the west needs to work with Assad to obliterate IS in Syria then put troops on the ground in Iraq to clear them out of there as well.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Good news - it's clear the Labor/Greens cheer squad don't like any positive news about Julie Bishop and the work she does for Australia on the world stage - they only want to read negative stories.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Let's just hope that after all the leadership instability of the past 5 years we settle down and see a PM in Malcolm Turnbull stay the course for another two or more terms in office.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Labor should use these down time' years to start to reform and rebuild their party - it was promised after the failure of the Rudd/Gillard/Rudd years and the near wipe out but we have seen very little if anything occur.
author: TimOfAltona

text: They need to start with their leadership, then work out their on again off again love affair with the Greens and then take a very hard look at the corrosive factional and union influence which destabilises their party time and time again.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The best opportunity for him is after the expected resounding win at the polls next year where he will have a mandate and the authority within his party to effect change.
author: TimOfAltona

text: If the ALP are joined at the hip with one or more of the alleged corrupt unions or alleged corrupt union officials then they need to sort that out and sort it out very quickly IMO.
author: TimOfAltona

text: What happened was at this morning's announcement of the new domestic violence package, a journo asked Cash if she supported NZ in prohibiting Brown from entering that country due to his criminal conviction for violence.
author: TimOfAltona

text: We all saw what occurred when Rudd encouraged people to make their way to Australia via people smugger boat. A massive disaster at any examination with massive loss of life.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The problem for you David is your views are held by an ever shrinking cabal of Labor cheer squadders trying to cling to a forlorn hope their party has some semblance of electability at the next election.
author: TimOfAltona

text: There will be more and more of this stuff coming out in coming weeks which will re-enforce in people's minds why a change to a Malcolm Turnbull lead government was both necessary and was applauded by most Australians.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Turnbull has no choice but to stay the course - if he were to even hint that the new government may be softening its policy, the people smuggler boats laden with people will start departing Indonesia again - precisely why Labor also endorsed maintaining the government's tough border protection policy, including turn backs, should they gain government one day.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Angela Merkel should have sought wise counsel from Kevin Rudd who tried the same thing when he set Australia up as the migrant/dis-placed persons magnet for SE Asia in 2007. We know the outcome from that.
author: TimOfAltona

text: There is no easy solution, but creating the conditions that allow people to remain in their homeland, where most of them want to be, should be the long term objective.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Any hint that things will be relaxed will see hundreds of boats laden with refugees headed our way once more, accompanied by the drownings and the necessity to reopen immigration detention centres - we have seen all this play out before during the failed Rudd/Gillard/Rudd years and it was a disaster for all concerned.
author: TimOfAltona

text: While we all want to see the offshore centres shut down, we cannot allow that to be the green light to start up the lucrative maritime people smuggling trade once more.
author: TimOfAltona

text: If you can suggest to the government how they can resettle and empty out Nauru and Manus and close them down without restarting hundreds of boats with tens of thousands of refugees and perhaps thousands drowning as a result - they will be all ears.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The Left don't like her because she was CoS to Tony Abbott when he was Opposition Leader & was a key player in bringing down 3 sitting Labor Prime Ministers (with a little help from Labor factional warfare on the first 2) so they will forever direct their collective anger at her.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You would like to think that between the Greens, Labor and the Coalition they can come up with an agreed solution that prevents a candidate who attracts a whopping 0.51% of the primary vote being rewarded with a seat in the Australian Senate.
author: TimOfAltona

text: So as it turns out Abbott is gone and Shorten has to contend with a PM who has the potential to blow Labor's electoral chances out of the water anyway.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I see on Sky that Neil James from the Australian Defence Assn has given Marise the big thumbs up as Defence Minister given her wide ranging experience on Senate Defence committees over the years plus her first hand experience with visits to front line Australian military bases in Afghanistan.
author: TimOfAltona

text: This is a click bait 'nothing to see here story' only the Labor/Greens cheer squad salivate over whilst they ignore their own party seemingly falling apart at the seams IMO.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Your comment does raise a valid point. There are many Labor voters out there who would seriously consider voting for a Turnbull lead government ahead of a seemingly weakened and dysfunctional Labor party.
author: TimOfAltona

text: He danced around the pertinent question from Tony Jones about his involvement and negotiations with Thiess on the Eastlink project - the allegations around this are damning and could ultimately see him ousted as ALP leader - if the polls don't bring him down first.
author: TimOfAltona

text: If Turnbull can demonstrate that he can bring his party and the country with him, then this is exactly the leadership and good government we have been asking for.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Nothing unites a party more and gets them falling in behind the leader than when that leader delivers them a significant lead in preferred PM plus a healthy 2PP majority.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Labor's worst fears have been realised and with Abbott's sudden departure they have been caught out with seemingly no plan or effective leadership to take them through to the next election. They were banking on constructing their entire campaign around Tony Abbott's unpopularity.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Turnbull should capitalise on this early lead to push through key policy reform and it will be refreshing to see Labor, Greens and cross benchers in the senate with no choice but to back the new PM on some of his policy amendments.
author: TimOfAltona

text: He'll single handedly ensure Labor thrash around in the political wilderness whilst having the occasional quickie with the Greens behind the bike sheds for at least another 2 terms of government.
author: TimOfAltona

text: 8 pm - Australian Story - all about why Malcolm Turnbull is the best person to lead Australia for the next 2-3 terms of government.8.30 - Four Corners - all about why Tony Abbott was not the best person to lead Australia9.30 - Q&A - Bill Shorten - solo guest and why he is also not the best person to lead Australia.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Of course there will be fallout from such a stunning coup that has placed the LNP well and truly on the front foot and has left Labor washed aside and almost on the rocks in it's wake.
author: TimOfAltona

text: That way we only get exposed to positive spin from Labor and Greens and hear only negative spin about the government - that's the way it should be in our free and open democracy.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You need to start changing your tune on Malcolm. One reason I am a huge supporter and have been for a long long time is I know he shares exactly the same concerns about West Papua. If any Australian PM is up for challenging Indonesia on their illegal occupation of that territory it is the one we have now. Successive Liberal and Labor governments have all looked the other way for fear of offending Indonesia. I'm confident Malcolm will find a way in time to address this issue. I know it is on his very extensive 'to do' list.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The only assumption you can make is Shorten saw Abbott as his keys to the Lodge, all he had to do was 'be there' and that has now been cruelly ripped away.
author: TimOfAltona

text: At any examination Labor have been caught out here - they were seriously banking on Abbott hanging around until the next election and hoping that would be enough for Shorten to fall over the line by doing nothing - just being there.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Maybe now they will be forced to deliver on their promise to reform and rebuild or risk being nothing more than a bit player being gradually replaced by the Greens.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Labor need to do something and do something quickly, they are being drowned out in the political debate and a situation made worse because they are stuck with the hapless Shorten who at times seems further to the Right than the PM.
author: TimOfAltona

text: If ever there was a safe Liberal seat, North Sydney is it - the Libs need to think carefully who they parachute into that one - someone who is future ministerial material.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Listen to Turnbull's speeches in the Lower House since becoming PM. This is precisely what he is trying to achieve despite Labor's constant wedge politics and confected 'gotcha' moments attempting to discredit the new PM.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Will the Labor candidate turn up at the House of Reps in 3 weeks and see if can sneak into one of the multitude of empty seats up behind Bill Shorten?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Could have something to do with the fact that Labor had little to offer the local area plus most see Labor as unelectable federally with Shorten as leader, so they may as well have a representative in Canberra who is actually sits on the government benches.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Also topical and relevant to this election is that Labor, on instructions from the CFMEU, are doing their best to block the China FTA - this act of attempted economic vandalism has a direct negative impact on businesses in Canning and will come to be a mill stone around the neck of Labor for years to come - even after they sort out their sad and sorry leadership dysfunction.
author: TimOfAltona

text: A great result for the Libs after the turmoil of the past week. Hastie was clearly the superior candidate on the day and the voters of Canning have rewarded him with a seat in the House of Representatives.
author: TimOfAltona

text: This was also a factor in the Liberal win, apart from the Libs having an outstanding candidate, people don't like what they see from Labor trying to destroy a massive economic benefit for Australia at a time when we need it most.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The Labor cheer squad are amongst the sorest losers on the planet - many seem to be unable to accept that the people of Canning voted for the LNP candidate because in their opinion he was the better candidate out of the field of other candidates. For good reason, the vast majority of voters saw Andrew Hastie as the best person to represent them in Canberra.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Funny how Labor fashioned their entire campaign around the slogan ' a vote for Andrew Hastie is a vote for Tony Abbott' only to have that cruelly ripped away from them at the last minute.

text: Oh that's right - because a vote for Andrew Hastie IS a vote for Malcolm Turnbull who is running 3 times more popular in the polls than their own leader.

text: You may be a bit confused - historically there is a 5% swing away from the government of the day in by elections - so this result is in keeping with that trend. It was looking like a 10+% swing only last week - a great result for the Libs, great result for Andrew and a magnificent result for the people of Canning.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Well, if that's the case, I'll be looking over at the opposition side of Parliament to see if I can spot their newly minted Member for Canning sitting up behind Shorten somewhere.

text: Naturally the Left wrote him off within the first 24 hrs of the 'coup' - motivated more by fear of what he may do to Labor's electoral chances than any damage they falsely accuse him inflicting on Australia in the future.

text: Providing he can construct an effective front bench, he can start moving the country in the right direction and Labor can hop on board and enjoy the ride whilst they reform and rebuild their shattered party.

text: Unlikely to be a swing to the LNP - I know Turnbull is the messiah and all that, but don't think even he could conjure up a swing to the Libs when they already enjoy an 11% gap last election.

text: Labor tacticians need to take a hard long look at themselves over the 3 week break and get Shorten and his crew to pull their heads in on trying to constantly disrupt the parliament like recalcitrant school children and try entering into some adult debate with the government on key policy areas.

text: Today it is a referendum on both Bill Shorten's leadership and how voters feel generally about the future of the Coalition government under Turnbull, a small snapshot but an interesting one.

text: I would not be too concerned Ebony, despite what Van Badham would have us believe about Malcolm - I think you will find he is the best friend gender equality groups have ever had in a PM.

text: This is not the main game in town right now and there is always finger pointing and accusations swirling around after a sitting PM is shown the door - ask Labor as they are past masters at this and highly probable that they will be going through the same thing again before Christmas.

text: Plibersek carries way too much baggage from the failed Gillard administration and was a founding member of the infamous Handbag Hit Squad attempting to but failing to pin a misogyny label on Abbott as a tactic to try and turn around Gillards unpopularity.

text: Malcolm Turnbull has been my pick ever since he was Opposition leader - it was all in the timing and thank god we now have Malcolm as our PM.

text: Safe seat or not, if Labor are as good as you tell us each day and the LNP is as bad as you tell us each day then Labor should win easily.

text: They haven't even shown that they are on the path to reform and rebuild - the best they can hope for is to thrash around in the political wilderness for years until they drop the delusion that an unpopular government is all they need to fall back over the line into government.

text: Actually you are wrong, this is only the start. Expecting Turnbull to change the world within his first 24 hrs as PM and before he even has his front bench in place is just a tiny bit unrealistic IMO .

text: The prognosis is looking very positive for the Turnbull administration as evidenced by early polling plus Canning result will be a further indication of the trajectory the government is on.
author: TimOfAltona

text: If Labor are good enough ( and we see plenty of comments each day in these threads trumpeting how good Labor are) they will romp it home in Canning apparently because the electorate don't trust the LNP and want them out of government,again as seen each day in these threads.
author: TimOfAltona

text: So do we expect to see Bill Shorten standing up on the winners podium holding up the hand of the Labor candidate ( anyone know his/her name?) in victory come Saturday night?
author: TimOfAltona

text: If Labor have been good enough in opposition and have presented the electorate with a credible set of policies and a leader who people want to see as our PM, they will romp it home and Shorten's leadership will be safe.
author: TimOfAltona

text: On the other hand if all the ALP have presented are negative wedge politics accompanied by an empty kit bag of ideas and policies along with a disaster of a leader then perhaps they won't taste sweet victory on Saturday?
author: TimOfAltona

text: A tricky situation - if any of the lefties can advise the new PM on how he can bring those asylum seekers who are genuine refugees to Australia without starting up an armada of people smuggling boats and hundreds if not thousands of lives being lost at sea along the way I reckon you should sit down and have a chat with him.

text: Speaking of knives - anyone know who's holding the key to the Labor party room cutlery draw. Did Bill manage to hide it or did Albo take control of it?

text: Who mentioned QT, not me. I'm talking about Labors pressers next week where they will try with the good old wedge politics tactic - this is what needs to change otherwise all they will see is themselves falling further and further behind in the polls.

text: Turnbull is right - Australians want better than that from their elected representatives and Labor are letting the country down thus ensuring they are destined to be stuck in opposition for quite a few years to come.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Labor seriously have to lift their game next week - sensing they are well and truly on the back foot, their childish tactics have been a shambles this week and has exposed them as nothing more than a lost party thrashing around in the political wilderness hoping and praying that if they throw enough mud at the new PM something may stick - unlikely though - Turnbull is too smart for them all and it shows.

text: Then we have to endure yet another knifing drama being played out but ultimate it s probably what Labor need to do if they are to have any hope in the 2019 election IMO.

text: The biggest problem the cheer squad have is that their own party is pretty much unelectable for the myriad of reasons we know so well - suggest they start working out how they can reform Labor and try and get them into a position where they are at least competitive in 2016.

text: Just focussing on Malcolm Turnbull is not enough to get Labor over the line, they need to step up and prove they have the ability to govern this country.

text: On the European refugee crisis - I see Merkel tried to do a Kevin Rudd and look what's happened. She should have spoken to K Rudd first and got his feedback on the human disaster that follows opening up borders to all and sundry.

text: Fantastic news for the LNP, the swinging voters who were not sure about Abbott and the large number of disillusioned Labor voters waiting for Turnbull to take the leadership.

text: If the polls are anything to go by, it seems plenty of Labor voters prefer Turnbull as PM than Shorten. In fact, more than plenty, a significant number of Labor voters.

text: The Labor cheer squad need to get their story straight, half of them were claiming this morning that Shorten got rid of Abbott, now you claim it was Turnbull who got rid of Abbott. Which one is it to be?
author: TimOfAltona

text: David, it must be so sad that you've had the rug pulled out from under your feet with the ascension of Malcolm Turnbull...don't worry you are not alone, most of the ALP are feeling the same way today.
author: TimOfAltona

text: As a 'self confessed' former Liberal voter you may want to give Malcolm a go to see if he can deliver on our expectations before you start canning him?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Do they still hang around with their silly Abbott images in their profile or do we expect they will now transform their online profile to start a crusade against Malcolm Turnbull?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Bill Shorten and the ALP will no longer be able to sit back, do nothing and think all they have to do to win government is 'be there'
author: TimOfAltona

text: All eyes will be on Turnbull and if he can deliver on what it is we all want to see from our government, Shorten will have to be replaced before Christmas.
author: TimOfAltona

text: This afternoon Turnbull had the numbers - I doubt they will change the other way between then and now and for the sake of everyone it would have been good for Abbott to resign his commission and make a clean bloodless transition to a new PM.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The theory is that as they have such small numbers in the lower house, making a noise makes it look like there are more of them than there actually are!
author: TimOfAltona

text: Yet he consistently polls as the nation's preferred PM - head and shoulders above anything Labor can put up - perhaps you are right and the rest of Australia are wrong?
author: TimOfAltona

text: We know happened, or didn't happen, when Labor were running things - not too flash as it turned out, but it'll be up to Turnbull to sell what the current government have achieved thus far.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Shorten and the ALP strategists are in for an uncomfortable few weeks for they know only too well that if Abbott goes then Shorten and the ALP are finished ( for 2016 at least) and will probably lead to yet another knife fest down at 'Team Labor'.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Worth pointing out that Labor under Shorten are in such a weak position that their entire 2016 campaign is not only dependant on Labor losing the Canning by election, but losing without a major swing away from the Libs.
author: TimOfAltona

text: With everyone commenting in Guardian threads who are fixated on polls and claiming the moral high ground because the polls back them up, it's worth pointing out that the same polls have for over two years consistently returned one individual as head and shoulders above everyone else as the clear favourite for PM.
author: TimOfAltona

text: That said, I have read countless times that this by election is a referendum on Tony Abbott's leadership of the Liberal Party and as PM so I'm guessing that if that's the case, everyone in these threads should be saying Hastie has no hope in hell?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Yes, they are not perfect and yes, the sooner the offshore detention centres are emptied and closed the better, however countless lives have been saved as a result of Operation Sovereign Borders.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Funny thing about all this Katharine is that in the view of many or perhaps most who congregate in the Guardian, you as a senior political journo, carry the heavy weight of expectation and responsibility to be actively pro-'left' and  that smacks of being even moderately critical of the ALP or Greens or their respective leadership tends to draw the wrath of those 'affectionately' termed the Labor/Greens cheer squad.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Should you ever, heaven forbid, report or commentate on anything  positive about the LNP or it's policies and particularly the PM, well that just falls into the high treason category and punishment is by way of a sharp personal rebuke and even threats of 'never reading the Guardian again' after a piece the other day (not by you) seemingly praising the Abbott government on it's intake of 12,000 Syrian refugees.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Seems to me that a big chunk of the Labor/Greens cheer squad enjoy logging onto the Guardian Australia edition each day to receive their daily dose of anti-Abbott/anti-LNP reporting and woe betide any Guardian journo who dares not to conform with that expectation.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Vanessa looks to be a pretty good candidate for the Greens and good work by the Guardian to feature another candidate rather than focus each day on the Liberal candidate.

text: As good as she may be, it must be a little disheartening as a candidate to know that you stand almost zero chance of getting up on the day, particularly in Canning.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The experience will be good for her though and if she's really that good Vanessa could be parachuted into another seat where she stands a better chance in the 2016 federal election.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Kudos to the Guardian for giving Andrew enormous publicity leading up to the election......however it could be a wasted effort......Liberal voters in Canning are unlikely to have heard about the Guardian, let alone read it.

text: Not the worst interview we've seen from Abbott and certainly not the best - but he did make some valid points relevant to progress the government is making in key areas.

text: We wait with much anticipation for Sarah Hanson-Young to hold a press conference to congratulate the government on it's decision to grant 12,000 Syrian refugees permanent residency in Australia, over and above the current UNHCR quota.

text: You can easily see why Mike Baird is the most popular senior politician at a state level whilst Malcolm Turnbull is the most popular senior politician federally - according to opinion polls which so many hang their hats on as the key indicator of electoral success.

text: Portraying Australia as some kind of evil empire with closed borders is mischievous and inaccurate. Australia has one of the largest refugee intakes in the world and will probably do more with this latest Syrian crisis.

text: Factcheck - Austria are not offering residency to the migrants arriving from Hungary, they are merely transporting/escorting them out if the country as quickly as possible and dumping them in Bavaria for Germany to sort out. In fact there are reports that Austria, like Hungary, are about to now close its borders to stem the tide of mass uncontrolled migration.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Factcheck - The government's stop the boats policy has worked and has very likely prevented hundreds of distressing situations like the Syrian boy washed up on the Bodrum beach last week. The dark days of the last Labor government saw over a thousand men, women and children drown in the waters north of Australia and why were they never named and personalised like the boy last week? Where were the Greens denouncing maritime people smugglers and calling on people not to board boats and head to Australia?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Factcheck - the government paid the crews on a couple of boats to return their passengers to the safety of Indonesia, not to their country of origin. These people are perfectly safe in Indonesia whilst they await processing through the UNHCR. They are not fleeing the threat of death in Indonesia.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Factcheck - the number of children in detention has significantly reduced since the dark days of the last Labor government. The government are working to empty the offshore facilities, opened by Labor and overflowing because they lost control of the borders. There have been reported cases of abuse which is unacceptable and the sooner the centres are closed the better. If the government were to relax the rules around families or unaccompanied children arriving by boat , refer to factcheck on drownings above.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Factcheck - Australia targeting IS positions in Syria will not lead to an improvement in the polls for Abbott. Claiming Abbott pressured the U.S. to invite Australia is nothing more than leftist rhetoric. Obama called Abbott from Airforce One to discuss the Trans Pacific Partnership and the topic of IS and Syria arose. U.S. Military officials subsequently contacted their Australian counterparts and it went from there. In case any of the Labor/Greens cheer squad don't like what the U.S. are doing in IS held territory in Syria hop onto Liveleak and take a look at what IS are doing to men, women and children from mainly non-Sunni communities - no wonder these people are fleeing. You may change your mind about Australia assisting with the effort to destroy IS.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Factcheck - Australia can and very likely will do more to assist within our capabilities, but there is limit to how many people we can accommodate - 10, 20 or even 30 thousand is a tiny fraction of those seeking resettlement, there are millions behind them. The solution has to be resolving the situation in their home countries so they can return - stopping IS is a prerequisite of that.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You maybe right,but reality is Di Natale will never ever be PM or even run for PM.....its LNP or Labor. You need to make the most out of those two.

text: Labor have been caught out going in half cocked with a number of 10,000 pulled out of their arse thinking they can wedge the government ahead of anything Dutton comes back with from UNHCR talks in Geneva and Paris.

text: Clearly a recalcitrant senate made up of a colourlful mix of washed out union hacks, kangaroo poo throwers, bogan Tasmanians and an eclectic array of people getting in with a tiny fraction of the vote courtesy of the Preference Whisperer has made good governing a tad challenging.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Once again the Greens are proposing the solution to halt the genocidal march of ISIS is to join them around a campfire in the desert and whilst holding hands everyone sings Kumbaya and everything will be resolved and all will happily ever after - well sure beats the shit out of bombing ISIS, but I doubt the Greens strategy will work too well in this case.
