text: I'm confused - all weekend the Labor/Greens cheer squad have been attacking the government for perceived inaction on the refugee situation in Europe and today when it's announced Dutton is headed to Geneva to meet with UNHCR officials on Australia's potential contribution, they are all attacking him for going over there to meet with the UNHCR?

text: It is a real shame so many of the Labor/Greens cheer squad seem more than happy to let Daesh continue their genocidal march through Syria and Iraq. text: Important to ensure necessary contingency plans are in place to rescue any RAAF crews in the highly unlikely event they come down in enemy territory - looks like the U.S. and any other Middle Eastern airforces currently operating on the Syrian theatre will have this key element covered.

text: Wrong.....only a RC can compel people to give evidence under oath. In any other situation including police interviews or courtroom evidence no one is compelled to say anything - exactly the reason why these corrupt union officials have got away with their criminality for so long ...no-one co-operates with the police and go to great lengths to disrupt or block a police investigation. Only a RC has the power to get to the bottom of serious allegations- which is precisely why Labor and the ACTU want this shut down and shut down quickly.

text: Labor and their supporters will be found to be barking up the wrong tree over this - more information is surfacing which clarifies the all important timeline and related responses by Heydon and his office to this event.

text: Looking forward to Labor having to apologise to the commissioner and Bill Shorten back in the witness box to explain his involvement in dodgy union practices. An interesting piece on Sky the other night about what's coming down the pipeline for Shorten.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Funny thing - we were saying the exact same thing about Bill Shorten the other day...Labor should do all they can to keep the unelectable Bill Shorten in the role until the next election - worth a lot of seats to the LNP if he is still there.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Fortunately voters don't buy this current smokescreen by the ALP designed to cover their tracks within the union movement. Crime and corruption within the union movement will be exposed despite Labor doing their utmost to keep it hidden.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Could be a bit of confusion here - last I looked the LNP are not the accused at the RC. In fact no one is accused....that may come out later at the findings.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Your theory is predicated on the assumption that there is a viable alternative government waiting in the wings - this is precisely where your argument falls over and will see the current government returned - with or without Tony Abbott.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Wouldn't it be ideal if the Guardian simply white washed any reports or news that could favour the government and only report on stuff that is either anti-LNP or pro-Labor/Greens. Now  a newspaper!
author: TimOfAltona

text: Have not agreed with his comments at all. The point is he is significantly better informed about the situation on the ground in Syria than anyone commenting in this thread and his opinions should at least be respected given what he has seen and heard over the past couple of weeks.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Given Dan Tehan is the Chair of Parliamentary Joint Committee on Intelligence and Security and just returned from a fact finding mission with intelligence agencies in the US, France and the UK he speaks with some authority on the situation on the ground in Syria and what is needed to assist curtail the advance of daesh in that country.
author: TimOfAltona

text: With all due respect to the Labor/Greens anti-government keyboard warriors in this thread sitting safely and comfortably at home or in your allocated cubicle at Trades Hall (whichever it may be) I suggest Dan Tehan has a much better insight into the complexities of Syria and Iraq than you. Just saying.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You may be a bit confused over this Dais - Dan Tehan is the Chair of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Intelligence and Security and has just returned from a fact finding mission to the USA, France and the UK meeting with senior military intelligence agencies in those countries regarding Syria and Iraq. His comments come from information he has been exposed to during the trip.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Factor in the vast amount of sophisticated electronic exploratory monitoring equipment employed over the decades plus thousands of archeologists pouring over every mm of that tomb and its surroundings in the past 90 odd years, to proclaim a hidden doorway has only just now been 'discovered' right under everyone's noses sounds fanciful.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I have been in that tomb several times over the years and let's face it, given the very small area of the burial chamber, it is highly implausible that a 'hidden' doorway purporting to lead to a much larger tomb has only just now come to light.
author: TimOfAltona

text: In addition, knowing how things work in Egypt, only a hint would have been needed that such a doorway existed and the former corrupt Mubarak regime would have been probing & cutting through the walls to get their hands on the much anticipated Nefertiti treasure years ago.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Strange why the 'experts' in Toulouse have not not publicly released anything that validates Najib's claim. Surely it is in everyones interests, foremost Najib's, to produce the evidence tracing this piece back to MH370?
author: TimOfAltona

text: I see and as expected the Labor MPs keep pushing the boundaries with the new Speaker to see what they can get away with before being thrown out. Tony Smith is doing a pretty good job in dealing with this on Day 2 of his tenure.
author: TimOfAltona

text: A small cabal of disaffected Labor/Greens supporters hovering around a Guardian thread do not a make up the majority of the public or for that matter even the 'public' - just so you know.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Perhaps the government MPs on their turn for a question put a question to the Opposition on some of their policies (or lack of policies)...that would make QT a lot more interesting.
author: TimOfAltona

text: This may come as a big surprise to the Labor/Greens cheer squad but there is a very large number of fellow Australians who agree with and support Abbott's positioning on this.
author: TimOfAltona

text: He did an ok job on his very first day. No doubt he will grow into the role and be 'tested' by Labor along the way to see what they can and cannot get away with.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Where are the howls of protests from the resident Labor/Greens cheer squad that the Labor government are evil and acting like Nazis for not doing enough for this endangered animal?
author: TimOfAltona

text: I'm sure the Labor/Greens cheer squad will be forensically scouring the list of MPs expenses to see who can be the first to come up with something, anything, on Tony Smith.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Largely because when push comes to shove, Labor are still on the nose after The Killing Season (best advertisement on why you should avoid the Labor Party) and voters will not risk returning an unreformed Labor party into government.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Not at all. Given the Bronwyn Bishop saga sucked the oxygen out of everything else, I anticipated the result would have been a lot worse for the government. This is a good result at any examination when you factor in trends over recent months.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The result tells us Tony Abbott is still not popular, Bill Shorten is still not popular and people nominate Labor for no other reason than a protest vote, not because Labor stands for anything in particular.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Good to see the government has Labor and their cheer squad floundering around trying to guess who will be the new LNP Speaker. This is a good start for whoever gets the gig tomorrow. No point the PM broadcasting his preference ahead of the party room vote. This is the correct way to approach this transition to a new Speaker IMHO.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Players who infringe against an opponent are routinely booed in any AFL game. Go for it Goodesy and watch the Geelong fans fall silent should you infringe against one of their players for fear of being labelled racist - high tackles, charging, late contact, striking - the choice is yours.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Don't disagree with your sentiments re Clinton. Problem for the Republicans is they don't seem to have a clear leading candidate, Trump is all empty froth and bubble and he is overshadowing genuine Republican aspirants.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I doubt the voters in SA are too concerned about how government strategies are executed - they have come out the big winners here and Abbott will probably succeed with his objective, irrespective of how messy it may look to Lenore.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Don't believe them for a minute - wild horses won't keep them from tuning in - they need to so we can get the 500 odd confected comments Tuesday morning attacking anything or everything Josh Frydenburg utters on the program.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Plenty of fair skinned, blonde haired, blue eyed AFL players have been subjected to regular booing for a period of time - from time to time it becomes fashionable to boo a particular player so crowds join in.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I ask this question- from now on if Adam Goodes infringes against an opposing player during play are the crowds permitted to boo or is he the only player in the AFL to be exempted?
author: TimOfAltona

text: The media will be swarming all over this match on the lookout for anyone in the crowd brave enough to actually boo at an AFL match whether Goodes is near the ball or not.
author: TimOfAltona

text: There are always going to be huge social and economic consequences with the uncontrolled migration of millions of people from different cultures having little or no money to support themselves turning up in 'wealthier' countries and expecting that country to support them.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I'm with you. The sheer gaul of a PM actually travelling around his country to talk to people and announce government policies. No Australian PM has ever done this type of thing before, why should Abbott start now? It's just not right.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I have always maintained that the majority of the Labor cheer squad are not really interested in the 'welfare' of those coming to Australia by people smuggler boats - it's all about not wanting a core policy that Abbott went to the last election with and won convincingly to succeed.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Well without doubt the PM and the government have had the last laugh here - not only has the policy been a great success, Labor have now conceded they were wrong and are emulating the government's stop the boat policy.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Actually they are being stopped - you are playing with semantics to try and bluff your way through the argument. What you really want to say is that a very small number of boats (compared to the thousands when Labor were in government) have not stopped
author: TimOfAltona

text: Bottom line here is Australia is participating, along with a number of other countries in the war against an evil and reprehensible non-state group of genocidal terrorists intent on destroying anyone or anything ideologically opposed to their twisted form of Islam.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The article above makes no mention of the tens of thousands of men, women and children murdered by Daesh nor does it mention the tens of thousands of lives that will be lost if Daesh are allowed to continue their jihadist rampage through Syria and Iraq unchecked.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Daesh, just like Hamas, embed themselves amongst civilian populations to both protect themselves and attempt to construct a propaganda victory should civilian casualties occur - broadcasting suspected or alleged civilian casualty numbers serves no purpose other than to play into the hands of the enemy and encourages continued use of civilians as human shields.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Seems no one is brave enough to admit that their own party is hopeless and voters won't trust another Labor/Greens government until Labor sort out their internal dysfunction and leadership woes.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I'm with you. If you want true unbiased media coverage that tells the true story you can't go past Red Flag, that doyen of Australian socialist newspapers that will tell you only what you to read and obliterate any opposing opinion.
author: TimOfAltona

text: First to go was Labor's belief that they need do nothing but sit back and cruise into government off the back of bad polling for the LNP - irrespective of how grossly unsuited their own leader was for the job.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Now that that little myth has been exposed for what it is, a myth, we can get back to the real world which has Labor strategists worried, very worried indeed.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Foreign investment is fine but there is a limit to how much and what we sell off before it becomes detrimental to the long term interests of the nation. Residential housing is the same.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Funny how Newspoll , that long time nemesis of the Labor/Greens cheer squad who routinely declared it 'rigged' and nothing more than a Murdoch conspiracy has morphed into the shining light of polls,highly credible and truly reflects the wishes of the electorate and now they can't wait for it to come out.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Or is it that Newspoll only has any credibility in the eyes of the cheer squad when it reports Labor in front otherwise as we regularly read in the Guardian threads, it isn't worth the paper it's written on and is nothing more than a tool to favour the conservative side of politics when it shows support for Labor falling?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Surprised me too. Either Labor are more on the nose than we thought or voters differentiated the 'sins' of Bronwyn from the good work the government has achieved across a number of policies. That said the Abbott government still have plenty of work ahead of them in the next 12 months.
author: TimOfAltona

text: He carries way too much baggage from knifing two sitting PMs', has had very public serious sexual criminal allegations directed at him and is seen to be beholding to the union movement who only represent a fraction of the work force.
author: TimOfAltona

text: So given Bill Shorten is ranked lower than Tony Abbott as preferred PM - any chance you can share with us what voters would prefer to Bill Shorten - TWO piles of steaming dog turds perhaps?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Makes no difference who owns whom in betting - if I were in the Labor cheer squad I'd be throwing a lazy few thousand on Labor to win the next election and Scott Morrison or Julie Bishop as the Liberal leader at the next election - I keep reading comments in Guardian threads how both of those outcomes are certainty.
author: TimOfAltona

text: It is no secret that Bronwyn Bishop was the great nemesis of the Labor front bench and they and their supporters cannot believe their luck that something like this came along. That said it is appropriate that she steps down and pays the penalty for her excesses with public money.
author: TimOfAltona

text: How much this has damaged the PM is debatable, but undoubtedly he has lost some of his shine as a result. If Abbott spearheads a review and tightening up of the 'grey' areas when it comes to MP entitlements then he will gain some credit for that and Labor will be backing him as well. All good.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Abbott is correct, he should have moved on this matter a good 7 days before he did and yes he will lose some of his shine as a result.
author: TimOfAltona

text: That said, the right appointment for Speaker will take a lot of heat out of the debate and settle things down in parliament almost immediately - providing Labor don't conduct themselves in the same disorderly manner they have since going into Opposition, things should be fine.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Wow, the Labor/Greens cheer squad are only too happy to try and milk this as much as they can while it takes the focus and heat off their own failing Leader. Sooner or later this will drop off the pages and we are back to talking about Bloob Shortstop again.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I don't have an opinion on Bruce Scott, but looks like he will be acting Speaker next week so we will see how he goes - the other thing is he has announced his retirement recently. You are right though, unlikely to go to a National Party MP when the Liberals have such strong numbers in the House.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Hate to be the bearer of bad news, but the new Speaker will come from a range of 90 government MP's and Philip Ruddock is the most experienced of all of them and will add considerable gravitas to the role.
author: TimOfAltona

text: As much as you want a Labor/Greens MP to be Speaker you have to wait until they are in government again, that is some considerable time off yet - perhaps in another two terms depending on what happens with the Liberal leadership.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Always good to see Turnbull has the Labor cheer squad breaking out into a cold sweat - for they know only too well their man is no match for a Turnbull lead government. In fact a Turnbull lead government has the capacity to keep Labor warming the opposition benches for years to come, if for no other reason there are plenty of Labor supporters who would switch sides if Turnbull was to be PM.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Well he did get her to stand down, granted it was probably 7 days too late, but Gillard set the precedent on that with her bunkering down for weeks trying to protect Craig Thomson.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I hope the Guardian report on Malcolm Turnbull's interviews this morning - he made some very good comments on this issue and about MPs entitlements in general which even the Labor/Greens cheer squad could not disagree.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Good response to this by Malcolm. He was spot on about MPs and their expenses that no one could disagree with except totally biased Labor cheer squadders concerned that Turnbull could replace Abbott.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Perhaps if Labor MPs stopped behaving like primary school children and continued flouting the standing orders after being warned several times they would not have been thrown out. More should have been thrown out, the Speaker showed great restraint IMHO.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I think it's a fair observation that it matters not who the PM and Leader of Government Business march up to the Speakers Chair next, the Labor/Greens cheer squad will be blindly attacking that individual with a vengeance - it's started already before a person has even been appointed.
author: TimOfAltona

text: As for Labor, they will be quick to 'test' whoever gets the gig to A) see how much nonsense they can get away with in QT and B) see who will receive the honour of being the first Labor MP thrown out by the new Speaker. We should open up a book on who will be first to get thrown out - I have a fair idea.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Very interesting that it is Malcolm Turnbull hitting all the airwaves this morning and speaking a fair amount of common sense over this issue - makes you wonder if it is a planned tactic by the government or it really is just Malcolm announcing the creation of 4000 new jobs associated with the NBN. Either way he's looking solid at the moment compared to others IMHO
author: TimOfAltona

text: The ALP eat one of their own at the drop of a hat, except where in Gillard's case with Thomson, he was shown loyalty to prop up her failing government.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Nonsense - he displayed very good leadership . You have to go back to Gillard to see weak leadership - the way she protected Craig Thomson despite all the evidence. THAT was weak leadership - destroyed he in the end.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I like Bronwyn, this expense issue aside, she did a great job in keeping a lid on the disruptive tactics Labor decided to adopt in parliament after they were decimated last election.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Good move by Abbott to shut this down..... No one could criticise him for not showing leadership and tapping Bronwyn on the shoulder to give the government clear air next week.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Hate to be the bearer of bad news comrade, but with the government having significantly superior numbers in the lower house after the drubbing of Labor in 2013 I seriously doubt anyone from Labor will be asked to sit in the Big Chair......in fact the chances of that happening are about the same as Bill Shorten one day being an Australian PM.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Looks like Bronwyn will have the last laugh - it is now only a matter of time before Labor Party luminaries are uncovered over travel 'rorts' as a result of the investigation announced by the PM today.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The comments of the past few days over this issue are reminiscent of the lead up to the great 1789 revolution in France which prompts me to observe the comments made about the great unwashed masses back then - "The peasants are revolting!"
author: TimOfAltona

text: The ALP will treading very carefully here -the last thing they want is forensic examination of some or any of their MP's travel claims going back over the years...Tony Burke and his family holiday extravaganza is a case in point...there will be more on this in coming days.
author: TimOfAltona

text: My view is the Speaker needs to stand aside, either while these allegations are investigated or fully retire from the role, notwithstanding that in either event a full, proper and transparent investigation is still warranted.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Because Gillard's were fake , they were a tactic by her puppet master McTernan to try and soften her looks, but the media rightly called her out on it.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Unlike the Labor Party who eat then excrete their own in a blink of an eye, Abbott strenuously backs his team until there is compelling evidence that he has no choice but to cut them loose - pretty much what you would expect from a good leader.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You somehow omitted the reason Slipper was put into the Speaker role in the first place - had something to do with the Gillard PM woman knifing an excellent Speaker in Harry Jenkins, whose father was a Speaker before him.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Why did Gillard knife Harry? - to try and do a grubby deal to prop up her failing administration knowing full well peter Slipper had more baggage on him than the left luggage room at Heathrow Airport.
author: TimOfAltona

text: A stunt because they and everyone else knows they have such piddly numbers in the lower house it is doomed before it even gets up - in fact it wont even debated - "I move the member be longer heard" will shut it all down before it wastes time in the parliament.
author: TimOfAltona

text: We look forward with great enthusiasm to the Guardian article (I'm sure it's on it's way) about Tony Burkes alleged multiple instances of claiming personal travel/holidays to the Australian taxpayer - it's pretty much splashed across every other media outlet and even stranger is that no one in this thread even wants to discuss it.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Fair to say Bronwyn could crawl across a kilometre of broken glass on her bare hands and knees begging for forgiveness and the cheer squad for Labor and the Greens would still be screeching "off with her head".
author: TimOfAltona

text: This has nothing to do with any moral effrontery they are supposedly claiming but everything to do with payback - revenge is sweet and no one does revenge better than a bitter and twisted Labor party and it's supporters.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Just as it is the media who have taken up the cause against the Minnesota dentist who killed Cecil the lion, the Bronwyn Bishop saga will only prevail whilst sections of the media elect to continue milking the story to see what comes out the other end.
author: TimOfAltona

text: So with all the Labor/Greens cheer squad calling for Bronwyn's head as sweet payback, their thoughts must now turn to who would replace her to lead the government into it's second term?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Bronwyn Bishop, that long time nemesis of the ALP, seems to be copping a bit of flack from the cheer squad who smell blood so come swarming into the thread to spew forth their confected anger hoping a new Liberal Speaker will be in the chair when parliament resumes.
author: TimOfAltona

text: It would be a shame to see her move out of the role, she's had a tough gig with a childish and recalcitrant Labor party trying to make up for their small numbers in the house by creating constant white noise during QT, but it will be interesting to see who may replace her if she chooses to step aside.
author: TimOfAltona

text: All the huff and puff about how badly Gillard was treated and yet we have seen the most vile, sexist and disparaging remarks thrown at Bronwyn Bishop from you and your cohorts in recent weeks.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Just quietly Janey, if you go back and have a look it was the High Court that scuttled Gillard's desperate effort to halt the damage already inflicted by her own party.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Going out and providing a meet and greet taxi service back to Australia for people arriving by people smuggler boats is certain to lead to hundreds of boats departing for Australia and lead to mass tragedy as we've seen both when Labor opened the gates previously and more recently in the Mediterranean.
author: TimOfAltona

text: How about getting the Deputy Speaker of the House of Lords filmed snorting cocaine from a female prostitute's breast and then sitting in a chair wearing a red bra on the show?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Now there's some real Labor talent for you. Perhaps the ALP will have an opening for him - we hear they are on the look out for a new leader.
author: TimOfAltona

text: If I was the PM I would now be seriously considering lifting the 'ban' by doing a solo appearance on the program. He has acquired enough political capital to front up to the program and tackle the predictable questions from the Labor/Greens cheer squad sitting in the audience.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You seem to be just as confused as many others in this thread - Boswell is not in government and is not even in politics since he retired last year.
author: TimOfAltona

text: If the Border Force or Australian Navy have a policy of towing all boats back to Australia or transferring people onto naval vessels then you have provided the people smugglers with a perfect business model with thousands of boats heading to Australia along with the guaranteed mass drownings.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Irrespective of any temporary bans on LNP front bench attendees, there were a plethora of suitable contemporary Liberal Party representatives to negate the predictable ho hum propaganda emanating from the mouth of the Qld Premier.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Boswell was referencing asylum seeker intake quotas, of which Australia I think has the second highest in the world, as opposed to countries who have lost control of their borders and thousands flow in each week.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Between you and me, in these threads I see the current PM labelled with significantly harsher & grubbier names on a daily basis and for the life of me cannot find any comments from you accusing or denouncing the authors as being sexist or demeaning.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I was so looking forward to the panel depicting Plibbers scurrying out of the venue to elude the boat turn back vote and hiding out amongst the mops in the janitors closet - only to find Penny Wong already in there.
author: TimOfAltona

text: At least the Palestinians have the ability to fight back, the poor West Papuans' get pummelled by the Indonesian soldiers and police tantamount to genocide & on our very doorstep.
author: TimOfAltona

text: A birdie told me the Labor left now label him "Silly Billy" and are no doubt weighing up their options to try and get a leader from the left inserted - it's all in the timing of course.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I would like to see a poll targeting the criminal people smuggling operators up in Indonesia - which government would you like to see in office after the next election?
author: TimOfAltona

text: I think we all know who would get 100% of the vote - here's a tip - it is not the party that has successfully shut down the People smuggling trade in this part of the world.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Funny thing Dais, the PM has around 8-10 engagements each day.....at some point he has to call a halt to doorstops or his schedule is thrown out. Just the way it is.
author: TimOfAltona

text: It's high time the media stopped showing its bias against the government - Labor is a protected species when it comes to the media. When will the media start doing their job instead of running a protection racket for Labor?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Labor need to go away and work out how they can unite a deeply divided party and then come back to us when they think they have a viable and united party.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Funny how when things go rapidly pear shaped for the ALP, the Labor cheer squad suddenly only want to talk about, of all things, helicopters. There is an adjective to describe that human behaviour, but it escapes me for the moment.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Pretty much there has been a conga line of ministers on Sky this morning, all being interviewed about Labor's dysfunction. You need to broaden your media interests beyond Guardian and Socialist weekly.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Please provide the link where Abbott is quoted as saying he would resign on Aug 08 if the coalition is not ahead in the polls. If not, you are simply adding to the growing perception from both sides that you are a goose in these threads.
author: TimOfAltona

text: So the leader of the ALP and the Deputy leader are publicly divided - one wants to copy the government's successful Operations Sovereign Borders formula and the other is pushing for Australia to be a magnet for people smuggler boats?
author: TimOfAltona

text: I'm with you - very important to keep the people smugglers informed of tactics used to shut down their deadly trade....the more information we feed them the easier it is for them to succeed.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Following the failed Gillard experiment, if Labor try for a person who will once again use the misogyny tactic to try and win support for her and her party, then they deserve to stay in opposition for a generation or more IMHO.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Yes will be interesting to see how the dust settles after Labor's display of massive disunity over the past 24 hrs and it's not over yet by a long shot.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The Labor Left should have got up - then there would have been a distinct difference in policy between the government and the ALP going into the next election - then we could allow voters decide who they want to govern.
author: TimOfAltona

text: This comment is typical of Labor and highlights why they are in opposition - all these 'ideas' costing multi-billions of dollars with no way to pay for them. Labor are abject failures when it comes to implementing major infrastructure projects - look at he shambles surrounding their last go at rolling out an NBN.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Increasing the government intake will not solve the issue of millions of displaced people and makes zero difference to people smugglers - if Labor give them a sign that Operation Sovereign Borders will be relaxed, the boats will start up again along with the associated drownings.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You need both deterrents to make the policy work - bringing people who have previously arrived here by boat into Australia is precisely what the people smugglers want the government to do......they have their business model back.
author: TimOfAltona

text: He knew well in advance of his little announcement re boat turn backs. Shorten is a numbers man - he knew he had the numbers or else he wouldn't have gone ahead with it - too much to lose if he got voted down.
author: TimOfAltona

text: This is going to be highly entertaining 3 days and thanks to the Guardian for providing a rolling commentary on the Labor Party tearing themselves apart before our very eyes.
author: TimOfAltona

text: After the crash and burn of the Gillard experiment, do you really think the ALP will knife another leader and insert a left over from the failed Gillard administration?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Something tells me this conference will be a gift to the government.....already the message to voters is Labor are divided and dysfunctional....nothing much has changed since the dark days graphically portrayed in The Killing Season recently.
author: TimOfAltona

text: One thing is certain - if the Left prevail and the party endorse a relaxing of Operation Sovereign Borders, Labor can look forward to years in the political wilderness.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Shorten was on the money...but his two biggest rivals for leadership Albo and the hapless Plibersek look like consigning Labor to the opposition benches for another two or three terms.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Good to see an increase in GST on the table - just like same-sex marriage, a GST increase will occur in Australia at some stage and it may as well be discussed and mapped out for all to see before the next election.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The successful NZ model was to go from 10% to 12.5% and then John Key took 15% to an election and smashed NZ Labour out of the ball park. Interesting the NZ GST is a broad based tax including fresh food etc.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Jem whichever way you cut this, the world cannot cope with mass migration of millions of people from continent to continent without creating significant and serious social and economic upheaval, not to mention the thousands of people who lose their lives along the way.
author: TimOfAltona

text: This is a humanitarian approach and the envy of European countries tasked with fishing thousands of bodies out of the Mediterranean over the past few months, not to mention the hundreds of thousands flooding into Europe with no money, no jobs, no where to live and no place to go.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I was in Paris recently and the shanty-like ghettos springing up in and around the fringes of the city, mainly around bridges and railway lines near the Peripherique were disturbing.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Can you imagine the mess we would be in with asylum seekers if we gave the Greens the keys to our border security - hundreds of thousands of people heading to Australia on boats. Come to think of it, I think the Greens policy is to go up to Indonesia and transport everyone back to Australia by charter flights or cruise boats.
author: TimOfAltona

text: It is only the company owned stores being phased out as leases come up, the dozens of other ABC outlets sitting within other retail organisations ie Dymocks will remain open as will the online sales.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Sarah Hanson-Young has predictably attacked Shorten and Labor over this one which begs the question, why do the Greens permit votes for their candidates to flow through to the ALP?
author: TimOfAltona

Then we can decide if it's a good policy or not.

text: Very interesting that Leigh Sales brought up the topic of Shorten knifing two serving PMs - she used those very words - right here is why Labor made a huge mistake in parachuting Shorten into the leadership - he carries way too much baggage which the government and media can call on in the lead up to the next election.

text: In any event, my view is it matters not who leads Labor to the next election, even with the usual help from their Greens partners, the ALP are largely unelectable until they get that reform sorted and map out a plan for the future.

text: Labor, along with their ever dwindling cohort of supporters recognise that a Turnbull lead government would wipe the floor with whatever the Labor party could muster at the present time, so all that is left is smear, innuendo and disingenuous comments calling on Turnbull to sacrifice his political career over an ABC television show.

text: True. However, if the consequences of him not playing ball with the CFMEUs alleged demands were physical harm or destruction of his business then I think I know where the court would rule on this one.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I'm with you. Clearly it's all his fault. If he was not operating a business in the first place, the CFMEU would not have come knocking on his door. Definitely his fault and he should be prosecuted to the full extent of the law.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The objectives of this commission are to be applauded - however it is fair to say that domestic abuse is not some kind of new 'modern day' phenomena and for all it's best intentions, the RC will not be able to eliminate or even necessarily reduce the incidence.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Partners abusing partners or family members abusing other family members has been occurring in all it's ugly manifestations for thousands of years.....in some cultures it is more prevalent than others, particularly husband on wife.
author: TimOfAltona

text: In 2015 Australia I would suggest that primarily alcohol and to a lesser extent drugs and mental illness play a major role in triggering both one off and regular episodes of domestic abuse, in which case sadly it can never be stamped out.
author: TimOfAltona

text: All the commission can do is raise awareness of a range of options a person may have to assist them seek help from an abusive family member and also perhaps recommend how health care workers and law enforcement officials can provide better early identification and intervention to help an abused individual and/or the perpetrator.
author: TimOfAltona

text: A real conundrum for the ALP. They know Shorten has under performed and is carrying way too much baggage to ever lead the ALP to an election win yet their 'rules' ensure they can't ditch him.
author: TimOfAltona

text: On Insiders this morning the panelist from the left believed Shorten was safe in his role for no other reason that there is no obvious successor who can step in and lead the party to an election, contrasting that with the Libs who have a strong candidate in Turnbull to lead the LNP to an election.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Given we are saving billions of dollars in not having to deal with the scourge of people smugglers foisted upon us by the last Labor/Greens government, there is probably a bit of coin available to invest in nuclear without imposing any taxes full stop.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You need to understand the context of the argument. The CEFC is still fully funded to invest in renewables like solar. No one is suggesting funding in renewables has stopped, except perhaps remnants of the Labor/Greens cheer squad looking to continue their anti-Abbott rants.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Funny, there are around 17 countries that say otherwise Mickey. France generates nearly all it's power from nuclear energy and around 10 other major economies get at least a third of their power from nuclear generation.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Well if that's the case, the ALP are pretty much backing the government's Tea Party type agenda too. So that accounts for 144 seats out of a 150 seat parliament.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Actually stopping the boats was not easy - after Labor and the Greens left the door so far open that tens of thousands arrived and 1000+ drowned it took a determined government with the backing of Australian voters to close it. Good to see however that the ALP have recognised their grave error and are now backing the government on border control.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Wrong...it gets back to the wisdom of the ABC in allowing a convicted criminal with a history of violent threats against commonwealth officers and female journos plus weapons offences to have a platform on a public broadcaster to push his rhetoric on live TV.

text: Suspect you are a little confused....I looked out for the live studio audience asking questions or making statements on Insiders and blow me down, buggered if I could spot one.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Suggest everyone read the bill for themselves - seems like 95% of the people on here have just simply attacked the government and Labor for the sake of it without understanding the contents of the bill.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I read it and it looks pretty clear to me that doctors (as an 'entrusted person' within the meaning of the Act) commit an offence if they make a record of or disclose protected information  (a) the making of the record or disclosure is authorised by section 43, 44, 45, 47, 48 or 49; or (b) the making of the record or disclosure is in the course of the persons employment or service as an entrusted person; or (c) the making of the record or disclosure is required or authorised by or under a law of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory; or (d) the making of the record or disclosure is required by an order or direction of a court or tribunal.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Not totally across what this is all about, but surely if both the lower and upper house passed this legislation, meaning supported by at least LNP, Labor and independents there is a valid reason behind it.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Surprising the amount of grubby attacks given he took the QLD Newman government to task over environmental issues and won and was poster boy for the anti-Newman brigade for a while.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Thank you for backing up my point. The cheer squad for Labor and the Greens would much prefer a Q&A that is totally devoted to their cause without any counter argument coming from the government. Works really well in North Korea, Cuba and Venezuela.
author: TimOfAltona

text: All the lefties on here clearly don't want to see any government minister infecting their Q&A panel, their wish is for a panel devoid of an LNP minister so only Labor/Greens views can be put forward on live national TV.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Yet for some strange reason when the PM grants them their wish, temporarily at least, they are frothing at the mouth for a government minister, Malcolm Turnbull in this case, to be on the panel.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Point 2 - Turnbull does not need advice from the Labor/Greens cheer squad who are only too pleased to see him fall on his sword over a Q&A storm in a teacup so he no longer presents a threat to labor and the Greens as our next PM
author: TimOfAltona

text: Point 3 - If this issue is so important, Where is our supposed 'alternative' government on this issue? Plenty of Q&A hyperventilating from their Guardian threads cheer squad but deftly silence from the people that matter, Shorten & co.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Point 4 - Everyone banging on about Tony Abbott not appearing on Q&A, like the 'magnificent'Julia Gillard did...well that appearance certainly did wonders for her popularity didn't it? BTW, when did we last see Bill Shorten take questions on Q&A? Just wondering.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Don't fret cheer squadders, Q&A will be on as normal Monday night to get your fill of left wing commentary, just won't be anyone from your government, well a minister anyway, on the panel to defend against the leftist rhetoric. Is that not want you ultimately want to see anyway?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Sorry to say, but I guess the government of Nauru, along with the Indonesian people smugglers, are hoping and praying a Left dominated ALP can win back government in this country.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Katharine is spot on - now for the aftermath of his TURC appearance. He will be scrambling to regain authority over an increasingly impatient Labor left who would dearly love to have their man (or woman) in there as would 60%+ of Labor members.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Would be good if the Guardian can obtain and put up the cost benefit analysis vs environmental impact report on this mine including the safeguards and policing of those safeguards built into the proposal.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Having mega profitable banks is one thing but on the other hand if it is at the expense of ordinary Australians then more stringent banking regulations need to be implemented.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The time has arrived for all those thousands of Greek citizens who have squirrelled away billions of un-taxed euros in Swiss bank accounts to come to the rescue of their nation.

text: Nice try Daisy. O'Conner was smashed by Leigh Sales.If anyone had any doubts about Shorten before the interview they are left in no doubt now - Shorten will never be a PM of Australia and the funny thing is - half the Labor a Party agree.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Ahh..the good old Labor tactic...try to destroy the credibility of anyone they deem opposes them. This time lets all attack the RC Commissioner...that's certain to save Bill from his looming knifing.
author: TimOfAltona

text: If I were an impartial observer of that interview I would come away with a strong impression that Shorten was caught out badly today if nothing else because of O'Conners obvious obfuscation.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Right here is the problem with the Labor cheer squad - unable to comprehend or understand that Labor were thrown out of government for very valid reasons and also thrown out because of a democratic election - calling the election illegal or invalid reflects denial and desperation.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Leigh Sales nailed O'Conner. He was obfuscating and dancing around the question....all the while trying to get the words "Tony" and "Abbott" out as many times as he could get way with hoping no one was looking at Bill Shorten's almost crash and burn appearance at the TURC.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Right here is where it all goes pear shaped for the Labor cheer squad. Their strong preference is to focus entirely on a belief that an unpopular PM will deliver them office and hope that no one notices that Labor have actually done little or nothing about reforming their own party since the collapse of Sept 2013.
author: TimOfAltona

text: 3. Relationship with the Greens. Their love-hate association with the Greens is crippling the party. Either they are in bed or they are out of bed with the Greens. Too many in Labor want it both ways and it shows. The big question is can Labor ever hope to return to government without relying on the Greens to get them over the line? Awkward question I know, but it bears thinking about.
author: TimOfAltona

text: 4. Too many ex-Union hacks treating the senate like it's a right of passage or a reward for services to the union movement....ditto the lower house. The hapless Shorten is a shining example. Unions represent a fraction of the Australian workforce. Eureka stockade happened a bloody long time ago and is no longer relevant to a new generation of voters.
author: TimOfAltona

text: 5. Admit the Gillard experiment was a mistake for the Labor Party. It backfired so spectacularly that if Gillard had not been replaced at the last moment, Labor would be lucky to have 30 seats in the lower house. It was a disastrous period in the history of the ALP and an admission they got it wrong will go a long way towards regaining some kind of credibility in the eyes of voters.
author: TimOfAltona

text: 6. Stop shooting the messenger. Media bashing is a popular pastime in Labor land. The majority of media/journos report it as they see it. If Labor were good enough at what they are supposed to be doing it will be positively reflected in the media. The ALP have generated enough shooting themselves in the foot ammunition to last a lifetime. This can be remedied by correctly addressing point 1 above.
author: TimOfAltona

text: 7. Stop the boats. No other issue is likely to tear apart the ALP and keep them out of government than this.If the left get their way they can kiss goodbye to any hope of returning to government. Majority of voters are rock solid behind the government's success in this area and any hint that a Labor government will restart the maritime people smuggling operation, the associated drownings at sea and the detention centres being filled up again with men, women and children ensures Labor a very very long occupancy on the opposition benches.
author: TimOfAltona

text: For those crying foul that Q&A is starting to move from the left back to the centre - rest assured that the composition of the live studio audience which is regularly 40% Conservative voters and 60% Labor/Greens voters ensures the left will be heard the loudest.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The same bloke who squibbed it when he knew he had not a snow balls chance in hell of retaining his seat, such was the public rage against him for supporting the toxic Gillard government?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Fat lot of good they did for the car manufacturing industry. Pushed Australian labour rates so high the manufacturers had to exit the country and head up to Asia. - despite successive governments throwing hundreds of millions of tax payer dollars at the industry to try and keep it afloat here.
author: TimOfAltona

text: All at each others throats over leadership.....factions trying to dominate the other...Labor lost their way during the toxic Rudd/Gillard/Rudd years and are still thrashing around in the political wilderness.
author: TimOfAltona

text: That's about the only way they can rid of him....I think Shorten will do the honourable thing and step down, but that's where it gets interesting.....the factions will be at war with each other over who replaced him. Popcorn.

text: What possible benefit can it be to the state to drop tens of millions of dollars in productivity and increase operating costs by millions of dollars for employers (large and small businesses) who have to open their doors?

text: Albo is a rough and tumble, take no prisoners, street fighter kind of pollie - pretty much what Labor needs right now if it has any hope of moving forward.

text: I give you that. Shorten a gentleman, however in the rough and tumble of Canberra politics, Labor need a real fighter to dig themselves out of the hole created by the Rudd/Gillard/Rudd years - Shorten is too placid.

text: Yep, to protect union members from unscrupulous union bosses and practices also to determine if any union officials in any way personally benefited from EBA's to the detriment of members.

text: If Shorten survives an anticipated leadership challenge and takes the ALP to the next election, how much material does the government have at its disposal to use during the campaign - bucket loads!

text: I see that old doyen of the Left, David Marr sitting up the back there trying to work out what spin he can conjure up for his next column. It must be painful indeed for him to see a Labor leader taken apart piece by piece in such a public forum.

text: This RC is evidence that Australian workers and especially those belonging to trade unions never had a better friend than in the current government to look out for their best interests IMHO.

text: Insiders with Barrie Cassidy7.30 with Leigh SalesThe Drum on ABC News 24Capitol Hill on ABC News 24Multiple interviews. Week on ABC News 24Pretty much every ABC radio station each day

text: Speculation that this could be the final nail in Shorten's internal leadership battle is not beyond comprehension. He is floundering on the subject of accepting undisclosed personal benefits in return for settling an EBA. This point needs to be further canvassed and determined. Let's hope Stoljer can get to the bottom of that, one way or the other.
author: TimOfAltona

text: RC revelations aside, Shorten came to the leadership with all sorts of heavy baggage from previous years...rape allegations, knifing of two sitting Labor PMs' (played out recently on The Killing Season), the ALP membership did not want him in the first place, his personal links to John Roskam and the list goes on.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Come back to us with how many years of a Rudd/Gillard/Rudd government we have just had to endure....if there were grounds for one a RC don't you think one would have been established in those 6 looooong years.

text: Plenty of questions remain and new allegations have surfaced. Don't worry it is not only the AWU and other unions under the microscope, plenty of employers may have acted inappropriately as well. Best everything is exposed so that illegal or unethical practices can be addressed and remedied.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I'm with you - the last thing we want is any transparency or focus on alleged corrupt activity surrounding the union movement. We all just know unions and their executives/organisers are all squeaky clean, so what is the point of a Royal Commission?

text: Why? Well can someone get back to us and list, apart from the obvious hapless Bill Shorten, how many Labor members in both the lower and upper house are ex-union hacks?

text: A mystery as to why so many people are obsessed and hot and bothered over the Q&A show - if the Labor/Greens cheer squad stopped talking about it and keeping it alive the whole thing will just go away.

text: Seems it is for plenty of your cohorts in the thread, all jumping up and down as if the world is about to end over the question of Turnbull's appearance on Q&A.
author: TimOfAltona

text: There are bigger issues on the national agenda right now and the big question is Labor's ability to respond and mount a credible opposition. So far things are not looking too good for Labor so expect to see a turnaround in the polls over the next few months IMHO.
author: TimOfAltona

text: This is where it all goes horribly pear shaped for the Labor cheer squad. Given the dysfunction in the Labor camp, all Labor supporters have left is the hope an unpopular PM can deliver them up government.
author: TimOfAltona

text: People like Chippendale need to stop focusing 100% on Tony Abbott and start looking at how Labor can reform and rebuild a shattered party after the doom and gloom of the Rudd/Gillard/Rudd years.

text: Very amusing photo halfway down the story - a stunned looking Labor/Greens cheer squad member can't believe his luck when he bumps into the PM in the fruit and veggie aisle in Wolli Creek Woolies.

text: There are always plenty of 'gotcha' moments for any government minister attending the Q & A panel, that said,Marles was asked a very direct and specific question by Tony Jones on boat turn backs and he floundered badly.

text: Labor are all at sea with their maritime border protection policy - it's either sink or swim and it appears they will not be the only ones drowning if the Labor Left get their way.

text: Larissa Waters confirmed why the Greens are unlikely to ever get any more than just the one seat in the Lower House. She certainly gave the maritime people smugglers some hope that they can start up their deadly trade again, but beyond that all she did was confirm why the Greens will never be trusted with border protection - ever.

text: If you are about to go to Greece, take plenty of Euros with you - the left wing Greek government have destroyed the nation's economy - rings a bell here as well. There is no truth to the rumour that Swanny has been consulting to the Greek government.

text: She certainly articulated how the Greens immigration policy would allow the maritime people smugglers operation to thrive. The Greens and Labor left lost this argument in the court of public opinion ages ago - not sure why they are so intent on alienating themselves from mainstream Australia.

text: Any sign that the Labor left prevail with an anti-turn back policy will have the people smugglers rubbing their vile little hands together with glee and hoping and praying a Labor/Greens government can win the next election so they can restart their deadly trade.

text: There are mountains of scientific/expert opinion and advice on global warming and it needs to be acted on - half hearted attempts or window dressing no longer cut it.

text: If you do, then it's all in the timing for Turnbull...this Q & A issue is not a hill to die on and will blow away in good time.

text: I'm with you...very important that only Labor & the Greens get to be heard on Q&A...last thing we want to hear is anything from coming from our elected government.

text: In fact, if we all stand up, put our fingers in our ears, stomp up and down and belt out a few robust choruses from that chart topping hit "Solidarity Forever" maybe they will just go away. Just a thought.

text: The ban appears to be restricted only to front benchers. There are plenty of talented men and women on the government backbench worth a look in on Q&A. Won't do their profile any harm at all.
author: TimOfAltona

text: For those of you attacking Turnbull for not standing up to the PM, there are plenty of you, get real and recognise that no politician has ever advanced their career by publicly going head to head with the party leader (unless it is a leadership challenge situation), all they do pretty much is sacrifice their career to make a point.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Those of you wanting to see Turnbull as next PM wil recognise that everything is in the timing from here on in. If the polls do not improve for either the government or more importantly for the PM, the numbers will soon be there and the door will open for a successful Turnbull challenge.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Seems most of the Labor/Greens cheer squad are more than happy however to see Turnbull, who represents the greatest threat to a Labor/Greens government returning, fall on his sword over the Q&A issue.

text: Until this issue blows over, a good opportunity for some of the talented LNP back benchers to get some good exposure and raise their profile both nationally and within their own electorates.

text: So toxic is Gillard in Australia, that her opinion and credibility on just about any topic, however noble the subject, is in the gutter and attracts copious amounts of derision and ridicule.

text: The Killing Season on the ABC bore some of this out, where she was horribly exposed as the architect of the downfall of the contemporary day Labor Party and still has the temerity to apportion all the blame onto Kevin Rudd.

text: One thing is certain - if the ALP through their national conference start sending out signals that their policies will restart the maritime people smuggling operation between Indonesia and Australia then they can confidently prepare for multiple terms in opposition.

text: Perhaps we should ask Penny Wong's country of birth, Malaysia, how they regard gay marriage and when we can expect to see Malaysia legislate to allow same sex marriages?

text: I hope the Brits are paying for this visit and not the Australian tax payer. The costs associated with such visits normally run into the millions - it's not like they (Prince Charles & Camilla) are doing anything useful for the country when they decide to visit Australia IMHO.

text: C'mon all you sour pusses out there, show some support for 20 yr old Nick and get behind him - he's doing a great job and is very likely Australia's next big (only) tennis champion.

text: He did not bounce it into the crowd intentionally, it was a fluke. Plenty of players bounce their racquet and catch it. He'll probably think twice about doing it again in the future though.

text: You have to be seriously concerned for all these Labor/Greens cheer squad members who are fixated on Tony Abbott and what happens to them when he is no longer PM or LNP leader?

text: Presumably the ones who hide behind a 'Tony Abbott-type' name or avatar will swap it to something resembling the name or likeness of whoever replaces Tony and so it starts all over again.

text: Abbott is highly intelligent observes politically savvy Katharine Murphy and in addition I suggest Abbott is certainly the more politically savvy compared to Shorten and for that reason will endure way beyond Shorten's rapidly floundering tenure as ALP leader.

text: There is a valid reason why that is so...Labor, particularly with Shorten as leader, are simply not up to the job and can't be trusted. Australians can see that.

text: The Labor cheer squad know full well their man is not up to the task, never has been really, which means they are relying on Abbott's perceived unpopularity alone to deliver what they crave.

text: I suspect also deep down they know that the chances of the LNP being returned are very high...simply because the ALP, even with the obligatory leg up from the Greens, are just not ready to govern and won't be for some years to come.

text: You keep saying that but the reality is Labor are just not up to the job. Sitting back and hoping that the LNP are voted out as opposed to the ALP/Greens being voted in is delusional. Labor are totally unconvincing for a multitude of reasons. The LNP will be returned with or without T.Abbot as leader.

text: If it was not for corrupt governments, military and civilian, siphoning off billions of oil dollars over the years, Nigeria would have the most advanced and prosperous economy in Africa.

text: You guys are kidding yourself, it does not work that way. It is not awarded by a public vote - a recipient only needs to be nominated once - a committee then evaluates the nominees.

text: I have been critical of some aspects of Gillian Triggs activity in the past, that said, providing the Republican movement do not have a breakthrough over the next few years I think she would make an admirable state governor or even governor general one day - presumably would only occur under an ALP government though.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You only have to look at pretty much any Guardian thread and they are littered with grubby, vile and offensive comments directed at Peta Credlin, Julie Bishop, Bronwyn Bishop and recently Sophie Mirabella. Sadly Abbott's wife and daughters have been targeted by the left as well.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Sadly many regular 'contributors' are serial offenders and often 'justify' their sexist & offensive remarks by saying that Gillard copped heaps, so this is their form of 'payback'. Again, sadly many have taken it too far.

text: No, it's clearly wrong. Both parties have been caught up in this type of thing one way or the other over the years. The whole issue of lobbyists and political donors needs reform to avoid organised crime infiltrating Local, state or federal government.

text: Thanks for your  input Jed, however I'd prefer echoniner to respond. He/she was passionate about changing the leader but did not offer anyone he/she thought would deliver the goods.

text: Nothing to do with misogyny, that was a concocted ploy by John McTernan to try and win a floundering Gillard an improvement in polling results, it's about competency and Labor are almost void of people on their front bench who are up to the task of forming government, Plibersek included.

text: Here's the thing - the majority of those crossing the Med are economic migrants - looking for a better life than they currently enjoy in their own countries...they need to be stopped forthwith.

text: You write a fair comment - interesting thing is that Rudd was not really aligned with the left, or the right for that matter, so his decision to start up the people smuggling operations is a little perplexing....clearly he though he was doing the 'right thing' but as it turned out it was a total disaster costing thousands of lives and one which will haunt Labor for a generation.

text: Many European countries are looking longingly at Australia and wishing their governments had the foresight and fortitude to shut down the people smugglers by disrupting their business model earlier in the piece. If the left get their way and propose opening up the people smuggling industry again which by definition means the detention centres will start filling up again and overflowing and the mass drownings start up they will be out of office for at least another 2 or 3 terms, maybe longer.

text: If Abbott survives until late next year and goes on to win, I'll be as surprised as anyone else - but you'd have to have nothing but respect for the guy if he can pull it off given all the shit thats been flying around over the past 18 months.

text: Did I read somewhere that Plibersek is 'representing' the government? text: Never mind Ian - you are one of only two regular posters from the left whose opinion I respect in these threads. There was a third but he/she has disappeared for some reason.
