text: I did and it was a pleasure being to there to experience a resounding win to the conservatives. There are clear parallels between UK Labour and the ALP...both have weak leaders and are seen as increasingly irrelevant in the political sphere. Voters in both countries know it is conservative governments who are the better economic managers hence UK Labour were kicked out of the ball park and the same will happen again to the ALP unless they speed up their internal reform along with getting their (unelectable) leadership dysfunction sorted.
author: TimOfAltona

text: At any examination you have to say that Bronwyn Bishop is doing a great job in controlling the Labor rabble - more should be thrown out to drive the message home - carrying on like recalcitrant primary school children is not the behaviour we want to see in parliament.
author: TimOfAltona

text: If Labor are seriously looking to count themselves in the running next year, they need to modify their behaviour - it will take a lot more than Greens preferences for them to get over the line.
author: TimOfAltona

text: No, the context was about successful female state leaders of the Labor Party. I was just pointing out that Kirner, Bligh and Kenneally were anything but successful for Labor, in fact the reverse and I threw Gillard into the mix for good measure.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Mate, seriously, it's time to give up on this anti-media crusade of yours. It's getting boring beyond belief with dozens of daily posts about media conspiracies and going on for months and months now and I reckon there are a fair few Labor supporters who would agree with me.
author: TimOfAltona

text: No idea Daisy - depends on whether it is any good or not - let's keep our eyes peeled and see if we can spot Abbott applauding Shorten's speech.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Given what happened to the first 3 I would not try and claim this as any kind of Labor positive...the first 3 were absolute disasters for Labor in the end (along with Gillard). The jury is still out on the 4th.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Touchy touchy Michael. We all recognise and acknowledge that Shorten has a predilection towards zingers - in fact he is renowned for it on a daily basis - that fact coupled with the phrase 'a most excellent school' has nothing whatsoever to do with what you are pushing.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Back on Budget night in the chamber - could not help but notice that Bill Shorten was applauding Hockey after the budget speech - clapping his hands along with the government members and those up in the public gallery.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Interesting - perhaps it's the 'done thing' for the LOTTO to congratulate the Treasurer on his budget delivery speech or perhaps he was just in agreement that it was a bloody good budget.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I see the Abbott budget has got you a bit rattled...I'm with you though, thousands of more votes going to the LNP from the tens of thousands of tradies out there who know a good deal when they see one.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The NBN was Labor's great folly - all pre-election smoke and mirrors hidden in reports buried somewhere on Albo's desk - never did lay his hands on those reports before the election did he?
author: TimOfAltona

text: As an aside...what's the betting like on Albo/Plibersek and the left making a move on Shorten and the right? Betting money at the moment is on Plibbers sharpening the knives in the Labor party room silverware drawer. I could not think of a greater gift to the LNP if the hapless Plibersek gets the gig- a very weak performer in parliament....Albo on the other hand would be a greater challenge IMHO.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Good delivery by Hockey at the Press Club lunch - one of his better addresses in some time. At times he appears washed out and tired...looks like he has good energy today off the back of a increasingly well recieved budget. All good.
author: TimOfAltona

text: 'This is an unfair budget' they squawk....'last year's was unfair but this year it's even unfairer..how dare this conservative government hand down a budget that is straight out an ALP government copybook...I mean...it's so fair that it's unfair because it makes the government look like they have moved back towards the centre and that means a certain victory for the LNP up against our weak, dysfunctional and insipid(leadership) Labor party next year...even Greens preferences won't save us ' they moan despairingly.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Good to see a tick of approval from this cartoonist fellow. See, life ain't that bad under a Liberal government.....might even do some good if those damn recalcitrant Greens didn't keep blocking everything in the senate.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Looks like Hockey's budget has the Labor cheer squad well and truly rattled....clearly this budget will be pretty well received throughout the community...particularly small business, farmers, parents and pensioners. Labor supporters were hoping for more of the same from last year and they have been bitterly disappointed.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Well we all fondly remember who was writing all Julia Gillard's stuff don't we Daisy? Went on for over a year. No wonder she crashed and burned so spectacularly in the end.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Crap - it's happening all over the world..not just in Australia. Just this year look at France, look at the UK, look the USA, look at Belgium, look at the Netherlands, look at Germany, look at Malaysia..the list goes on. Muslim youth are being radicalised via social media and internet around the planet...nothing to do what political leaders in Australia may have said. Political leaders in all these countries speak out against terror acts, the causes and possible solutions.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Bill Kelty and Paul Keating in case you did not know - all Shorten did was parrot their words - as I said Labor have all sorts of problems ahead with Shorten there.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Daisy, Daisy, Daisy - I think you know I have plenty of positive things to say about my own side - it's just that Shorten is getting weaker and weaker as each day goes by and I could not rely on any of you to point that fact out, now could I?
author: TimOfAltona

text: As in Australia, bitter and twisted Labour/Labor supporters want to point the finger of blame at everyone else for their stunning respective defeats without confronting the reality of the situation - if their own party was good enough and up to it when it comes to leadership, vision and policies that mainstream voters can relate to, then victory is there for the taking.
author: TimOfAltona

text: There is enough social media spinning around to counter any other media pushing for one party or the other. In both countries Murdoch has backed Labour in the past when he thought they were up to it.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Surprising as it may sound and given the relatively vacuous state the ALP are in, I would like to see Abbott or his successor sit down with Di Natale and have a frank discussion on where the country is heading and how it may look in 20, 30 or even 50 years time.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The Greens can bring some constructive dialogue to the table and sure, they won't get a lot of what they want in the short to medium term but only good can come from opening dialogue and sharing ideas and proposed solutions - small steps and ultimately, irrespective of ideology differences, we are all working towards protecting and improving on what makes Australia great now and for future generations.
author: TimOfAltona

text: It's how we manage the economic, social and environmental challenges along the way that is contentious. Negotiation and reasonable compromise is the key to success, particularly in the senate.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Perhaps improved collaboration between the Greens & the LNP will see a less fractured & poisonous political landscape emerge and given the events of the past 8 years or so, that is not such a bad thing.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Shorten hoping he can just glide into Kirribilli House propped up by Green preferences & off the back of a Liberal Party leader even more unpopular than himself is delusional.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You get the distinct feeling things are getting back on track for the government. The electorate can smell the factional dysfunction and obvious weaknesses in the Labor camp...not ready to govern for quite a few years yet - at least not until they jettison Shorten and sort out if it's the left or the right running the show.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I'm with you, it's high time those people who perpetrated those atrocities in colonial Australia in the 19th century are tracked down and brought before the courts as soon as possible. The death sentence should be applied where it is applicable.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The refugees can stay there as long as they like - particularly so if they are Muslim. The difference between the two countries is that in Australia they go on welfare and in Indonesia there is no welfare for them, they have to live off existing savings or find jobs or go home.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The government are not sending them back to Iraq etc etc - they are being returned to where they came from, Indonesia. They are perfectly safe there as they would be had they come to Australia - just without the welfare support.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Marles also said in the same Sky interview, omitted by the journo here, that labor will do everything possible to prevent boats departing Java again, including regional processing...hmmmmm...sounds like an endorsement of the governments policies.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You must be confused - there are no rapes, torture, executions,imprisonment and disappearances of those waiting in Indonesia to get on people smuggler boats to come to Australia.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Well Marles would say that wouldn't he, this from the man who presided for a time where Australia completely lost control of our borders coupled with the mass drownings that accompanied that dark period in Australia's history.
author: TimOfAltona

text: When Abbott arrived in Paris he was travelling solo, protocol dictates that the Australian Ambassador therefore meets and greets the PM at the airport solo. Had Margie been with Abbott then the Ambassadors partner, male or female, will accompany the Ambassador at the airport greeting.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Did the article also report that Abbott had dinner hat night with the Ambassador and his partner in Paris just as they had done back in Australia before Abbott went to Europe?
author: TimOfAltona

text: This story is misleading...why did the journo not also report that Marles also said in the interview that if Labor were in power they would likewise do everything possible to stop boats departing Java and that the regional processing centres in PNG and Nauru were Labor's initiative which has worked and not the governments.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Yeah right, there has been infighting going on for months, primarily around leadership.Looks like the anti-Milne camp have succeeded. Anyone who resigns to "spend more time with their family" is a metaphor for you know what.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Labor will be watching this with keen interest to see who will be leading their coalition partner into next years election. Hard to pick between the top 3 contenders but more likely it will be a male.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Good to see the previous government left the states finances in good shape with a healthy surplus. Now watch labor wreck the joint just as they did when they took over federally from Howard.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Good outcome. The left hate this kind of story as it shows the government's election promise is being upheld. Encouraging people to get on leaky boats to reach Australia is cruel and often leads to mass drownings.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I see the Labor/Greens cheer squad are getting a tad nervous - the last thing they want right now, on top of the looming Labor factional leadership wars, is for the government to hand down a budget which is perceived to be fair and reasonable compared to the last one and considering the fall in commodity prices is a pretty good effort to try and keep the economy moving.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The house is in perfect order...there is a PM regaining popularity and a very popular successor if Abbott goes. It's all over for Labor for another two terms at least if Turnbull takes the government into the next election particularly as Labor's factional wars come to the surface in coming weeks. All good.
author: TimOfAltona

text: When will the Labor/Greens cheer squad wake up to the fact that Shorten is unelectable.....not only do the conservative and Greens voters not want him, half or more of his own party don't want him as leader.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Labor are still in a rebuilding phase and have made little progress since the disasters of the Rudd/Gillard/Rudd years. You need to sort out the leadership dysfunction first...I think everyone knows that Albo is the only credible leader who can take Labor forward and give them a fighting chance in 2019.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The Rudd experiment on this issue was a dismal failure - that we know...if Shorten proposes to soften the current policy which gives the people smugglers their business model back - all hell will break loose...and is certain to keep the Labor/Greens coalition on the opposition benches for years and years to come.
author: TimOfAltona

text: There is a way to stop the thousands of deaths at sea in the Mediterranean - stop the boats departing Nth Africa by shutting down the people smugglers . Try it - it works.
author: TimOfAltona

text: These boys, thinking the risk was worth it, knowingly and willingly played with fire and ended up getting horribly burnt. They are the ones ultimately to blame for this outcome, sad as it is.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Actually defence is an area where massive savings can be made - ditch the submarines I say - I cannot see how Australia maintaining a naval submarine fleet benefits the country?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Perhaps it was their addiction to borrowing coupled with dysfunctional leadership over the 6 years that distracted Labor from addressing the much needed Australian tax reform...either that or were they were just protecting the top 10%?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Perhaps if Labor chose a policy they have some semblance of achieving it may look good on their score card but this is nothing but rhetoric, complete and utter rubbish, waste of time and zero will come of it - I think we all recognise that from the outset. Political opportunism pure and simple.
author: TimOfAltona

text: So the ALP are about to embark on a crusade to wipe out the death penalty around the globe - hmmmm let's see, that would be China, about 20 states in the USA, Vietnam, Singapore, Malaysia, Japan, Indonesia, Egypt, India plus another 17 odd countries all of whom are still executing people who break certain laws, primarily for murder.
author: TimOfAltona

text: A little bit of trivia - of the roughly 35,000 McDonalds restaurants around the globe, only two in the world are housed in original stand alone art deco buildings - one is in Napier, the other in Melbourne Australia.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Shut em down I say - if they can't be self sufficient then time to withdraw taxpayer support and allow these people to move into larger communities where sufficient services and infrastructure exist and also allows more opportunity to get jobs, provide education for children and better health care.
author: TimOfAltona

text: My my, so many of the Labor/Greens cheer squad are walking around with massive chips on their shoulders it seems - here's a tip pal, we don't think Labor are to blame for everything - just some things. This particular issue occurred when Labor were in govt, but it is not necessarily their 'fault'. ASIO operate within the legislation/guidelines of the day and there is clearly more to this story.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You are right but I suspect that in a matter of only 3 or 4 weeks the events of the past 24 hrs will be distant memory and we all move on, including tens of thousands of Australians booking their flights and hotels for holidays in Bali.
author: TimOfAltona

text: There were many players in this drama of which a number hold some degree of responsibility for the final outcome - none more so than the two men themselves.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Congratulations, you managed to cover roughly 12 separate issues ranging from beef exports to Antarctic bases to Knighthoods in your rant on a story about the execution of the two Australians.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Actually I think you will be wrong - Labor are in no condition to form government - even in partnership with the Greens - The LNP will be returned, albeit with reduced number of seats in the lower house.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Should it not be incumbent upon this UN person to also speak with WA or federal government representatives and receive both sides of the story before releasing a public statement?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Australia cannot continue to provide unlimited welfare for people who choose to remain in tiny remote communities where there are no jobs, no schools, few medical facilities, no infrastructure and zero hope for the future apart from living off state and federal government handouts.
author: TimOfAltona

text: At some point people have to start taking responsibility for their own futures and not expect the government to keep throwing tax payer money at them to maintain their desire to live in unsustainable remote areas.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Indonesian public opinion favours executing criminals for drug crimes....Widodo went to the election on a promise of being tough on drug criminals - he won't back down for fear of being deemed weak.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I was in Place de la Rpublique in Paris a couple of days ago where there was a very large public demonstration, similar to the ones we saw in Australia for Chan and Sukumaran, against the imminent execution of Frenchman Serge Atlaoui but interestingly there were also photos of Chan and Sukumaran being held up in the crowd......Atlaoui appears to have a legitimate alibi which may reverse his execution sentence and a few hours later we hear he will not be executed pending another appeal......a glimmer of hope that at least 1 of these 10 will not be executed.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Only if you work for a large public media organisation and on ANZAC day very publicly accuse deceased Australian soldiers as being murderers and rapists - other than that I think you are fairly safe.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Right here is the problem with so many people making comments in these threads, they say anything and make things up as they go along to try and prosecute their case.
author: TimOfAltona

text: He breached the conduct code of the organisation he was employed by.....there have to be consequences and there were. He exercised his right to make offensive comments the consequences of which meant his employment was terminated.
author: TimOfAltona

text: It's called Freedom of Speech comrade. Wanting to shut down views expressed by the right and only hear views expressed by the left has already been experimented with in Cuba and Venezuela - things have not turned out too well in either of those two countries IMHO.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You seem to be confused over this issue - when you work for a large public organisation you are required to sign and agree to a code of conduct as a condition of your continued employment. When you breech that conduct code and go on to deliberately flout the code of conduct despite warnings - there are consequences.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You are absolutely correct - he is entitled to his opinions as are you or I - however when you are a reasonably high profile media identity working for a large public broadcasting entity, choosing to call deceased Australian troops on Anzac Day, murderers and rapists will have it's consequences.....and not unreasonably so.
author: TimOfAltona

text: He is an intelligent fellow who must feel very strongly about this issue in that he was prepared to throw himself under the proverbial bus to express his views....or maybe not.
author: TimOfAltona

text: After reading McIntyre's comments you have to ask the question - did he really think he would have kept his job in a major public media organisation after tweeting those offensive remarks - on ANZAC day of all days?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Those of the left may be happy to see the offshore detention centres continue to operate whilst the LNP are in government, but I suspect the LNP will achieve what Howard did when he was in government - close them down.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Well of course they would, but your argument is a nonsense because we don't have these boats crashing into rocks on our shoreline anymore because the government have shut down the people smuggler operations. Everyone wins.
author: TimOfAltona

text: A very good thing these kind of events, think Christmas Island here, are a thing of the past since Labor and the Greens were booted out of government in Australia in 2013.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The left don't like it or a whole number of reasons......... and I would never suggest that the left condone people drowning at sea...however I do look forward to the day when someone from the Labor/Greens cheer squad concedes that it is a good thing that we have effectively stopped the mass drownings occurring in the seas between SE Asia and Australia because the people smugglers business model has been disrupted and boats are no longer leaving in their hundreds each month bound for Australia.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Anybody would think, reading comments in this thread, that Sydney has never experienced heavy hail before and you would also think that, according to the cheer squad for Labor and the Greens, that this event is god's punishment for us voting in a conservative government.
author: TimOfAltona

text: It follows that if a Labor/Greens government were still in power this event would have happened because Tony Abbott is destroying the planet with severe weather events never seen before in the past 200 years.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I am in Paris currently, and I would dearly love to invite the Australian Labor/Greens cheer squad members so indignant and damning of the Australian government policy on immigration to take a walk with me through some of the migrant suburbs (ghettos) here in Paris where even the police are highly cautious about entering.The result of  migration, most of it from Africa. (albeit France allows people from former French colonies to join relatives in France)  You feel for these people...but what a disaster for the economic and social cohesion of many French urban areas where migration is out of control. Lessons indeed for Australia.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You need a reality check pal. migration from Africa to Europe cannot continue without serious negative social and economic consequences, starting with thousands of people drowning in the oceans along the way.
author: TimOfAltona

text: What a sensationalist and misleading headline. David Marr employing a little poetic licence perhaps? I don't see anywhere where Farage says Tony Abbott is too tough on immigration. He in fact says the opposite and has praised Abbott for showing European leaders how to deal with the boats from Africa.
author: TimOfAltona

text: That may be so - have not seen any data around that supports your claim, but my point is attempting to link Australia's teen suicide rate with detention of asylum seekers is a nonsense.... NZ has a far higher rate of teenage suicide per head of population than Australia and NZ don't even have asylum seeker families in detention. The two issues, whilst complex, are entirely separate.
author: TimOfAltona

text: errr...not really. Thankfully, Australia is quite a way down the list..........NZ is way ahead of Australia as are many other 'western' countries. Attempting to link these two subjects is meaningless.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Yes, pave the way and encourage tens of thousands more to try and make the voyage by sea and send hundreds or thousands more to their death by drowning.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The last Labor/Greens government in Australia gave the insidious people smugglers a working business model with the same results we are seeing in the Mediterranean ie: people drowning in their thousands.
author: TimOfAltona

text: So far all that has happened is the Dept of Immigration have followed the rules regarding this situation. It is now up to the minister/government to overrule the immigration rules for this case or have it enforced.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Julian Burnside completely ignores the fact that thousands of people have paid with their lives by drowning en route at the hands of people smugglers....what about all these dead men, women and children Burnside...don't they figure in your 'open borders, we should take all comers' utopia?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Well, I for one am proud that Australia has largely shut down the insidious people smuggler trade in this part of the world and quite possibly saved thousands of lives in doing so.
author: TimOfAltona

text: No one likes to see or hear of Australian politicians being investigated for possible criminal acts/activity. Reflects badly on the party, the ALP in this case, and does nothing for the standing of politicians overall.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I'm with you, we would not want any good to come out of this in case it makes Abbott look good. Let's all hope it is a disaster so we can keep on manufacturing hatred towards Abbott.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You goose, why would the PM of Australia visiting Turkey not meet with his counterpart to discuss items of mutual interest to both nations? Your problem I suspect is that you only want to see a Labor PM meeting with the Turkish PM.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I've notice some commentators in the last couple of days trying to lay the blame for what's happening in the Mediterranean on Tony Abbott. Claiming that he has not stopped the boats due to people drowning in their thousands off the coast of North Africa.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Oh the irony....I think you will find the government will be the first signatory on the petition. No one, including the government want these places operating, hence they are being emptied out as soon as is practicable....only a matter of time and you won't be needing anymore petitions - they will be closed - just like when Howard sorted this out when he was PM.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Grubby comments directed at a person's appearance or clothing are best left out of these threads, hence the story is not open for comments...the issue is the good work Bishop is doing in Iran, not what she happens to wear which seems to be the main focus of attention for the Labor/Greens cheer squad IMHO.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The article is about thousands of men, women and children drowning at sea and all you want to do is encourage more people onto people smuggler boats to try and make the journey. No wonder your side of politics got thrashed and booted out at the last federal election in Australia.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Like so many other apologists for the people smugglers you go into hiding when hundreds of men, women and children drown at sea because you would rather they keep coming just to be able to say Abbott's policies have failed.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Southern Europe need to take a look at the successful Australian model for taking back control of your borders, shutting down the people smuggling operations and preventing wholesale drownings at sea.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Funny thing is while they are carrying on blindly attacking Ley for fear this makes the government look good, there is a sentence in the article that goes something like this.....
author: TimOfAltona

text: This begs the question - where are UNICEF when dozens of children are drowning at sea after being lured to Australia on people smuggler boats. Where are the UNICEF condemnation of boats departing Indonesia for Australia and where is UNICEF's praise for the Abbott government in preventing the hundreds or perhaps thousands of deaths at sea.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Also, there is nothing that shows the interests or well being of the children and their parents are compromised by going to Cambodia - sounds like Cambodia is immeasurably better than the processing centre in Nauru.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Proud moment for Julie Bishop and Australia....playing on the world stage with the big boys...Kevin Rudd must be green with envy. Bishop has been impressive with her forays into global events and it's easy to see why she is a contender for leadership of the Liberal Party.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Clearly the left feel threatened by such a strong and intelligent woman who is on the conservative side of politics - largely I suspect because their side lacks any female with the calibre of Julie Bishop...Penny Wong probably comes the closest after that the cupboard is bare. Herein lies the problem for the ALP - almost zero depth of talent in their ranks apart from perhaps 5 individuals and only one of those is a female.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Bishop is shining on the world stage and good on her......your bitterness over losing the 2013 election is on display for all to see. Clearly strong and intelligent conservative women present a clear and present danger for you.....time to pull your head in and acknowledge that Julie Bishop has done a great job as Australia's FM - all you can do is attack the clothes she wears...you were quick to demonise people who criticised Julia Gillard's dress sense and here you are doing exactly the same thing against Bishop?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Nobody wins out of that - in fact people get injured and it was a good thing BNE was spared that - as much as the socialist left would have enjoyed the prospect of street battles with the police.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Daisy, I really think it's time you pulled your head in on trying to vilify Abbott over the action he is taking on tackling domestic violence - this is above politics, yet you persist in trying to find an angle to try and attack Abbott over this....listen to Daniel Andrews comments this afternoon, he praised Abbott for his leadership over this issue.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I had not realised until this thread that Rudd is not exactly the poster boy for the Labor cheer squad.....didn't he save some of the furniture for you guys in the 2013 election?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Rudd was always going to chase this dream of his to lead the UN.....holding onto the Australian Prime Ministership was the perfect lobbying stepping stone/platform for him to land the top gig at the UN....then disaster struck for him when he lost the 2013 election.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Helen Clarke (former Labour PM of NZ) was probably well ahead of Rudd in the pecking for the top job anyway. Don't discount that Clarke could well be the first female UN Secretary General.
author: TimOfAltona

text: So, a poster boy for the refugee advocate groups and the Greens who are actively trying to stop people being sent to Nauru is  to put on a show for the asylum seekers the detention centre???
author: TimOfAltona

text: Chances of a change back to a Labor/Greens government unlikely though - the success of the government's asylum seeker policy and stopping the boats is, on it's own, enough to return the current government IMHO.
author: TimOfAltona

text: All boats are either pushed back, towed back or occupants transferred to other boats and returned to Indonesia - people can't reach Australia by boat and if they do, they are transferred to detention centres in other countries in the region - they never get to Australia.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Australia has dealt with this issue by denying the people smugglers a viable business model so the customers have stopped handing over money and the asylum seeker boats have stopped departing Indonesia.
author: TimOfAltona

text: There is already a regional solution in place under the current government and it has done the job - no more boats arriving in Australia and no more drownings at sea. Soon it will also see no more offshore processing centres as well. Everyone wins.
author: TimOfAltona

text: My understanding of a Royal Commission is it needs to be initiated by the government of the day so as the LNP and Labor are as one with this it will never happen.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Morrison and Dutton are to be congratulated and will be at the ballot box in next years federal election which I suspect is really at the crux of your displeasure over this. .
author: TimOfAltona

text: Giving asylum seekers who arrive by boat residency in Australia provides the people smugglers with the perfect business model - like the one Labor and the Greens gave them a few years ago. Result - hundreds of people smuggler boats departing Indonesia carrying thousands of asylum seekers with 1000+ drowning along the way.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You may be a bit confused about this.....the Australian troops are not going to Iraq to fight anyone..they are going on a mission to assist train Iraqi army recruits in how to defend the country against IS insurgents. There is a big difference. Read the article again.
author: TimOfAltona

text: It's time the left stopped blaming the media for the inadequacies of their party - time to face up to the fact that the ALP and their Greens partners are in no state to govern the country.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Stop blaming everyone else and try and work out how Labor can reform, rebuild and try and work themselves into a credible alternative government in the years ahead. Start by taking a good hard look at your leader....there is a major problem for you right there in Bill Shorten.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Glamorpig does want to hear about those things - he is on a mission to vilify the Australian government even if it means he ignores IS atrocities to achieve his aim.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Along with the UK, USA, NZ, France, Saudi Arabia, Canada, Jordan, UAE, Bahrain, and Qatar - yep they all bask in giving IS dream coverage by sending support troops.
author: TimOfAltona

text: So who is Bill Shorten hiding behind? Labor would be doing the same thing if they were in government. There is a valid reason why we are going on this training mission - presumably you want to see IS defeated? Or maybe not.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Good to see Labor backing the government on this initiative and a shame Milne is doing her usual pacifist routine even it means allowing IS to continue their genocidal rampage through Syria and Iraq.
author: TimOfAltona

text: A week is a longtime in politics....18 months is a lifetime. The polls will bounce around for Abbott, but no question if Turnbull were to take the leadership, the ALP will be be all but gone - I think the ALP focus groups have already alerted them to that fact, hence Shorten ramping up the anti- Turnbull rhetoric. (Shorten, along with the rest of the ALP know their best chance lies in Abbott holding on to the election)
author: TimOfAltona

text: If Abbott were to hang on, a lot more media scrutiny will be applied to Shorten, what he stands for, how would he perform as PM, what direction would he lead the government, what are his costed policies and where does he stand on red hot contentious issues such as stopping boats, Budget deficits, managing climate change, relationship with the Greens, union control, relationship with Labor's left faction and any past closet skeletons which may emerge.

text: You deliberately missed the point - we don't need official government reports to know what is going on at sea... there are possibly hundreds of people at the start and end of the journey that are looking out for people departing on boats......social media is a powerful medium ........

text: It is seriously only a matter of time before there are no children in offshore detention, in fact there will be noone in offshre detention and the facilities are closed down.

text: Before you reply saying how do we know it has stopped? Simple, no boat departs Indonesia without both satellite phone communication plus people both in Indonesia and friends/family/refugee advocates in Australia knowing exactly who has left on that boat....if the boat goes missing or is in distress media and SAR authorities are alerted fairly quickly. There have been no such reports of boats/people missing for a year or more. During the last Labor government boats were being reported missing almost weekly.

text: Burnside will twist this around - the people smugglers need to be shut down - Julian will no doubt argue that people smugglers have rights too and argue that they be allowed to continue their trade in transporting people who pay them to enter Australia illegally by sea outside the UNHCR program.

text: Give it a rest you are talking dribble again - the issue here is communities remaining self sufficient and sustainable without relying on tax payers dollars to fund their lifestyle. The fact they may be aboriginal is neither here nor there - they are Australians and no more entitled to a free ride through life than you or I.

text: Actually I found it refreshing not have some female ALP person on the panel attempting to turn it into a political catfight. Julie Bishop did a great job representing the female political voice, she said nothing that a female Labor politician would not have also have expressed.

text: We stand a pretty good chance of getting a seat at the HRC table..apart from the current kerfuffle, Australia has a proud history of standing up for the sanctity of life irrespective of the political party in government - like it or not Abbott's recent lobbying and public and private appeals to Widodo over Indonesian death sentencing has gained worldwide recognition and will no doubt be looked upon favourably by the HRC committee.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Apart from the people on the boat themselves, they have relatives/friends on shore monitoring their departure and awaiting their arrival in Australia who will raise the alarm, in addition there are refugee advocates along with friends and relatives in Australia aware of the journey and awaiting word of their arrival who will also raise the alarm if the boat disappears. Most of these boats have satellite phones with direct access to both Australian search and rescue and refugee advocates and even media in Australia....it is highly unlikely/improbable a boat will simply disappear and we hear nothing more about it without the alarm being raised through the media or refugee advocates.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I will have a lot more confidence in the UN when I see the UNHCR acknowledging that Australia has played a major role in preventing helpless people perishing at sea.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Take a look at what's happening between North Africa and southern Europe where there are zero border controls - hundreds of thousands trying to get to Europe by people smuggler boats and thousands perishing at sea along the way. The UN should be zeroing in on that human catastrophe.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The UN is NOT the messenger - they are the accuser based on untested allegations by people who paid people smugglers to get them to Australia and had that ripped away from them.
author: TimOfAltona

text: errr...the allegations are they were going to join IS in Iraq or Syria...I somehow suspect that would have been a little more damaging to their lives than being stopped at Sydney airport and sent home with their Mum and Dad.

text: Burying your head in the sand pretending terrorism is someone else's problem is at best delusional, at worst deadly. Still, if that thinking keeps an inept labor out of government for another 2 or 3 terms, go for it!

text: I thought at the time under the circumstances and given their ages a court appearance notice would have been a little premature - there will need to be a fairly extensive investigation into what these two were up to, if anything, before anti-terrorism charges would be laid.

text: That said, some 'material' was alleged to have been found in their possession which lead Customs to suspect they may be in contravention of Australia's Foreign Fighters legislation - presumably more information will be revealed in coming weeks and maybe charges laid.

text: As unpopular as Abbott is with the Labor/Greens cheer squad and certainly within some quarters of his own camp - didn't he do a resounding slap down of the hapless Shorten in QT last week over the Tattersalls Men Only club event.

text: I think if I were a relative of someone on board I'm pretty sure I would have come to the realisation that no one would still be alive and the plane is  in the ocean.

text: So I assume you want to to see the people smugglers have free reign to send hundreds of boats with thousands of asylum seekers to Australia - in effect letting them control our borders along with our immigration policy and possibly thousands drowning along the way (as we have seen here under the Rudd/Gillard debacles and occurring in Nth Africa today), then I would assert you are creating a massive political disadvantage, not to mention the billions of extra dollars this country will need to find because of uncontrolled borders to supply housing, health care, feeding, education and general welfare.

text: Those are the lifejackets the Australian authorities supplied them when they were intercepted. If you think people smugglers are operating some kind of pleasure cruise handing out life jackets to their customers you are terribly naive.

text: The headline to this story is misleading - the government have said no such thing - only PAC (Independent Statutory Authority) & Rio Tinto have made comment. The government is yet to respond.

text: You may be mistaken to immediately jump to the conclusion it is a NSW government decision - the PAC is an independent statutory body - not a government department.

text: This morning on Sky Graham Richardson, the doyen of the Labor Party, came out in support of Abbott raising the issue of Australia's generous disaster relief assistance being consistent with our values when it comes to opposing the death penalty...Richardson believed the PM was quite correct in raising that point.

text: The AFP were liaising with their Indonesian counterparts over catching these heroin drug runners, not the government.....in Australia there is separation of powers between the police and the state. The AFP operate independently of the government in criminal investigations.

text: I truly suspect the coalition government returned in 2016 will not look and have the same feel about it as we have at present. A new leader and some front bench rearranging along with policy adjustments will be all that's needed to keep a potentially woeful Labor/Greens government out of office for another term or two IMHO.

text: Last I looked Manus and Nauru are not staring down the barrel of a world heritage endangered listing - in any case they are territories of other sovereign nations.

text: I am no fan of Indonesia....it shits me that both Liberal and Labor governments kowtow to one of the most corrupt nations on the planet...you only have to look at past events in East Timor and what amounts to genocide perpetrated by the Indonesian government occupiers of West Papua to see that Indonesia is not the 'good neighbour' successive Labor and Liberal governments have portrayed.

text: The next round of opinion polls are critical to gauge how much longer Abbott can hold on. The nation, including many Labor/Green voters, clearly want Malcolm Turnbull to replace Abbott to steady the ship, throw out unpopular policies that have little or no prospect of getting through the current senate and get on with a more centrist good government.

text: The challenge for a Turnbull lead government is what to do with the current front bench - some ministers will be feeling a little more secure than others and then there is the issue of the National Party, however I think Turnbull has the smarts to do a deal with the Nats to keep them onside.

text: I think critically a Turnbull (PM), Julie Bishop (Deputy) and Scott Morrison (Treasurer) along with some changes to other portfolios will see an unbeatable government lineup going into next year's election - particularly when you consider the fairly inept leadership from Shorten and a relatively weak Labor front bench, none of whom apart from Albo, are particularly strong performers in parliament.

text: I think it's fair to say that a Turnbull, Bishop, Morrison lead government will quickly dissolve any notion that the ALP and their cheer squad have of Labor cruising into government on the back of an unpopular Abbott, with a weak leader and no policies.

text: Gee, I hope Bill has got his numbers right. Labor does not have a great track record when it comes to applying a tax, in fact they have been woeful in the past. This may well have the same outcome.

text: The Labor cheer squad hate the idea that Morrison is actually a very decent person and an effective politician. He certainly showed up how inept Labor were at protecting our borders and with Bill Shorten's policy free zone, Australian voters still have no idea how Labor would protect our borders from people smuggling operations - to be frank I doubt they have any idea either.

text: His biggest challenge is getting the extra funding through cabinet/budget - but we live in interesting times and who knows what role Morrison may have in the near future - hell, he may even be Treasurer one day!

text: Baird is currently rated as the most popular political leader in the nation, particularly in NSW where it matters and he has a competent team of ministers behind him. Foley is a total unknown, most people don't even know his name, so the chances of him getting up are next to zero.

text: Labor has not a hope in hell of winning this contest...I think they know this in their hearts and really need to start looking ahead to 2019 when, if Foley is still around, they may be able to cobble together some kind of decent alternative.

text: That said, if Baird gets 4 years to continue the great work he has already done for the state, Labor may need to wait 8 years before they get another look in - goodness knows how many leaders they will have gone through by then.

text: Before you start pinning up more images of Che Guevara around your bedroom you need to consider this......Australia is a democracy where the people of voting age duly elect a political party to govern for 3 years after which time the government go to the polls and if they have performed well enough they will be reelected for a further 3 year term by the people. Your fantasy of trying to overthrow a duly elected government midterm is just that, a fantasy. You will just have to wait until 2016 to mark the government's scorecard. If your views are in the minority, which I suspect they are, you will have to wait until 2019 or perhaps 2022 before your Labor/Greens party can regain power.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Why don't we wait and see what Turnbull will do - we know already he will take the party, and government, back towards the centre, hell he may even go further to the left than Shorten. Wouldn't that be fun and games?

text:
I don't know what the PM said but I support whatever it was she did say)(Shorten - wannabe PM with buckleys chance)
Can't see there is any actual story here that is news worthy? 
I suspect the embarrassing Chris Bowen brain freeze which is headlines in every other media outlet today except The Guardian Australia is worthy of a piece but alas no.
Dreyfus is kicked out because he is a serial offender when it comes to flouting standing orders. Bishop should 'name' him to save us recalcitrant behavior for 24 hrs.  
That said he is not alone. Labor are an undisciplined rabble in QT. Shorten (the destroyer of 'policy developer' Julia Gillard) has no authority and it shows.
Can't see any issue with this - unless Triggs and Dreyfus had something to hide, which is unlikely. 
Normal machinations of government at work.
But John, Labor members did elect their leader - his name is Anthony Albanese. 
The factions took over. told the members to bugger off and installed a bloke called Bill Shorten...a decision they no doubt a truly regret today, particularly with the prospect of a Turnbull lead Coalition government on the horizon.
While Abbott's on a roll he should also lay into the Indonesians over their murderous occupation of West Papua.
Well let's hope the $88k fine goes towards reef conservation.
Because if an economy does not grow, job vacancies stagnate or dry up which is not good for Queenslanders or any Australians for that matter.
Despite my strong reservations about Labor's ability to manage/grow the QLD economy without robbing from future generations, I cannot see any downside from this particular initiative. 
Makes sense to do all we reasonably can to preserve the reef.
Good old Labor fiscal mismanagement. 
They do it every time. 
Gillard's fingerprints,along with Wong, all over it. 
This is why they are in opposition and will remain there for quite a few years ahead.
