text: Abbott had better do a cracking job at the Press Club on Monday, the task made harder by the inevitable large loss of LNP seats in today's QLD election, but Monday's speech will define the PM's political future. He may survive the next 6 months, he may not.
author: TimOfAltona

text: QLD Election......the QLD LNP stand to be the big winner on Saturday...returned to government with a reduced majority...the prospect of their relatively unpopular leader being jettisoned with a new popular leader in Tim Nicholls to take the party forward for the next 3 years.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The ALP leader will no doubt be dropped from the leadership as is the Labor Way after elections are lost, but in this case it will be necessary if Labor are to remount a credible challenge in 3 years time.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Newman was right when he held up 4 pages containing Labor's cobbled together costings which they expect voters to accept as proof of their ability to manage the state's finances'
author: TimOfAltona

text: Not particularly...Newman was ok and consistent with his performance in the last debate but I think to Anna's credit she lifted her game a peg or two to stay in touch with Newman.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I think the Labor/Greens cheer squad should come clean when giving their 'unbiased' opinion that the ALP opposition leader won the debate - Campbell Newman could have been debating a flower pot and the cheer squad would still announce the flower pot the winner.
author: TimOfAltona

text: We all wait in anticipation to see what this Anna woman will stuff up during the debate. She was clearly nervous at the last one and mucked up her opening set piece....I wonder how long it will be before a journo asks her to nominate the current rate of GST?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Bottom line is the ALP had no intention that this woman would one day be premier. She was a seat warmer to tide the QLD ALP over until they were in a position to contest the election again after 2 or 3 terms in opposition with another leader.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Daisy, Daisy, Daisy...last I looked Tony Abbott is not running for a seat in QLD, yet for some reason, confused Labor voters want him to campaign as if he is.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The QLD LNP stand to be the big winner on Saturday...returned to government with a reduced majority...the prospect of their relatively unpopular leader being jettisoned with a new popular leader in Tim Nicholls to take the party forward for the next 3 years.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The QLD ALP leader will no doubt be dropped from the leadership as is the Labor Way after elections are lost, but in this case it will be necessary if Labor are to remount a credible challenge in 3 years time.
author: TimOfAltona

text: But hang on...you want them kicked out only to be replaced with a government who adopted the same policies...in fact restarted this whole off shore processing mess..were you calling for the Labor government to be kicked out back then?
author: TimOfAltona

text: But you never know - Abbott is a political fighter, he dispensed Labor by crushing them at the last election..he will still have one or two cards still up his sleeve - but anything is possible from here.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The Labor cheer squad need to be cautious here - after months of hysterical screaming to replace Abbott they may get their wish and he could well he replaced by a leader who enjoys significant support/popularity across Liberal/Labor/Greens voters- in fact many believe Malcolm Turnbull is closer to the centre and therefore governing for all than any other likely candidate.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Irrespective of the outcome you have to admire Campbell Newman - he could have parachuted into any safe seat held by his party (the way Labor do these things) yet he chose a marginal seat which was always going to be risky down the track.
author: TimOfAltona

text: This Kate woman was rejected big time by the Ashgrove voters 3 years ago - in fact she didn't even campaign under the Labor banner back then, hoping voters would not recognise her as a member of the toxic Bligh Labor brand and this time her tactic is trying to play the underdog to pick up a sympathy vote - at least she is brave enough to associate herself with the Labor Party this time around. Many voters will remember her subterfuge however and will stick with the Premier -as they should.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The socialist left are starting to allow their dead weight ideology ball and chain hinder their judgement and comprehension of what is on offer here...when you break it down it's actually not a bad reform package which I believe enjoys the support of the majority of tertiary institutions.
author: TimOfAltona

text: It's called  comrades....shaping Australia's tertiary institutions (university and non-university) so that they are sustainable and can be equipped to compete in an increasingly competitive environment. Good for our students and good for the nation.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Pyne is quite correct....the government are proposing some good additional funding initiatives as part of the overall package that will benefit, amongst others, students attending non-university higher education facilities who tend to come from lower socio-economic backgrounds.
author: TimOfAltona

text: -Detainees are tattooed with a number on arrival- All their clothes and possessions are removed,their heads shaved and they are made to wear striped uniforms- Half of them on arrival at the island are marched into underground chambers and exterminated by poisonous gas or shot out in a field- Where those still living are required to feed the bodies of the dead into cremation furnaces which are running 24 hrs per day- Where guards are selecting detainees for horrific medical experiments such as measuring how long it takes a person to die when exposed to extreme temperatures-Forced physical labour-summary executions for the slightest misdemeanor
author: TimOfAltona

text: Either provide us the evidence that these activities are being carried out on Manus or Nauru or alternatively best you stop attempting to hijack one of the darkest periods in human history to substantiate your case...it is not only incredibly disrespectful to those who survived Auschwitz but also the families and descendants of those who perished of which there are thousands in Australia.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You can sympathise with what this group is trying to achieve but what seems lost on them is that the people smugglers desperately want some sign that the government is relenting on this issue.
author: TimOfAltona

text: If the relenting involves releasing children and their parent/s from custody and placing them into the community then standby for the massive influx of boats from Indonesia carrying children along with a sharp rise in drownings along the way.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The people smugglers suddenly have a viable business model with which to restart their insidious trade and we all now what happened when Rudd kick started their business model last time.
author: TimOfAltona

text: At some stage you will just have to accept that a panel of High Court judges have a bit more knowledge of the law than yourself..........good result for the government.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I hold no view one way or the other on Peta Credlin apart from the fact she is credited with helping steer Tony Abbott from Opposition Leader to PM, albeit the task was made easier on the back of a highly dysfunctional Labor Party.
author: TimOfAltona

text: If the rumblings emanating from some Coalition backbenchers and also some front benchers are true, it may well be that Credlin holds too much power in the day to day machinations of government which means she must wear some of the heat currently being applied to Abbott.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Co-incidentally Julie Bishop, on her way to Afghanistan, had a private meeting with Rupert in NY a few days ago - if Rupert throws his support behind a leadership change (that definitely won't be announced via a tweet) we can safely assume that Tony's days as PM may well be numbered.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I hold no view one way or the other on Peta Credlin apart from the fact she is credited with helping steer Tony Abbott from Opposition Leader to PM, albeit the task was made easier on the back of a highly dysfunctional Labor Party.
author: TimOfAltona

text: If the rumblings emanating from some Coalition backbenchers and also some front benchers are true, it may well be that Credlin holds too much power in the day to day machinations of government which means she must wear some of the heat currently being applied to Abbott.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Co-incidentally Julie Bishop, on her way to Afghanistan, had a private meeting with Rupert in NY a few days ago - if Rupert throws his support behind a leadership change (that  won't be announced via a tweet) we can safely assume that Tony's days as PM may well be numbered.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The Labor cheer squad only want to talk about Newman and the LNP because they see what the rest of QLD voters see - the ALP are just not ready to assume government so soon after the disaster of the Bligh years.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Palawhatever can giggle and obfuscate all she likes when reporters ask her about Labor's costed policies but all it does is reveal what we already know - you'd have to have rocks in your head to bring the ALP back into government in QLD.
author: TimOfAltona

text: While you are at it - please share with QLD voters where you intend to make savage cuts to pay for all your pie in the sky policies...would be good to know before the polls open.
author: TimOfAltona

text: C'mon Labor..you can do it...share your fully costed policies with QLD voters (you know, like the LNP did a few days ago)...or are you just going to keep us in suspense and maybe release your fully costed policies around 4am on the day the polls open?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Problem for the left is voters don't see Labor as a safe pair of hands in QLD, for all the reasons we know Labor are just not ready for government so soon.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Fair to say Tom Uren was a genuinely good man who tried to make a difference for Australia through party politics. Inspired by Chifley he chose the left side of politics and went on to lead the ALP left.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Surviving the hell hole of the Burma Railway would have taught him humility, compassion and justice and whether from the left or right of politics you cannot help but admire his principles and achievements.
author: TimOfAltona

text: He and Hawke were not the best of mates, in fact he openly opposed Hawke becoming ALP leader - so he only got a very junior portfolio during the Hawke government years.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Abbott is right - if leaders buckled under the threat of grubby comments from opponents who infect social media they wouldn't last a week. Abbott is sticking to his principles here which demonstrates strong leadership.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The Labor/Greens cheer squad would have been scratching their collective heads in confusion and disarray this morning....how do we attack what has occurred without posting our usual grubby and insulting remarks aimed at causing maximum damage to the character and reputations of the recipients? they asked themselves.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Apart from the pro-Rudd divison of the Labor cheer squad who would be openly attacking the integrity of the second person on the list, the rest would have no where to go on this.....it would have been a beautiful thing to watch. LOL
author: TimOfAltona

text: I think this highlights the sheer hypocrisy of those who went to bed all excited last night - could not wait to log on this morning and post the usual contrived hatred towards the individuals chosen for this honor - irrespective of who they were going to be.
author: TimOfAltona

text: She is urging defence force personnel to help pave a way for the return of a Labor government who did nothing but rip millions out of the defence budget and weaken Australia's defence capability across the board.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Ah...I must have got it wrong..the CFMEU are in favour of shutting the coal mines down and putting 13000 members out of work..that's why they want you to vote for a Labor/Greens government.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The Labor leader tells us to vote for Labor, put the LNP last but don't worry, if Labor win government we will still give you everything the LNP promised you before the election.
author: TimOfAltona

text: They may have started under Labor, but your political affiliate the Greens who you rely on to get you into government have a very clear anti-coal mining platform which is to shut the mines down and throw thousands of CFMEU members out of work.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Sounds fair enough to me - voters can't expect to have it both ways ie vote for a Labor candidate but still expect all the good things that would have occurred had they remained an LNP seat to happen anyway. That's why they should number every box and place the ALP last.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The Labor/Greens cheer squad's legendary fascination, more like pathological obsession, with anything and everything to do with Nazis, Hitler, Concentration Camps and the like is wearing a little thin and highly disrespectful to living survivors of that dark period in world history.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Here's a tip - no clear thinking person believes the atrocities & events in Europe 75 odd years ago are being played out in 2015 Australia just because a Labor/Greens government is not in power . Feeble attempts to manufacture links make the authors look somewhat unhinged and desperate IMHO.
author: TimOfAltona

text: 13,000 members directly employed in the coal industry...you know, the same industry Labor's political partner The Greens want to shut down and throw 13,000 existing members out of a job as well as snuff out thousands of new mining jobs being created?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Newman is right - when you Google CFMEU Bikie Links, it comes up with plenty of articles on bikies infiltrating the CFMEU, standover tactics, threats, assaults and the like.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Actually, I think you'll find the ALP have done a pretty good job all by themselves in trashing their brand...look at all the former supporters crossing over to the Greens.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Funny how the cheer squad react so to a Newspoll when it shows Labor ahead, but when a Newspoll shows Labor trailing it's all a Murdoch conspiracy designed to protect the LNP and should be ignored.
author: TimOfAltona

text: It would be good to know who the QLD Labor team are - I mean apart from that Anna woman who has a clue who else there is... pretty much no-one.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The day the ALP get up and stop doing grubby deals with the Greens to help them win seats is the day many of the disaffected Labor supporters will return to the party.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Despite all the contrived bluff and bluster from the ALP/Greens and their supporters it's evident the ALP, even with their addiction to Green preferences, will fall well short in a few days time.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The reason? Queenslanders' are still reeling from the disasters of the Bligh years, only 3 short years ago. There is no way they will entrust their state to another under-performing and ill-equipped Labor government for years to come. Particularly with the low standard of leadership currently on offer.
author: TimOfAltona

text: At the end of the day, the ALP and their leader were found wanting in the debate and this will translate to an LNP victory in a few days time.
author: TimOfAltona

text: It was clear that she is not the right leader for the ALP at the moment - she will in time make a good shadow minister of some portfolio/s & when the ALP actually find someone who can lead the party towards some kind of viable alternative government.
author: TimOfAltona

text: As for ALP voters? I call this 'burnt stick syndrome' - they would vote for a burnt stick if it was leading the Labor party and after last night's performance is anything to go by, that may be about all they have at the moment.
author: TimOfAltona

text: What most people saw was an ALP leader clearly out of her depth and who struggled to even get her scripted set pieces out, let alone anything remotely off the cuff.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I'm not saying she does not care about communities and the country, reality is though you need more than caring to lead a state the size of QLD - this person is totally ill equipped to be a premier.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Labor supporters hoping she will fall over the line on the back of an unpopular LNP and Greens preferences are kidding themselves - another Bligh disaster waiting to happen for Labor and Queensland.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Half of you declare Murdoch is plotting to protect the LNP by rigging polls and the other half are quoting Murdoch owned Newspoll results showing the ALP in front in some seats as proof 'it's all over for the LNP'?????
author: TimOfAltona

text: The televised debate confirmed for us what most people already knew or suspected - that Labor are not prepared in both leadership and policy to take over the reigns of government in QLD.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Newman clearly articulated how his government will reduce debt through billions raised from electricity asset leasing whilst the Labor leader gave us no clue how Labor will achieve that other than 'we have a plan' which involves not selling state assets????
author: TimOfAltona

text: Labor need to regroup after next weeks election, see what seats they have won, who else they have in parliament and try and find a new leader with at least some charisma and personality to try and take the party forward to contest the 2018 election.
author: TimOfAltona

text: It was not all smooth sailing for Newman either - he stumbled a bit at the end when the topic of Fitzgerald was raised and he started down the Bandidos/CFMEU/QLD ALP track which didn't go down too well and for which he lost some points.
author: TimOfAltona

text: That said, overall Newman was way out in front in terms of confidence, direct answers and spruiking the government's achievements vs a lacklustre and almost timid performance by the ALP leader.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Unfortunately the ALP leader was a little out of her depth tonight.....clearly very nervous at the start to the point she mucked up her set opening piece and was unable to properly articulate how the ALP would write down debt, apart from repeating over and over they will not be selling off assets in order to reduce the debt, but trust us Queensland, we will eliminate the debt anyway.
author: TimOfAltona

text: She was unconvincing and I feel a little sorry for Anna, they inserted this party woman into the role and given the belting they had received at the last election, never really thought she had any serious opportunity to win an election but rather keep the leader's seat warm for a couple of terms, perhaps get back a few seats and then insert a more viable leader to hopefully take the party forward after the 2018 election.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Actually, Op Sov Borders has been a huge success - people smugglers shut down, zero drownings, off shore detention centres being emptied and in time closed, genuine refugees arriving via the front door to start a new life and Australia fast becoming the border protection model European countries can only dream of.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Switch your Foxtel to Sky News tonight at 8pm AEDST...open forum from the Brisbane Broncos club with the ALP and LNP leader's answering questions from a panel of 100 undecided voters. David Speers is moderator.
author: TimOfAltona

text: ACTU trying to maintain the class warfare & workers v bosses line is tired and redundant in today's Australia - partly why Labor are seen as increasingly irrelevant - living in the past you could say.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Trying to maintain the class warfare & workers v bosses line is tired and redundant in today's Australia - partly why Labor are seen as increasingly irrelevant - living in the past you could say.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Not sure these Guardian threads are designed for campaigning on behalf of the ALP...that said you are wasting your time....Queensland LNP voters do not read these threads...mainly ALP/Greens supporters who would vote for a burnt stick if it was leader of the ALP.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Labor have definitely lost support from a fairly large portion of their traditional base...basically saying Labor have lost their way, abandoned the principles and ideals of the Whitlam years, too close to the Liberal Party, factional in-fighting, too coal hungry, re-opened off shore processing centres in order to stop the boats etc etc.
author: TimOfAltona

text: What i  know is that had Malcolm Turnbull persevered in the Liberal leadership (putting aside the the Ute-gate fuck-up) many Labor voters would have seriously contemplated jumping ship to the Coalition.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Admittedly this was fuelled by the Rudd/Gillard civil wars tearing the ALP apart, but Turnbull is/was regarded as a moderate who could govern for all Australians in a fair and inclusive manner drawing on successful elements of policies from both the left and the right, even giving the Greens environmental hobby horse a good look in.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Those disillusioned Labor voters are no longer contemplating jumping ship to the Libs (under Turnbull) but I suspect many are now lending looking to the Greens who they see more closely espousing many of the values of the Labor of old.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Are you angry about what the Labor Party did to Australia? Then join the Liberal party.Perhaps this article could appear in The Guardian next week, just for some much needed balance in journalism, free speech and opinion.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Abbott is right when he suggests that changing leaders can result in the opposite effect of what you are trying to achieve - look no further than the ALP as proof of that.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Failing that the decision needs to be made and a transition made quickly to another leader for the sake of the party and the country. The last thing we need is another knife fest with blood splattered walls (the Labor way).
author: TimOfAltona

text: I give Tony Abbott until the middle of this year to get some traction and get the polls going the other way or else the tough decision needs to be made for the sake of the country.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Careful what you wish for - if Abbott goes it opens up the possibility of a more popular Coalition leader emerging and turning around the fortunes of the current government to the point that Labor will continue to languish on the opposition benches for years to come whilst they sort out their future direction and leadership problems.
author: TimOfAltona

text: At some point, & not the night before the 2016 election, Shorten & Labor will need to clearly articulate how they plan on managing Australia's economy, what cuts they will be making and where, how they will manage border protection and anti-terrorism and how they plan to pay for all their policy promises that got them into so much strife during the failed Gillard/Rudd years.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Is it just me, or if a person or persons are disclosing, without authorisation under the Crimes Act, commonwealth information then there is a fair chance they can expect to be investigated to at least determine if a breach has occurred?
author: TimOfAltona

text: As you ask, if I were Abbott I would stay right away from QLD...the LNP can easily win it without support from the PM. Perhaps he will go up there for the 2018 QLD state election - who knows?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Ahh..Lee Rhiannon, the former doyen of the Socialist Party of Australia who is on record for expressing her sorrow that the Berlin Wall came down and the demise of the Soviet backed German Democratic Republic and her displeasure on the reunification of the two German states....yes she is definitely one we should be paying attention to and following her lead.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I see the desperation and disappointment is starting to set in as many Labor/Greens supporters start to realise they are backing the losing team.....something most of Queensland and the rest of Australia could have told them, and probably did, weeks ago.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Queensland voters are not goldfish - they actually remember the disaster of the Bligh government only 3 short years ago. Labor are in no fit state to govern Queensland, have not been for the last three years and won't be for another few years away yet...just the way it is. Like federal Labor, they need to regroup, find a strong charismatic leader people will follow and start finding direction and purpose to turn themselves into a viable alternative government in another 3 or 6 years time.
author: TimOfAltona

text: With all the disasters, death and human misery occurring around the planet each day, arguing that women should wear shorts instead of skirts playing tennis seems rather trivial to the point of being ridiculous.
author: TimOfAltona

text: If you want to further the rights and well being of females best focus on the horrors of kidnapped women and girls being forced into sexual servitude in Nigeria or parts of Asia (even in Australian brothels it seems).
author: TimOfAltona

text: I seriously doubt this woman will be leading the QLD ALP into the next election - she will have given it her best shot in two weeks but with no real expectation that she will win. After this election QLD Labor will need to re-group under a new leader to try and get their shit together for 2018.
author: TimOfAltona

text: On the plus side for Labor is that they will definitely pick up a bag of seats in a couple of weeks which is not a bad outcome for them or the state....no disrespect to Ms Palaszczuk but if Labor are to go to the next level she is not the person to take them there.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Just look at the horrid things they are doing - fancy protecting the dugongs and sea turtles..how dare the LNP government interfere with those nice poacher folk earning a dishonest living up north?
author: TimOfAltona

text: And as for protecting endangered African animals from those nice poor poachers trying to make a dishonest living supplying Asia's insatiable appetite for ivory and other parts of elephants and rhinos - this government should be ashamed of themselves.....
author: TimOfAltona

text: ...and as for those poor feral cats killing off millions of native mammals every week in Australia - how dare Greg Hunt be so callous as to fund a feral cat extermination program aimed at saving our vulnerable wildlife.....
author: TimOfAltona

text: Labor? Well the new Victorian Labor government have just announced that they will allow duck hunting to continue in that state which threatens to decimate already depleted duck species in their wetland habitat - now that's the sort of government we want!
author: TimOfAltona

text: Best you stop attacking Abbott for trying to have these executions stopped - if he does or says nothing and these men are executed you will be attacking him for doing nothing to save their lives...so he intervenes and he is attacked for speaking out against it.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The PNG authorities have a duty of care to prevent detainees harming themselves or others hence the action taken to shut down the ring leaders who wish harm on their fellow detainees by encouraging hunger strikes and self harm.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I suspect the people making comments in this thread would vote for a burnt stick if it was the leader of the ALP and right now that's about all they have got.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Ultimately at elections voters judge an incumbent government on it's performance and decide if they deserve another term - this why we saw the ALP all but wiped out in QLD last election and again federally in Sept 2013.
author: TimOfAltona

text: In two weeks time, QLD voters will mark the LNP's scorecard and also that of the ALP and decide who they believe, based on the evidence they have, is the best party to take QLD forward for the next 3 years.
author: TimOfAltona

text: No amount of childish name calling, grubby and insulting comments from the Labor/Greens peanut gallery will get Labor over the line...it is up to Labor to demonstrate they have the capacity to govern Queensland so soon after they were emphatically given the thumbs down by Queensland voters.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Polling shows it could be close, talk of a minority govt is in the air, it will certainly be interesting to see the outcome...betting agencies however are picking an almost certain LNP victory.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Most Queenslanders will see Newman as a safe pair of hands - it needs two or three terms to reap the benefits of economic reform - the question is..are Queenslanders prepared to re-elect the LNP and give QLD Labor a few more years to rebuild and try and mount a credible claim to govt?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Tony Abbott and Rupert Murdoch are not standing for election in the QLD election - I checked the Queensland electoral website and could find no sign of them listed.
author: TimOfAltona

text: So you acknowledge this is no more than a shabby attempt by the Wilderness Society to pursue their anti-coal agenda conveniently disguised as something else - certainly sucked in a lot of the anti-Newman supporters going by the comments below.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The Wilderness Society falls into exactly the same bucket as the Australia Institute - the Greens have their fingerprints all over it and has a significant anti-coal mining agenda. Bob Brown was a past director.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Perhaps this fellow should reveal he is speaking on behalf of the anti-coal lobby group who are intent non stopping the Adani deal by removing the Newman government and shutting down thousands of jobs in the state. Does he say that anywhere?
author: TimOfAltona

text: The BMW's were ordered while Julia Gillard was PM, in fact they were ordered by Nicola Roxon on the advice from the AFP who deemed them more suitable for protection work than the locally built Holden's. They were already well and truly in the pipeline and happened to be ready for delivery just after the Coalition decimated Labor at the polls.
author: TimOfAltona

text: But will Kate fess up to being part of Labor this election, or will she try and hide that fact like she did last time around when she was defeated with a swing of 13% against her?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Those drownings are occurring in the waters between North Africa and southern Europe. Tragically they would have been much larger had this government not succesfully shut down the maritime people smugglers in this part of the world.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Are you referring to the Labor government who started up the boat arrivals and when the numbers got out of control opened up Manus and Nauru to ship the refugees off shore and which the current government inherited and has to sort out the mess?
author: TimOfAltona

text: To be fair to Peter, he has only been in the role for 5 minutes. Perhaps if you go back to the conga line of Labor immigration ministers presiding over Manus it may give you a clue as to how all this started.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Don't disagree that these off shore places should be emptied and closed down - but don't forget the same stuff was going on inside on-shore detention centres as well - remember the riots, fires, hunger strikes, sewing of lips etc in Australian detention centres during the Labor and probably Liberal years before that?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Let's face it - the only solution these refugees want is to be allowed to come to Australia by boat, be allowed to roam free on arrival, be provided with accommodation, find a job or go on welfare and live in the community.
author: TimOfAltona

text: That's fine if it is only a few hundred people, but reality is there are millions of displaced people looking for a 'host' country which is why we need a controlled & regulated refugee intake program that ensures a safe and secure assimilation into the community.
author: TimOfAltona

text: No I mean from authorities onsite at Manus - not people sitting on their keyboards back in Australia pulling stuff out of the air about a situation they know nothing about to suit their political preferences.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The left don't like 'Stop the Boats' because it was a key plank in the Coalition' drubbing of the ALP last election and one which the government subsequently delivered on and something where Labor spectacularly failed - shutting down the evil people smugglers' deadly trade.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You cannot easily estimate the numbers of lives subsequently saved by this action, but if the Labor years and events between North Africa and Southern Europe are any guide, the numbers would be substantial.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Let no one forget that it was Julia Gillard and the Labor government who re-opened these offshore detention centres in 2012 after the Howard government had closed them down in 2004.
author: TimOfAltona

text: This current government is tasked with cleaning up Labor's mess in this area and hopefully, as in the Howard government years, these off-shore facilities will be emptied and closed down - permanently.
author: TimOfAltona

text: PS - I have yet to hear Labor's policy on all this - as far as you can tell they will be maintaining the same rigid deterrent 'Stop the Boats' policy aimed at shutting down people smugglers - will 'Chippendale' be equally critical if it is a Labor government stopping the boats, or is the criticism only reserved for when Liberal governments stop the boats?.
author: TimOfAltona

text: That aside, if the detainees are behaving in a way that is unlawful or are a danger to themselves or others some level of intervention is required by the PNG authorities. The intervention however should be commensurate with the threat or risk.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The future in health care is research, the flow on from better funded medical research is improved healthcare, better quality of life for an ageing population, fewer visits to the doctor and shorter queues for treatment. The whole nation benefits.
author: TimOfAltona

text: They have, it was called a federal election where, due to past performance, the voters determined that Labor were unfit to govern and were thrown out with a massive loss of seats in the lower house.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The same fate can easily await the current government at the next election if voters deem their performance inadequate and they see Labor have got their shit together and are ready to be in government after one term - I think the latter will ensure the current government will remain comfortably on the treasury benches.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Herein lies the problem - in Labor supporter land, all the government has to do is go out and pick the money off the magical money tree (mostly foreign debt) and hey presto all is fine and we all live happily ever after.
author: TimOfAltona

text: In the real world however, it is a little more complex. The government has to find money from other areas to keep pace with the rising subsidies required to fund Medicare and this against a backdrop of falling revenues. Sussan Ley is tasked with trying to find a way to make Medicare more self sufficient and sustainable for the long term without the need for increased overseas borrowings.
author: TimOfAltona

text: If you don't see that $1bn per year saved by reducing inefficiencies in public hospitals or $0.5bn savings in 'workforce reform' in public hospitals is not code for slashing and burning jobs to help pay for Medicare then you would be naive in the extreme.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Abolishing the Private Health Insurance rebate to save $6bn is counterproductive as it would channel tens of thousands of patients into the public health system which would be crippled under the strain.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Sussan Ley is on the right track to consult with all stakeholders and try and reach agreement on the fairest way forward to make this work...we would then expect Labor and the senate to back the government for the benefit of all Australians.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Please provide us the links that show where every Liberal government since Fraser have intended to kill off Medicare...while you are showing us that I will provide the links that show every Liberal government Health Minister since Fraser have worked hard & implemented policies to maintain/sustain Medicare. Sussan Ley is no different.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Problem with your summation is that if Ley were to adopt some of Lenore's 'incisive laser beam'suggestions you will need to get on here and praise the Minister for adopting a well thought out solution that will ensure the viability of Medicare.
author: TimOfAltona

text: ...and Labor's solution to fix this is.... you guessed it.....do nothing...except perhaps keep borrowing more money from overseas to keep artificially propping Medicare up because it is unable to sustain itself through the Medicare levy.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Now that's smart thinking on behalf of Labor and partly the reason they find themselves sitting on the opposition benches federally and in most states and territories. Sustainable economic management is not one of their strong points.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Well done Sussan Ley for going down the consultation path to resolve the impasse and we wish her well in achieving an outcome that is fair but also ensures the sustainability of the Medicare system.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You cannot allow a piece like this attacking someone else's credentials/credibility go through to the keeper without reminding readers that the author was recently caught red handed by the National Audit Office diverting recommended project funding from the $227m Regional Development Australia fund when she was Regional Services Minister from Coalition held seats into marginal Labor seats. Projects missing out on funding as a result included a cancer centre and an outreach disadvantaged youth facility.
author: TimOfAltona

text: That's the biggest joke of the day. Their anti-coal lobbying and connection with the Greens and Labor is legendary. You only have to look at their Chair, Chief Executive and board members to see this 'thinktank' has Christine Milne and Bob Brown's fingerprints all over it.

text: Ahhh..The Australia Institute - that doyen of the Labor/Greens climate change squad and partly bank rolled by the environmental activist group Poola Foundation (also major benefactor to the Australian Conservation Foundation) who interestingly, also teamed up with GetUp! and the Gillard Labor administration to deliver us the now defunct Carbon Tax
author: TimOfAltona

text: Perhaps the Guardian should have come clean on The Australia Institute and it's anti-coal mining agenda - just for some much needed balance to the article which of course much of the Labor/Greens cheer squad have blindly deemed as gospel because The Australia Institute said so.

text: At some stage you must surely realise that the LNP will be returned in QLD.....some will concede defeat earlier than others.....no offence intended but I reckon you will still be claiming victory for Labor they have been defeated.

text: All the anger in this thread directed at the current government over the approval of the Adani coal venture on the basis that it is bad for the environment and counter-productive for the state's economy, yet from what I can see the party they so desperately want to replace the current government,Labor, have also given the green light for Adani to extract coal if the ALP were to win government - yet strangely, critics of the Newman govt are dead silent on this.

text: Is it a case of only when the LNP are in government, extracting coal is an evil industry destroying Queensland along with the planet, but if it occurs under a  government all is forgiven and maybe it is not such a bad thing for Queensland jobs growth and future prosperity after all?

text: Plucking a figure like $100m out of the air is easy to do - problem for Labor is there is no detail to back up how this will be funded (ie what cuts will it have to implement to pay for this) or how it will be implemented and function.

text: Nothing could save Gillard however and she was eventually terminated by her own party (c'mon down Bill Shorten) before Australian voters could have their turn at throwing her and her Labor party out of office.

It is a crying shame that Australia's first female PM was not chosen by the voters of Australia but was installed by some grubby backroom faceless men whilst knifing the duly elected PM Rudd fairly and squarely between the shoulder blades.

text: Labor have no chance of winning government in QLD with that person as leader - it's all very well going on about the LNP but if you don't have a leader that's up to the task then forget getting back into government

She was an absolute shocker.....trying to tell people that Labor has changed from the failures of the Bligh years is falling on deaf ears...QLD Labor has done nothing in 3 years to demonstrate they have even remotely rebuilt their shattered party and the worst thing of all is she is dancing around the questions about costed policies - won't answer the question.

text: If I were Labor I would be focusing on the 2018 election and how they may be able at least place themselves in a position to be a viable alternative government in 3 years. This year is well and truly all over for them.

text: Good to see Abbott maintaining a steady ship with our regional neighbours. Sri Lanka plays an important part in the war against people smugglers and their co-operation means the current off-shore processing facilities will be emptied and closed down sooner rather than later. Everyone wins.

text: What a ridiculous assertion that is. If that is the best the Labor/Greens can come up with as part of a scare tactic no wonder Labor will stay in opposition - noone is buying it because it ain't true.

text: Right here is why Labor have no hope in QLD - if Labor and their dwindling band of supporters think they can just fall into government with no policies, a leader no-one has heard of and the raw memory of the last Labor disaster still fresh in peoples' minds then they are at best delusional.

Also, don't lose your Deputy Leader a couple of weeks out from the election (does not fill the voters with much confidence in the party) and above all, get some bloody costed policies for god's sake - releasing them around mid-night the night before the election just won't cut it...people simply don't trust you after the failures of the Beattie/Bigh years. Rebuilding takes time.

text: NZ have applied two increases in GST since starting out at 10% and the centre-right government who increased it have recently been returned with a historical majority vs the NZ Labour party.

text: Will the opposition oppose in the senate? Probably not if it means lifting Australia out of it's current malaise - providing the right safety nets are place for the vulnerable amongst us.

text: The Human Rights Commission is not a court and Triggs is not a judge. She heads a statutory organisation reporting through to parliament via the Attorney General. No judicial ruling has been made on this fellow's detention and certainly none has been made that tax payers should be coughing up $350,000 to reward him for his trouble.

No doubt the ALP with the help from the Greens will claw back a few seats here and there, but with a massive majority in the Legislative chamber the LNP will prevail for another 3 years.

text: To those holding up the recent Victorian election as proof Labor will win in QLD, remember the Napthine Govt only had a majority of 1 in the lower house - the Newman government has a majority of 70+ seats. It will be years before QLD trust another Labor government to run down their state.

text: Hiding your collective heads in the sand will not make it go away - with resource revenues slowing Australia needs tax reform to help pay for new infrastructure,including an NBN, hospitals, schools, TAFES and tertiary institutions - a GST increase is the logical and fair way to achieve increased funding for the states.

text: No-one seems game enough to articulate who/what would replace this government in the 2016 federal election - so we are left to assume that half the commentators on here want to see Christine Milne as PM whilst the other half want to see Bill Shorten become PM.Good luck with both of those options. text: Not to mention Labor's disaster of an immigration policy that saw thousands of people lured to Australia by people smuggling boats with over 1000 drownings and billions of dollars of cost burden added to the economy through building and maintaining onshore and offshore detention/processing centres to cope with the massive influx of people claiming asylum which all ended in tears anyway.

text: Selling the reforms has been problematic, especially when people don't like losing handouts they have taken for granted...this was always going to be challenging and could have been handled better hence the poll results...the message containing clear beneficial outcomes will need to be improved in 2015.

text: Ultimately though, Labor and the Greens have very low ratings when it comes to economic credibility and I'm willing to bet that Shorten (providing he can hold onto the leadership) is happy to sit back and let the government wear all the pain of fiscal reform and hopes he can sneak in under the radar accompanied by the usual ALP rhetoric "all our fully costed policies will be released the night before the next election"

text: Always good to see a cheer squadder conceding that Labor are gone for at least another 2 terms - they have no hope with Shorten and Plibersek running the show on behalf of the unions and the Greens.

text: Not a bad result for the government - plenty of opportunity to turn things around over the next 12 months. Providing we get our debt under control, reduce operating costs to counter decreasing revenues then overall 2015 looks promising for both the government and the country.

text: Hockey, like the PM has 12 months to turn the ship around - failure to do so will see both him and Abbott looking increasingly unlikey to lead the government into it's third year.

text: Overall a good shuffle by the PM. Good to see Sussan Ley enter the front bench - she will make a very capable Health Minister in the new look cabinet. I thought Morrison was a shoe-in for Defence but you can see the wisdom in putting him into Social Services to replicate the success he delivered on within the Immigration portfolio. Should be a stronger government next year with these changes.

text: If things are not turning around for the government by year's end, Abbott will definitely go and we will have a new PM to take the party to the election victory 12 months later.
author: TimOfAltona

text: That said, my guess is things will start to improve for the govt in 2015 once the budget measures are through and they can get on with the business of governing. Abbott is likely to go on and take the party to it's second term - Shorten and the ALP are miles away from being up to the task - even with the mandatory backing of the Greens.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You see here's where it all falls apart for the Labor/Greens cheer squad. Tony Abbott is the PM - people expect to hear from the PM in times of crisis - it's what PM's do. If we heard nothing from the PM you would be on here attacking him for being invisible.
author: TimOfAltona

text: PMs' are surrounded by advisers - they brief the PM on a particular situation so that he can address the nation - the PM relys on that information to be accurate. In this case it appears it may not have been.It is no reflection on a PM if he is given the wrong advice. That is why there will be an inquiry.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Yet again you allow anti-Abbott rhetoric to cloud your judgement - let's spell it out in plain english so there is no misunderstanding - the PM was erroneously advised regarding the status of the gunmans firearms licence and Abbott acted on that advice as any PM would do - hell even Julia Gillard would have made statements based on adivce she received - hence an inquiry will be held as to how the PM was given seemingly inaccurate facts.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Tisk tisk Guardian - the headline to this article is pure click bait for the anti-Abbott brigade and going by the comments from the usual suspects looks like you achieved what you set out to achieve, they flock to it like flies.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Because he was advised not to by the experts - sometimes clouded left-wing thinking just doesn't cut it in situations like this. Best the Labor/Greens cheer squad stick to what they know - which ain't much.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I think in your usual rush to demonise on a daily basis anything and everything related to the PM and current government you got yourself a bit tangled up.....the PM made a statement acting on advice given to him, presumably by people authorised to brief the PM.....explain to us how he was irresponsible by making a statement following that advice? Not too sure you can answer that one. In fact you can't.
author: TimOfAltona

text: At the risk of not getting a 'Guardian Pick', last I looked #I'llridewithyou had nothing to do with News Corp, the LNP or even Labor or the Greens yet First Dog IMHO has chosen to hijack & politicise it for his ideological views and presumably cater to his left-wing anti-Murdoch fan base.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Here's a tip - LNP, Labor, Greens, Jewish, Christian, Muslim, black, whites, atheists and hell, even News Corp journos support what #i'llridewithyou represents and how it frames the Australian way of life - or at least the way of life we would all like it to remain.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I'm with you - the horrific Martin Place incident would  have occurred if it was a Labor/Greens government in power - only bad things happen when an LNP government is in power.

text: Does he lose his contract with the Guardian because he can't be seen to satirise a Labor/Greens government or does he just focus his attention on the Opposition and ignore what his centre-left government are doing along with their numerous failures?

text: Shame we couldn't dodge the old desal plant bullet - it smacked us fair and square between the eyes and everyone of us will be paying dearly for Labor's ineptitude for the next 50+ years. Watch out for Andrews, he's as slippery as the proverbial eel....like all Victorian Labor governments before him we will all be feeling the fiscal pain as he lurches from one fiscal disaster to another trying to implement policies at the direction of the unions and the Greens. Mark my words.

text: Little point - it would be swamped by all the bitter and twisted Labor/Greens supporters blaming it all on the PM - as they do for pretty much any man made or natural disaster occurring anywhere in the world.

text: The first term of this government was  going to be challenging fixing up Labor's fiscal mess plus a largely hostile senate to boot. With a slowing world economy and commodity pricing heading south we would be in all kinds of strife if Labor had kept borrowing to pay for their unaffordable policies without the fortitude and balls to implement much needed cost cutting.

text: It's clear that the ALP and Greens are wrecking our economy by blocking key cost saving measures in the senate. Ironic how the Labor/Greens government mismanaged the nation's finances when in government and have gone on to wreck the nations finances while in opposition. Shorten and Milne have a lot to answer for here and the sooner they come to terms with the fact that they are no longer in government and allow the government we elected to fix up the mess the better off we will be.

text: No police member is trained to 'shoot to kill'. Police are trained to use their firearms as a last resort to protect themselves or others against an imminent life threatening situation and more often or not it is a split second decision. If you perceive that your life is in danger, you fire your weapon at the largest body mass presented which is most often the torso area - shooting at limbs to stop someone who is coming at you with a knife is the stuff of Hollywood.
author: TimOfAltona

text: What police  trained to do is prevent death or injury to themselves or others by using the amount of force necessary in proportion to the threat that presents itself...these include a range of options from capsicum spray to firearms but it is ultimately the judgement of the police member attending as to which of these he/she uses depending on the threat presented and often it has to be a split second decision.
author: TimOfAltona

Successive Federal and State governments, Labor and Liberal, have flowed billions of dollars into Indigenous programs over the past 30-40 years with some success and many failures. 
I think pretty much everyone agrees that throwing money at this is not the solution - at some stage disadvantaged indigenous communities need to stand up for themselves and take control of their future - over reliance on government handouts is often self defeating and perpetuates the cycle of substance abuse, sexual assault , domestic violence and longterm unemployment.  
There are some rural and remote indigenous communities that have lifted themselves out of that cycle and they should be the role model & inspiration for other less fortunate communities.
Sarah Ferguson was good - she took no nonsense from either party and made pollies from both sides squirm in their seats. 
Good to watch.
This is where it all goes pear shaped for the Left - blame the media for all the inadequacies and failures of the ALP.
Julie Bishop is winning a lot of cudos in the international community - the Left just don't like to see a strong assertive conservative female politician succeeding on the world stage.  
Good on her.
After the Gillard experiment imploded so spectacularly on Labor you would have to say no - but I believe the sex of the PM is irrelevant if she/he are doing a good job for the country. 
It would be good to see another female PM in this country, but one that was voted in by the people and not in inserted by the faceless factional men in the ALP as Gillard was. 
It was always going to end in tears.
Ian, you have to ask yourself - why is it that centre right parties are in government in just about all western democracies - even the the Republicans are looking solid for a landslide win in the next US elections. 
There is a reason old chap. Think it through.
Obama has significantly more problems at home where American voters gave the Democrats a resounding vote of no confidence just recently.

Grubby name calling are the hallmarks of a person who has well and truly lost the argument a long time ago - if you are not capable of mounting an argument without resorting to childish/offensive names then it reflects more on you than it does the Foreign Minister. 
I can mount an extremely solid argument as to why a Labor/Greens party are not fit to govern Australia for at least another 10 years and I can easily prosecute my case without resorting to childish names - give it a go.
Bishop is correct in her assertions that Australia are taking appropriate actions when it comes to preserving the reef. 
Good on her for standing up for Australia and letting the world know this country takes protecting the reef very seriously. 
There is no evidence that the current government have contributed to the degregation that occurred under the six years of Labor mismanagement, in the fact the opposite is true. Hunt has implemented additional safeguards to protect the reef.

I wonder how many people voted for their local LNP candidate because Abbott made a comment about no cuts to the ABC the night before the election - how many Labor MP's lost their seats on the basis that Abbott said there would be no cuts to the ABC? 
Hmmmmmmmm 
It's true, Abbott did say that and now will have to deal with the criticism from the left, however overall anything that makes the ABC a leaner more effective media organisation without unnecessarily draining the public purse is a good thing.
It's clear the Labor cheer squad are missing the point here - the country could not maintain the debt and deficit that 6 years of a Labor/Greens government saddled us with - while Labor would have us believe that spending money we do not have is the right way to run an economy, it eventually ends in tears for everyone. 
No one likes cuts but the country and the ABC will be better for it.

Overall, it's good to see the government tackling the costly waste that existed/ballooned under Labor.

text: Asylum seekers are encouraged to enter Australia via the UNHCR program which sees genuine asylum seekers welcomed into Australia through the front door, not by paying people smugglers thousands of dollars to circumnavigate the orderly acceptance process.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The people smugglers are banking on a change back to a Labour government in Australia so they can start up their deadly trade once more, but in the meantime business is terrible for them because the current government took a stand and shut them down.
author: TimOfAltona

text: If they are traveling to a designated "no go" zone to join and participate in the local jihad then there should be consequences - if they are traveling to a designated "no go" zone for family or other business then they have nothing to fear as per the exemptions contained in the bill.
author: TimOfAltona

text: No, pretty much living in the  world, not some delusional state of denial that the Labor/Greens alliance will keep Labor out of government for years to come - along with all the other reform issues.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I have said it before - the Labor/Greens cheer squad are fooling themselves by thinking that all they need do as a tactic to get back into government are daily ad nauseum, often confected, attacks against the PM and government.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Labor simply wont be in any position to form government while the current state of dysfunction continues. Divided leadership, union control and the love affair with Greens preferences to get them over the line all need to be addressed.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Looking back at old news footage of pro-Gough Whitlam rallies back in the 1970's, the Labor cheer squad of that time are holding up banners reading 'Fraser = Hitler' and 'Fraser = Nazi'.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The ALP mishandled so many issues whilst in government - People smugglers, live animal exports and ceiling batts to name but three. The cost? Over a thousand lives lost and billions of dollars in extra cost to the country.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Just confirms what the rest of Australia already knows - the people smugglers are hoping and praying another Labor/Greens government gets into office in 2016 so they can start up their business model once more.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Under the previous Labour government, asylum seeker boats were arriving in their hundreds from Indonesia, people were drowning and the people smugglers had become very adept at using Australian maritime authorities, search and rescue and the navy as a taxi service extension to their business model. There were reports that many people smuggling boats were calling up Australian search and rescue for help before they even left Indonesian ports.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The current government have totally dismantled the people smugglers business model by denying them a product to sell - the result is that only one boat arrived in Australia in the last year - there were dozens arriving each week under the previous government, hundreds if not thousands drowning at sea and the people smugglers were amassing vast fortunes.
author: TimOfAltona

text: It was largely accepted that Labor had created the problem by dismantling Howard's successful Pacific Solution and by doing so lost control of our borders - the result? Hundreds of boats, thousands of asylum seekers, detention centres unable to cope with the numbers and 1000+ poor souls drowned at sea.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Now I'm guessing that even you would agree that the situation under Labor, and no doubt encouraged all the way by their Greens partners, was untenable and not in the best interests of asylum seekers, both genuine and economic.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The government has achieved what it set out to do. Morrison has done a stirling job on delivering what Labor and it's supporters claimed could never be done - they have Stopped the Boats, dismantled the people smugglers business model and saved potentially hundreds, if not thousands, of lives along the way.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I simply don't get why Labor and Greens supporters think this is a bad outcome - one can only be left with the view that it is because the government has achieved a stunning success in this area where Labor and the Greens were found to be wanting - and it does not look good for their electoral prospects in 2016.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Australia's GST rate will increase at some point just as NZ went from 10% to 12.5% to the current 15% under a conservative government and it's economy and budget surplus is something Australia can only dream of.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Abbott said prior to the last convincingly won election that the matter of a GST increase must firstly be agreed by the states and then it would be taken to an election to allow the people to decide.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I can hear the excuses now - ''It's all Murdoch's fault" and "Australian voters are stupid" are two of my personal favourites of Labor/Greens supporters explaining away why they get thrashed at the polls - never a mention of a dysfunctional ALP joined at the hip with the Greens, poor leadership and excessive union control over the party.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Majority of Australians' applaud Morrison for delivering on a promise taken to the last election - Stopping the Boats and fixing up the immigration/asylum seeker mess caused by the ousted Labor/Greens government.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Either we shut down the evil people smuggling trade or we create an environment that encourages and allows the trade to prosper, along with the resultant deaths at sea.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Any grease-ball can stand up and sprout that they will spend billions of dollars on projects if they become premier - the trick is how will it be paid for?
author: TimOfAltona

text: What the Labor/Greens cheer squad in Australia fail to realise is that governments cannot provide schools, hospitals and public transport etc without revenue to fund it. They live in some Whitlamesque LaLa Land where everyone gets everything for free and then lives happily ever after.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Gee..I'm surprised the Rolling Stones even came to our shores given we live under such an evil & destructive government - they should have waited until 2022 when the next Labor government may look like getting back in.mind you how old would Jagger be then?
author: TimOfAltona

text: NZ have had 2 GST increases, 12.5 % then to 15% and the nations finances have never looked better - delivering a budget surplus Australia can only dream about - all under a conservative government too.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Only a matter of time - I reckon Abbott should take a 2.5% increase to the 2016 election - something else to differentiate from the ALP and he should not have any difficulty in returning to government.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The fact that hundreds if not thousands of asylum seekers are alive today because the Australian government got tough on people smugglers is always ignored by the Labor/Greens cheers squad - it's as if a few hundred drowning is just part and parcel of Australia welcoming asylum seekers who try and make the journey by boat - I think Sarah Hanson-Young, the Labor/Greens spokesperson on immigration, once said the drownings were 'unfortunate' and she would much prefer 'they didn't happen'.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Simple really.Indonesian authorities have not been able to come up with a way to line their own pockets under such a scheme - at least with the current arrangement they are handsomely rewarded by the people smugglers for assisting them.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Not sure their Greens bedfellows will be too impressed - but I guess Labor know they have little chance of victory in 2016 unless they run with what the majority of Australians voted for last year - also Labor by and large created this whole mess under Rudd and then Gillard so they need to be seen to help fix up their errors of judgment.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I strongly suspect that the cheer squad for Labor and the Greens already know 2016 is beyond them - perhaps time to re-group and focus on 2019 or 2022 when Labor party reform (if it happens) will have transitioned Labor into a viable alternative government.
author: TimOfAltona

text: If the siege of Kobani is broken and IS have been defeated there and the press get in, the stories of the Kurdish people defending that town will emerge.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The Kurdish Womens Protection Units (YPJ) will emerge as the real heroes. These all female fighting militias are on the front line in Kobani in street to street combat against the IS fighters.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Despite being heavily outgunned by superior IS weaponry and firepower,the YPJ can be credited with thwarting the IS entry into the town utilising sniper attacks, booby traps and when necessary, suicide bombings to disrupt the IS advance.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I fear for any YPJ fighters captured by IS, who perpetrate the most horrific and barbaric acts imaginable against these female captives - I have read reports and seen some vision of what IS are doing to these captured women, some are teenage girls, and if you ever wanted justification for why IS need to be destroyed it is right there.
author: TimOfAltona

text:
Stop the Boats' seems to me there is one major promise fulfilled right there - and don't the lefties just hate a promise being fulfilled.
Seriously, your obsession with the media is getting pretty tiresome. 
I can promise you this - the media did not create a bad Labor party - the ALP did it all by themselves.
I can't recall if Faulkner was a Rudd or Gillard backer - I think he was behind Rudd and wanted Gillard gone for the damage she caused the party. 
On that basis a very astute Labor politician and a wise man indeed. 
Yes, the ALP should take careful note of his comments on party reform. 
Unite or perish.
I would not get too excited about this - I doubt it will go through in it's current form or as indicated in this article. 
There has to be a line drawn in the sand when it comes to those negatively impacted by this bill - depending on their individual circumstances,pregnant women should not be disadvantaged, particularly single Mums who have no support from the father of the child.
It was all going along so well until the last panel hit.
That's no way to talk about the ALP.  
Shifty yes, dysfunctional yes, leaderless yes, policy-free party yes, recklessly spending tax payers money yes, factional infighting yes, recalcitrant yes, bugger all seats left yes, implementation failures galore yes, inept yes, visionless yes, directionless yes, bed partners with the Greens yes, moving rapidly towards the right yes, puppets of the trade unions yes, budget surplus free zone yes, economic pygmies yes, living off past glories yes.but bit harsh.
Alan Joyce, how the hell has he survived the trashing of Qantas since he took over? 
How/why is he still there? 
Beats me.
Yellow Crazy Ants - love it.
Any suggestions?
The Labor/Greens cheer squad should not get all excited thinking Palmer is about to scuttle the government's plans. 
Your hopes get dashed time and time again. 
Just saying
Good comment
Well all I know is that thank goodness we have a coalition government in power looking after our national security in these difficult times - heaven knows what may happen if a Labor/Greens government got their sticky dysfunctional mitts on national security. Shudder to think.
- in 2007 it was Rudd
I noticed most of the Labor/Greens supporters went silent the other day on Rupert Murdoch's backing of the ALP and Whitlam in the run up to Whitlam taking government in 1972. 
Some of the clueless ones even accused Murdoch of being behind Whitlam's dismissal.  
The hysteria around Murdoch by the cheer squad is unbelievable.Murdoch generally backs winners - in 1972 it was Whitlam - in 2017 it was Rudd - in 2013 it was Abbott. 
The Murdoch press called Labor out for what they were - a dysfunctional government self-imploding through ongoing civil wars - fact. 
Blaming Murdoch for Labor's woes is fanciful and reeks of denial. 
Hey even Bob Hawke called out Gillard and Rudd for what they were a - architects of their own demise. 
Perhaps if Labor can get their act together, Murdoch may even back the ALP next time.
Good to see we have sooooo many ebola  residing within the Labor/Greens cheer squad. 
Who woulda guessed?
No one else seems to ask that question except you - perhaps you missed the bit where the government is arranging guarantees on evacuation and care if anyone goes over there on behalf of the Australian government and contracts ebola. 
One thing is certain - if the government had sent Australians over there and one or more of them contracts ebola and dies, you will be the first person on here accusing the government of murder. 
Its just the way it is with the cheer squad.
No one is stopping you from going not least the government - there are plenty of flights via London to west Africa departing from all Australian cities tomorrow. 
Off you go - your assistance will be very much appreciated. 
But if you only want to head over there with the Australian government holding your hand then best you wait a little bit so they can assure/guarantee you of a proper medical evacuation and care should you contract ebola.
Still bitter and twisted over last September much?
What do expect the Australian PM to do - say nothing? 
Clearly you would only be happy if it was a  PM commenting - then it would be totally acceptable. 
Funny old thing politics. Life is too short to harbour so much hatred.
Perhaps there is a problem with their product?
The probability of a co-ordinated terrorist attack on Australian soil is very low - what is more likely is an unhinged individual acting alone which seems to be the case in the two recent attacks in Canada. 
Not sure how you guard against a 'lone wolf' attack where the weapon used may be just a motor vehicle or a knife. 
These are not 'terrorist' attacks in my opinion, but the actions of individuals who are mentally ill sociopaths.
Not happy with our democracy comrade?
All things considered, in these dangerous times it's far better we have a Coalition government in power to ensure national security and the safety of our MPs. 
Labor are influenced/dictated too much by the Greens whose solution to any terrorist act is to sprinkle fairy dust over the perpetrators in the hope they go away.
I don't get why the left cheer squad mock and ridicule attempts to halt the ISIS advance - yes the US stuffed up with one of the arms drops - but the rest reached the right target. 
In the meantime hundreds more Kurd men, women and children have been raped and slaughtered at the hands of ISIS. 
Still funny?
Occasionally I watch QT live on the ABCV - today was such a day. 
You can't help but feel Labor are in all sorts of bother. Overall they have a fairly weak and insipid front bench - clearly not up to the task of effective opposition. Their only consistently effective 'performer' is Albo - all the rest including Shorten are pretenders. Bowen comes in a distant second then Jason Clare a distant third - after that..zilch. 
The government have a number of strong and effective communicators in parliament and the void between the two parties has never been greater in my opinion.
I doubt there will be too many world leaders attending the funeral of Abu Bakr Al-Baghdadi after he's taken out by the coalition forces or Iraqi army.
The Greens are pretty much confirming to us all how irrelevant they are when it comes to national security issues.thinking that a group hug and singing Kumbaya around a camp fire with ISIS will solve everything just does not cut it with mainstream Australia.
Don't you just hate a lover's tiff?
The unions are taking the ALP down the gurgler with them.
Enjoyable series - Crabb does it very well. 
People I'd love her to 'visit' some time - 
Clive PalmerAnthony AlbaneseJulia GillardSussan LeyScott MorrisonJulie BishopOhand Labor's next PM, Paul Howse
Good luck with that
I'm with youAustralia can't  to vote in another Labor/Greens government.
Don't you just hate a lovers tiff?
Geethanks Daisy!
The Greens/Whitlam poster confirms exactly what I have been saying for a long time - Labor and the Greens are one and the same - joined at the hip while they try and help each other hobble past the finishing line. 
Fact - Labor have no hope of getting back into government while they rely on the Greens to get them over the line.
You know - the ones pulling Bill Shorten's strings.
How on earth did Jacqui Lambie get a seat at that senate committee table? She is probably the most dysfunctional senator in the whole joint - a loose cannon - almost invariably irrelevant.
You want the budget passed? - speak to your mates down at Trades Hall.
Not since labor went into opposition - children's games and recalcitrant behaviour is now the ALP norm. Sad really
Obama uses glass teleprompters for pretty much all of his addresses. Nothing off the cuff about it.
Good luck with that
Good comment
Keep going Scott - majority of Australians are backing you
He enjoys the support of the majority of Australian voters for a job well done - have you ever considered your views are those of a minority grouping?
Actually, you will find it is swinging the other way - 200,000 votes the Coalition. 
This is why the Labor/Greens cheer squad hate this success by the governmentit is a pre-election promise delivered.
The ALP are supporting the government on this.
Either we stop the people smuggling trade or we don't. ALP/Greens opted for the latter and the Coalition opted for the former. 
Good move by Morrison.
It depends on who you talk to - some people claim they or their relatives cried with joy when Whitlam was dismissed - some say he was, in the finest of Labor traditions, sending the country broke with his social reform agenda where everyone got everything for free but there was no money to pay for it all - sound familiar?
Good luck with that
Well, as the poster boy for the Labor/Greens cheer squad, David Marr would say that wouldn't he? 
Without foundation, just leftist speculation. 
Speaking of lengths politicians will go in pursuit of power, any chance you can look at the Rudd/Gillard/Rudd years David - or is that too close to home?
Whitlam had plenty of flaws and he took government after nearly 25 years of conservative rule (pretty much any mug leading the ALP could have done it - even Bill Shorten would have scraped through). 
The problem the ALP have now is that they are devoid of talent on their front bench - aint no Whitlams or Hawkies in sight. 
Labor will be in the wilderness for at least another two terms and probably 2 or 3 changes of leadership.
As with all Labor governments, more recently Labor/Greens governments, Whitlam ultimately presided over an economic messspend,spend,spend..which eventually lead to his downfall. 
Labor governments have a poor track record with economic management. The Liberals always return to fix up the mess.
Who pick's up the tab for you to go to university for free comrade? 
Try Cuba, I hear they still run with free unis and health care. 
Life is not a free ride anymore.
Whitlam's passing allows us to reflect on how mediocre and irrelevant today's ALP is.  
Labor and the Greens will pay for the disastrous Rudd/Gillard/Rudd (Brown/Milne) period for Australia was and their own party. 
There is a HUGE vacuum in Labor/Greens land right now with noone to fill the void. 
Labor need to work hard to find another Bob Hawke to lead them out of the abyss in my honest opinion.
The labor/Greens cheer squad get all excited when a Newspoll 2 years out from an election show Labor have a slight advantage - evidence they say that a Labor/Greens government will be returned in 2016. 
Here's a tip - Labor and the Greens are in no position to form a government for a very long time ahead. Using polls 2 years out from an election as evidence is naive and reeks of desperation. 
The polls will swing back to the government next year.
Unhinged comments such as this ensure Labor are gone in 2016. 
JS
Many of those listed were caused by the previous Labor government - the government will need to sort it out from here and they will in my estimation.
The Julia Gillard experiment was a total disaster for the ALP - a rump of it's former self. 
I suspect Gough would not have been impressed with the Gillard/Rudd civil war tearing Labor apart.
Settle down - do we detect a hint of more Labor disunity tearing the party apart and keeping it in opposition for years and years to come? 
Disunity is death for Labor. You only have to look at the Rudd/Gillard years to see the damage caused.
The 'Labor values' pursued by Whitlam were closer to those of Fidel Castro at the time. Everything free for everyone. 
We all know how that ultimately worked out.
ALP supporters cannot keep blaming the media for Labor's failures. At some point you have to stand up and say yep we stuffed that one up" and move on or look for ways to prevent the same mistake happening again.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Whitlam has a fairly large fan base from the left of politics but also has plenty of critics and for good reason - but he was no Bob Hawke and ultimately Kerr probably did the nation a favour.

text: John, bottom line - when I look at the coalition bench I see a team united behind their leader for the common cause of defeating the sitting government. Yes there have been moments of division, but that exists in every organisation.When you look at he Labor side you see hatred, division,backstabbing, white anting, deception and morale at rock bottom. Hardly the elements of a good government or the recipe to win an election. Now go and ask yourself why is this situation so?
