text: The problem Labor have is not the theatrics of the Coalition or the right wing shock jocks , it is the internal hatred ripping the party apart. Gillard has her strengths, but it is her devisiveness and lack of leadership for all that is destroying this government. Using class warfare and sexism to divide and conquer is not the way to run a government for all people or to defeat the opposition. Purely and simply she has relied on this John McTernan fellow to construct her tactics and public persona and this strategy has failed dismally. The entire ALP is about to pay the price for her decisions.

text: Your argument has more holes in it than Labor's so called 'protection' of our borders. Firstly, Cuba, Nth Korea and Tibet have a media strictly controlled by the communist/socialist government - any dissenting or opposing views or criticism of the government is strictly outlawed punishable by incarceration for very long periods. How is that similar to Australia and our media? Nothing at all. Secondly, you claim Murdoch and the MSM are spreading lies about Labor - a very broad statement with absolutely nothing to back it up. What lies have you heard? Thirdly, you claim are our democratic rights are being challenged because of alleged media conspiracies - bottom line is that people are intelligent enough to arrive at their own conclusions and neither do they have a gun at their head in the polling booth forcing them to vote for the Coalition. If they don't want the Coalition they will vote Labor, Greens or Indies - it's called democracy. And finally, I am not a moron. I find that term offensive to disabled people so afflicted and pretty much sums up your radical socialist persona. Thank goodness people with your beliefs account for less than 0.05% of the Australian population.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Having read a few of you posts, I reckon you would be much more at home living in Cuba or perhaps North Korea or Tibet even. Here you can enjoy media coverage that only permits the government's propaganda and disallows any coverage of alternative opinions or commentary. Much more to your liking to a far left socialist such as yourself?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Your problem is you back the team that most Australians' want thrown out of office in Sept. Had those media outlets you mentioned been perceived to be backing your team, we would not be hearing a peep out of you. Would you be so fervantly denouncing political media bias if they were supporting Labor? We all know the answer. Do yourself a favour, come over to the good side and your problem is solved.

text: Yet another pro-Gillard groupie living in complete denial of the true situation. You guys are going to be so disappointed - Gillard is destined to be thrown out along with Labor and she will be resigning from politics shortly after having 'lead' Labor to it's most resounding defeat ever. This will allow the ALP to throw in yet another union hack into her seat and instead of rebuilding, they will follow the same cycle and error ridden decisions which got them to were they are today. Then again, 10-15 years in opposition may be enough for them to try and rebuild to try and mount a credible challenge with an entirely new group of Opposition shadow ministers and a new leader. Wake up the Lil_Andy's on here get into the real world. It's all over for Gillard and Labor.

text: I have enormous sympathy for those less fortunate - my beef is with governments, in this case Labor and Rudd, who created an environment which encouraged these poor souls onto dangerous boat journeys to Australia - the result? hundreds if not thousands of men, woman and children dying needlessly at sea because K Rudd thought he would score political points by messing with the Coalition's border protection policy. I'm surprised to see you supporting Rudd on this one. Also, fyi, I have lived in 3rd world countries, African and Asian, for many years and experienced first hand the squalor, deprivation, death and desperation that famine, wars and starvation brings to communities - Rudd went down a path that actually added to the misery of the genuine refugees - remembering that a large portion of these 'boat people' are purely economic opportunists in no danger at home and simply trying to forge a better life in Australia for them and their families by beating the established UNHCR processes.
author: TimOfAltona

The key to this is working closely with Indonesia to halt the corruption facilitating the boat departures. A huge challenge diplomatically but one worth pursuing. Your asylum assessment in refugee camps argument is valid, but the long wait for this process means people will still go with the boat option if it is available and as of today it is.

text: Daisy, just a quick question  Will you be keeping this daily barrage up for the next 9+ years of a Coalition govt or will you be shutting up shop when the Labor social media unit is closed down on Sunday?  Just interested to know. Thanks.

text: Daisy, are you going to be keeping this daily barrage for the next 9 years or so while the Libs are in government - or do you quit when Labor's social media unit is dismantled on Sunday?
author: TimOfAltona

text: If he retains his seat, Rudd will be dropped from the leadership like a hot potato and then he will retire which paves the way for Bill Glasson to win Griffith in the by-election.
author: TimOfAltona

text: This post-election period will be a great spectator sport watching the ALP implode and reminding us why we voted them onto the opposition benches for the next 9 years or more.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Actually Lenore is doing an excellent job - you however only want to read pro-Labor commentary and get all bitter and twisted when someone points out that Labor are finished.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Settle petal. Don't believe all the Labor spin. Abbott will actually do a very good job as PM. Throw your support behind him and you will feel a whole lot better to be backing the winning side - guaranteed
author: TimOfAltona

text: Perhaps if Labor governments did not stuff up our economy there would be no need for cost cutting with incoming conservative govts. The cycle repeats itself - Conservative governments create the wealth and savings, Labor govts spend all the money and place us in debt, conservative govts come back into power and fix up Labor's fiscal mess. This cycle has been ongoing for the past 50 years.
author: TimOfAltona

text: That is a gross over-reach and gross misrepresentation. Typical of Labor's tactics. Abbott has said we will play no part militarily so we are not following the American's into anything. Our contribution is through the Security Council seat.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Hey Daisy - there is a rich offering of personal and demeaning insults about Julie Bishop, Sophie Mirabella, Bronwyn Bishop and Peta Credlin from Labor supporters doing the rounds.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Katharine @2.16 - How many blue so called labor base people do you think stopped their Father's Day actvities to crowd around the tele to watch Rudd and his campaign launch?
author: TimOfAltona

text: I'll contend that these people have already decided on their voting intentions and decided they don't like what they have seen in Labor,particularly revolving leadership doors,back stabbing and dysfunctionality.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Easy, Liberal's will be power for the next 3 terms at least while Labor languish and stew on the opposition benches playing revolving doors with leaders and musical chairs with shadow ministers.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Don't let it bother you Marcia - Labor has a great tradition of releasing policy costings on the eve of an election. I reckon it's pretty safe to bet my house on the fact that you could see nothing wrong with this approach in 2007 and 2010?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Your problem is that Murdoch is not backing your team. If Murdoch was backing Rudd this time, as he did in 2007, you and the hundreds of other Murdoch bashers in these forums would be silent.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Rudd will know he has zero chance of winning on Saturday and that his days in politics are nearly over - attending the G20 as Australia's PM will provide a major boost to his UN leadership aspirations. The networking and lobbying would be invaluable for him.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Rudd may as well make his concession speech at tomorrow's campaign launch. What a joke - 80-90% of those attending know they have zero chance of winning the election yet have to portray a positive persona.
author: TimOfAltona

text: So, if Abbott had said something before the House of Commons vote you would have condemned him for it, and now he has said something after the House of Commons vote you condemn him. What exactly would you have him do about Syria that you would find acceptable?
author: TimOfAltona

text: He won't. Why would Abbott want to be marching to Obama's tune? Obama's Democrats are buddy buddy with Rudd and Labor, Abbott has no interest in following Obama's lead on this and he won't. If anything here, Rudd is more likely to get us involved through his friendship with Obama. Abbott is right when he says we are kidding ourselves if we think we can or will contribute anything militarily to this situation. Our contribution will be through our seat at the security council.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You guys are delusional. Why would Abbott be beholden to the Obama administration - Obama's Democrats are aligned with the ALP and Rudd. Abbott has no reason or desire to be seen marching to Obama's tune and won't. Settle down children.
author: TimOfAltona

text: So the bottom line is that if Abbott takes caution on Syria you condemn him and if Abbott takes a harder line on Syria you condemn him - what would you suggest he does that would be acceptable to you?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Your comments are getting more and more delusional and irrelevant to the debate. You need to settle down a bit - are you going to try and keep this up for the next 9 years?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Valid point on Libya - where did all that money go?  Abbott is probably the one who is erring on the side of caution - which is a good thing in this matter and he is correct when he say's we are kidding ourselves if we think Australia can make any meaningful military contribution. Our contribution is in the Security Council alone.
author: TimOfAltona

text: All you and so many other rusted on Labor people want to talk about is media bias as the reason Labor are about to be crushed. Wake up to yourselves and think about how differently this all could have been for Labor if the party had not lost it's way.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You're biggest problem is that you only want to see comment and articles which are pro Labor and pro Rudd. When you don't see those you immediately accuse people of poor journalism, bias, conspiracies etc etc' . Most of these journos call it as they see it and heaven knows Labor have given them plenty of ammunition to write negative stories about Labor over the past 6 years
author: TimOfAltona

text: It's because they know they are well and truly beaten, so the only thing left is to lash out in this forum - it makes them feel a little better to let off steam and this is the only MSM that will allow their delusional rants to be published.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Yawn....this is sounding like a broken record from Labor. C'mon guys you know you will only get the costings when the coalition are ready and at a time that suits their campaign. Labor have applied exactly the same tactic in past elections.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Give away demanding the costings - it will make no difference to the outcome of the election - Australia has decided to no longer wants Rudd as PM - simple as that.
author: TimOfAltona

text:
I have just telephoned Mr Abbott to convey my congratulations on his comprehensive win in today's election 
 *boos from the crowd ring out*  *Deb O'Neil yelling Shame Shame"*
author: TimOfAltona

text: We in the Australian Labor Party will be protecting the rights and aspirations of all Australians and we will never give up in prosecuting the case for what is right and fair
author: TimOfAltona

text: 1.Rudd was thrown out by his own party (nothing to do with Murdoch)2.Gillard was brought in as an experiment (nothing to do with Murdoch)3.Rudd continually white anted and undermined Gillard's tenure as PM (nothing to do with Murdoch)4.Rudd knifes Gillard to take back his ALP leadership (nothing to do with Murdoch - unless you think Rudd and Murdoch were working together)
author: TimOfAltona

text: Anyone see the Greens policy launch in Melb this morning - some fellow dancing around the stage with scarves in his hands and doing forward rolls before stripping off his shirt exposing green paint on his torso.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Perhaps over the next decade or so while in opposition Labor will analyse why it all went so horribly wrong for them and try to cobble together an alternative government.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I wonder if the Guardian or Lenore are going to report that Treasury have publicly called Rudd's $10bn black hole claim a fraud - pretty much every other media outlet is reporting on this today.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Labor will only just hold it together for one more week then standby for the bloodletting, headrolling and analysis on how Rudd and Hawker delivered Labor such a resounding defeat.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Not as much as some of Labor's front bench have. Question? Which current minister stayed for free on more than one occasion with his family at Eddie Obeid's ski lodge?Answer - Immigration Minister Tony Burke!!!
author: TimOfAltona

text: Ah ha - I smell yet another labor conspiracy theory that whole world is against them, particularly that pesky media who very annoyingly report on Labor's failings - if only the media would go away Rudd may be able to bluff/con his way back.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You must have missed the first half which interviewed Malcolm Turnbull on a range of campaign issues. It was quite interesting to hear Malcolms take on some of the coalition policies. Sorry you missed that part.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You want the Guardian to only promote positive propaganda about Rudd and seem to be disappointed. Perhaps you should start reading newspapers that will only report the government in a positive light, here's a list of suggestions that may suit you -
author: TimOfAltona

text: David, your questions are too late - no ones taking any notice of your comments apart from other Labor supporters watching the dying days of a Labor government. Keep going if it makes you feel better, but as you and everyone else well knows, it's all over for Labor in 2013.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I still maintain, a vote for the Coalition on Sept 07 is a vote for Turnbull.After all he is next cab off the rank for Liberal leadership and should Abbott stumble in the first term, Malcolm is ready to go. Malcolm cannot be PM sitting in the opposition.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I think we are at the stage that it does not matter a toss what the Govt say about Tony Abbott - people have simply stopped listening to their daily barrage of negativity.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Gabrielle I think you are right - Rudd knows within himself the battle is lost.He must be contemplating what he will do after the election. Strong rumors are he was banking on winning the election to boost his chances of replacing Ban Ki-moon at the UN - lobbying for that role would have immeasurably easier if he was Australian PM. With the prime ministership now beyond him, the UN Role will be harder, if not impossible to obtain. Being the consumate diplomat, the Coalition could do worse by giving him a senior overseas posting - perhaps the UN?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Rudd - Opposition Leader? Your'e kidding right. Rudd will be dropped like a hot potato after he loses the election. The faceless union men wil be calling for blood and Rud will be despatched as quickly as you can say "$75,000 to billionaires"
author: TimOfAltona

text: Interesting thing, the betting markets have opened on what time on Saturday Rudd will concede defeat and call Tony Abbott to offer his congratulations - money is on between 9 + 10 pm so far!
author: TimOfAltona

text: It's all window dressing with Rudd. He presents quite well but is terrible at follow through and implementation. Behind the scenes his leadership is chaotic and dysfunctional - people don't want to work with him - half the Labor front bench walked away when he returned to leadership.. Abbott is a far superior leader and visionary for his party - he has the support of his team. Rudd leads a dysfunctional and divided team.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Now c'mon - you know as well as I that nothing can change the election outcome from here - everyone have already made up their mind to toss Labor out.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Labor were never going to get up off the canvas after Gillard knifed Rudd and never did, so now let's see how the Coalition go for the next 3 years.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Obviously you are referring to the Labor/Greens coalition. Yep, I'm with you. Labor either need to join with the Greens or split from them altogether and stand on their own two feet.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Yes, he looks like he will win (if you go by the polls and the betting markets) which is more a reflection on Labor's toxic brand in Western Sydney than anything else.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Your assertion is flawed. The best way for the poor, disabled or ill-educated to be supported is to have a strong economy which can pay for the necessary assistance programs.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Fire and brimstone will rain down upon us, our cattle will die, our first born daughters will be barren, our crops will wither and die and disease and pestilence will wipe out half the population if Tony Abbott is elected.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You are totally blind to Labor's shortcomings - just like all the other Labor losers in these forums you blame everyone else for Labor's crushing defeat on Saturday. Can you acknowledge that maybe, just maybe Labor have made some contribution to their own demise?
author: TimOfAltona

text: ....but if he were praising Rudd instead of condemning him, you would think Corbett was a sensational CEO and was a man of great wisdom and good character and a great Australian.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott,Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott,Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott,Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott,Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott,Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr AbbottMr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott,Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott,Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott, Mr Abbott

text: I'm picking Milne will step down from the leadership post-election. This is why the Greens are so focussed on trying to keep Bandt in his seat so he can assume leadership.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Had Corbett come out in favour of Rudd, I'm guessing there is a fair chance Tibstar, Janey and Ready Reader would have been silent this morning - or if not silent, would have been praising Corbett for his insight and contribution.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Daisy, nice try -  You omitted that Abbott referenced political suicide - hardly offensive terminology -  How does it go - never let the facts get in the way of a good social media campaign?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Albo will forced to handover his NBN progress report next week - the report he had difficulty locating on his desk and then declared it was only a 'draft'.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Actually there is no desperation in Fiona Scott's campaign at all. She is about to trounce Bradbury with a massive margin. It's all good for her and the Libs.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You would best be advised to focus on how Labor can rebuild their shattered party over the next few years - it is a considerable task and I'd be interested who you think may be the first new ALP leader next week.
author: TimOfAltona

text: ReadyReader - come on, come clean - you know as well as we all do that had Abbott gone on Q&A you would be blasting and condemning every word he uttered and if he does not go on Q&A you spend all day condemning him, as you are now, for not going on. So in your world Tony Abbott can't win either way, right?
author: TimOfAltona

text: ReadyReader - come on, come clean - you know as well as we all do that had Abbott gone on Q&A you would be blasting and condemning every word he uttered and if he does not go on Q&A you spend all day condemning him, as you are now, for not going on.
author: TimOfAltona

text: If you subscribe to the theory, as I do, that a vote for the Coalition is also a vote for Malcolm Turnbull, then I suspect the arts will fare significantly better under a Coalition Govt than under Labor.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Karzai is squirriling away hundreds of millions of dollars which should be going to the country he governs and is supposidly rebuilding - and guess what - we allow him to get away with this.
author: TimOfAltona

text: In the meantime the tens of billions of dollars burned up in Afghanistan will amount to zip, the human rights initiatives particularly as they impact females will be dismantled and Sharia law will prevail once more in country and many urban areas.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Here's the thing - Rudd is very good at spin and often communicates a seemingly credible message, then it all falls over from there. He does not have the ability to implement anything he espouses - this is why he is being tossed out on Saturday.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Griffith voters may as well vote Glasson in now to save themselves the cost and inconvenience of the guaranteed by-election when Rudd retires from politics straight after the election.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Sorry to burst your bubble Mike, but I think the polling stands - Labor are about to be crushed and Julie Bishop will make a fine first female Foreign Minister for Australia.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Well boys and girls, I got up this morning, the sun was shining, the birds were singing and the smell of roast coffee permeated the air, Labor was crushed and Tony Abbott is our new PM.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Well, so far so good. But just in case you guys are right, I'll keep looking out of the window during the day to see if any birds are falling out of the sky.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The first Labor LOTO will probably not still be there at the next election - doubt that Albo or Shorten want the poison chalice just yet. My money's on Bowen.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Interesting to see how many ALP candidates have abandoned the Labor red for their posters and t shirts and adopted the Liberal blue - in may electorates you'd be hard pressed to even spot the Labor logo on their posters - some have dropped it altogether.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You know something? If this was an AFL game there is still 10 minutes of the game to go before he siren. All we need is a quick 26 unanswered goals and we will win!
author: TimOfAltona

text: Delusional - Coalition by 40 odd seats - Labor are about to crushed and for good reason.  Tony Abbott will be a superior PM to Rudd.  Unless of course someone wants to argue that Rudd would be a better PM than Abbott?  *Silence* I thought as much.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Veteran psephologist Malcolm Mackerras has predicted a landslide victory for the Coalition and that Labor leader Kevin Rudd will lose his Brisbane seat of Griffith. Mr Mackerras told Fairfax Media's Tim Lester that he expects the Coalition to win 94 lower house seats with Labor winning 54 and crossbenchers Andrew Wilkie and Bob Katter retaining their seats.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I hope Bob Carr has a hotline to Julie Bishop while he's attending the G20 - he is only there in care taker mode and cannot commit Australia to anything without the Coalition's approval.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Raises an interesting point - Labor will be out of government tomorrow and Carr is over at the G20 - presumably he will have to return home and Julie Bishop flies over - or perhaps he stays there until the Coalition are sworn in?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Interestingly, one of the betting agencies has opened up a market on what time tomorrow Rudd will concede defeat and phone Tony Abbott to congratulate him - Between 9 and 10 pm has all the money on it so far.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Infighting? - wait until Sunday morning and watch the public infighting start in Labor - finger pointing, Gillard camp calling Rudd a fake, Rudd camp blaming Gillard, Labor MP's resigning left right and centre causing by-elections (Griffith included), back stabbing and tears all around.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Perhaps we can spend millions on jet charter and fly 100,000 over and put them up in the seats at the MCG before billeting them out in the homes of Australians'?
author: TimOfAltona

text: The weakness in your argument is that in the case of those two leadership changes it was a change for the better, particularly in Vic.Napthine has put the Libs back into a winning position according to the polls.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Now c'mon Michael, come clean with the Australian people - you know as well as we do that you will never agree with any Coalition ministerial selection - everyone of them will be a dud in your mind and only the great Labor party can put up credible ministers'.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Interesting that reports are surfacing today that Kevin Rudd may be eyeing up a 3rd stint as ALP leader. Not now, but in the future when he thinks Labor have a better chance of victory with him as leader.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Alan, Gillard made many more errors of judgment than the one or two you describe - there were dozens during her period as PM which perpetuated the notion she was politically inept.I can start listing them if you wish but I suspect if you cast your mind back they will soon come to you
author: TimOfAltona

text: May I remind you that she was on track to wipe Labor out at the election- lucky if they came away with 35 seats. In addition she knifed Rudd in 2010 which imploded on her and Labor big time and hence the ALP are where they are today.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Hang on - Abbott hasn't even been sworn in yet and already you're trying to tear down the man who may replace Abbott in 4 or 5 years time.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Of course while all you Labor/Greens supporters are arguing over who will lead the ALP, Abbott is getting on with the business of setting up his new government to take this country forward.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Who would you suggest in the current senior Labor team would be best to lead - given they have all been involved one way or another in the actions you describe?
author: TimOfAltona

text: We are the country holding all the aces here - billions of dollars of Australian aid pouring in, billions of Australian tourist dollars pouring into Bali, just about every Australian aid agency operating up there etc
author: TimOfAltona

text: Tony, like Chris Bowen, is biding his time. Plenty of time for either of them to become leader in the next few years. Whoever takes the leadership now won't last the distance.
author: TimOfAltona

text: She has so much to offer? To whom? Certainly not the Labor party where she would have delivered something like 38 seats for Labor in the election had she not been pushed out. Massive failure at any examination.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Exactly my point - Labor supporters want her head on a platter because of who she is and your wrath is worse because you've just been smashed at an election.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Assuming Mirabella is gone and Bronwyn Bishop becomes Speaker you are correct. I'm with you, Sussan Ley would make a great govt minister.She's held a number of shadow minister portfolios already and acquitted herself well - she must be under consideration.
author: TimOfAltona

text: 2. Using the good old 'we have a mandate' line. Nothing like the word 'mandate' to raise the hackles of everyone. All incoming govts use it. Labor and Liberal. Abbott would be far better off not using the mandate argument - it's too easily shot down.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Now there's two outgoing Labor ministers' biding their time for ALP leadership, Bowen and Burke. They know only too well that whoever gets the gig now will never be PM.
author: TimOfAltona

text: There is no way he will want to stick around in parliament for 3 years as an MP when his vote is meaningless given the numbers the coalition have - most likely vote with the Libs anyway.
author: TimOfAltona

text: It's not like he needs the MP salary, he'll get bored, pull the pin and trigger a by-election - that's 2 more seats going to the Coalition in time, Fairfax and Griffith.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Funny I don't recall at any time Abbott sticking a knife in Gillard's back - only Kevin Rudd achieved that after 3 years of white anting and planned destabilisation.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Abbott was LOTO - pretty much in their job description to win back govt at the next election - Labor will be doing the same now - it's how our democracy works.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Christine Milne with her 1 seat in a 150 seat parliament and a weakened Greens senate speaks as if she is the opposition leader and will be stopping the new government from passing bills they were elected to introduce by voters.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Can someone give this woman a reality check and tell her that now that Labor have been defeated, the Greens no longer have the ability to hold their ideaology gun to the head of Australians to force them to follow Greens policies?
author: TimOfAltona

text: I don't disagree with you at all - she is the Coalition's worst performer - I could never understand why they kept sending her along to sit on the Q&A panel - disaster.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Will make very interesting reading highlighting the roll out incompetencies coupled with huge cost blowouts and years of delay ahead. Let's see how close Turnbull was in his $90bn prediction.
author: TimOfAltona

text: They will never be a force in their own right in Australian politics. Labor will prop them up for a while longer yet - but once they lose their senate seats (& they will eventually) the Greens will go the same way as the Democrats.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I nominate Kevin Rudd to sit on the Advisory Panel of Elders - he is after all a two time PM for Labor - and perhaps heading for a 3rd time.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I'm guessing there will be more females in Cabinet in the second term and most definitely more in the 3rd term. By the 4th term I reckon there will be around 5 females in the Coalition Cabinet.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The 7 boats have arrived under Rudd's watch - which is nothing new as tens of thousands of boat people have arrived and 1000+ have drowned under Labor's watch.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You know as well as I that there is nothing Abbott can do from here on in that you would agree with - so bitter and twisted you are from the crushing of Labor - it's all about retribution for you and the other regular Labor cheer squad in these threads.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You just don't get it do you. Gillard was destroyed from within the Labor party - you know, those guys and gals in the Rudd camp who continually white-anted and undermined Gillard?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Presumably you are admitting that Labor did bugger all so now corprate corruption is flourishing and it's up to the Coalition to have to come in and clean it up.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Yes, there are an unusually low number of women in the new Cabinet but ultimately the Coalition will be judged on their performance, not how many men or women they have in Cabinet.
author: TimOfAltona

text: If they underperform the entire Labor cheer squad will be all over them irrespective of their gender - look how much abuse Julie Bishop cops from the Labor mob already. I'm sure the vitriol would be extended to Kelly O'Dwyer or any other senior female Liberal MP if she were to be placed in Cabinet.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Nice try - how about we ask the question when is Kevin Rudd going to make another push for ALP leadership - there is already a campaign going on by Rudd supporters - Shorten or Albo wll have to fend off Rudd down the track - here we go again..
author: TimOfAltona

text: Tony Abbott made it very clear before and during the election campaign that should the Coalition gain government he would essentially be carrying over his opposition front bench into government. He was always going to have to shed two because his opposition front bench exceeded the permissable numbers for government. Since then Mirabella has lost her seat, Bronwyn Bishop has (rightfully) been elevated to the Speaker's chair which leaves the only female ,Julie Bishop, in cabinet.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Abbott has pretty much done what he said he would do before the election. There are future female Cabinet Ministers' in the outer ministry. I don't recall hearing all this argument before the election and it is not as if we did not see this coming - apart from Mirabella leaving and Cormann coming in - this is the cabinet team the Coalition took into the election.
author: TimOfAltona

text: How's the hapless Chris Bowen trying to land a punch by talking about the Afghan ministry - if that's the best he can come up with no wonder he is acting-ALP leader.
author: TimOfAltona

text: No point continuing with the doom and gloom campaign - you and your comrades need to allow the new government to settle in and give them some clear air to implement adult governance and deliver on the many policies they were voted in by Australia to achieve.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The contrast with Labor couldn't be greater - no longer will we see Cabinet reshuffles every few months with some portfolios changing hands 4 and 5 times because of instability and leadership dysfunction.
author: TimOfAltona

text: A few more women in cabinet would be ideal but there are plenty in the outer ministry who will be well placed to step into cabinet roles in the second and third terms.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Shorten will still be hovering and find a way to get into the roll when it appears Labor are more competitive in the polls - but he may have to fight it out with Rudd to get there.
author: TimOfAltona

text: David, I look forward to your live commentary sinking the boot into every Coalition front bench member as they are announced - only 30 or so to go - we're in for a long day.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I don't think it matters who the Coalition put into the Speakers chair, the Labor cheer squad will attack the decision and as per their usual MO, the person too.
author: TimOfAltona

text: To provide some much needed balance - Harry Jenkins was a brilliant Speaker and it is a real shame Gillard cut him down to further her own personal political agenda.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Fair enough - but you've at least got to give him a chance. If he stuffs it up you're justified in having a go but give it a bit of time - he's not even PM yet - Rudd still is.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Thay haven't said that at all - they said they don't agree with 2 elements of the Coalition's border protection policy - buying boats and paying for intellience from locals on people smugglers.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Neither of those two were ever going to get up and running - the big one is turning around boats where it is safe to so. That'll be interesting to see if they can get that happening.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I reckon half of you will give up on your daily abuse when it becomes clear that we are in for an extended period of good governance in this country.
author: TimOfAltona

text: They want to see and hear from him so they can rip into everything he says, vilify and tear him down in their own very special way that we have come to know.
author: TimOfAltona

text: On the premise that whoever leads the ALP straight after a crushing defeat will never be a Labor PM, Albo will win and take up the leadership - Shorten will bide his time and move on the leadership nearer the time he thinks the ALP can win.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Exactly - that's why she was on track to bring home a resounding victory for the ALP in the election - she would have crushed the Coalition and sent them into the political wilderness for years.
author: TimOfAltona

text: To provide some balance to this article, the following article by Katharine Murphy of the Guardian should also be digested - it provides good insight and a reflection on the failings for Labor during the Gillard era.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Get over it Alan - you've lost the election. No point crying over what might have been. The dud Labor government are gone and we now have an adult government leading the country for the next decade.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Because there were too many 'Julia's' put up when she was in office - her spin merchants were going flat out trying to come up with one that would resonate with the electorate - big fail there.

text: I put it to you that Tony Abbott has received more than his share of below-the-belt abuse and vilification from the Left - particularly since last Saturday. So by your definition, he must be on track to be doing a great job.

text: Alison, read this article by Katharine Murphy of the Guardian and it may open your eyes a bit, it makes interesting reading and provides some much needed balance -

text: Alison,chances are if you had swapped your vote to the Greens, you would still have been voting for Labor, such was the tight preference flows between Greens and Labor the old addage applies - a vote for the Greens is a vote for Labor.

text: I believe Julia Gillard is a good person but hopelessly inadequate as a Labor PM who allowed herself to be scripted and manipulated by her failed Scottish communications director - she would have served Labor better by staying in the education portfolio, where her true strengths lay and allowing others to lead the party.

text: To provide some balance to this article, the following article by Katharine Murphy of the Guardian should also be digested - it provides good insight and a reflection on the failings for Labor during the Gillard era. Have a read - http://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jun/26/julia-gillard-where-go-wrong

text: I agree - how dare the Opposition act like an Opposition. They should have rolled over and given Labor a free ride for 3 years without any criticism at all. text: Yes, the media did negatively report on Gillard and her administration, largely fuelled by white-anting and backgrounding by elements of her own party (Team Rudd). text: As much as the Labor/Greens cheersquad would have us believe, there is no media black out on boat arrivals - as you say, there are plenty of other sources for that kind of information - the govt is simply saying they will release official figures weekly.
author: TimOfAltona

text: If you tune into the weekly media briefing you will learn about boat arrival activity - as much as you would love there to be, there are no media blackouts on boat arrivals.

text: Bottom line in someone has to take charge and deliver on the coalition's pledge to stop the illegal boats. It will never happen with 16 different govt agencies running around uncoordinated and without central leadership.

text: Mate, the idea is that people don't get on the boats in the first place. That is the priority - everything the coalition are doing is to disrupt and ultimately destroy the smugglers business model.

text: You seem to think that men, women and children paying to board boats that have already been sabotaged to sink at any time, all risk drowning with the survivors spirited out of Christmas Island within 48 hrs to Manus or Nauru never to set foot on Australian soil is a viable product for people smugglers? Hmmmmmm.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The coalition are on the right track here and there is no media ban. Tune into the weekly media briefings to learn how a successful government is dealing with this problem.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Remember, we do live in a democracy and In 3 years time you will have the opportunity to vote out this government if they have failed to perform. If everything the Labor/Greens cheersquadders are saying in these forums are true then the Abbott government will be well and truly voted out.

text: If you want the boats to keep arriving, just say so. If you don't, let the coalition get on with the job of fulfilling their election pledge and one of the key platforms of their election win.

text: There will be weekly briefings where arrival information will be disseminated to the media. Other operational information will be disseminated as seen fit by the operational commander - not dissimilar to any other military led operation.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The bottom line is the coalition are going about fulfilling a key election pledge and perhaps it's better we let them get on with it. Nothing in the rules that says they have to use the same failed template Labor used in their disasterous handling of this issue.

text: You will have an opportunity in 3 years time to vote them out if they have not performed. Probably a bit premature calling for that when they have only been in govt for less than 1 week don't you think?

text: I had already guessed you are way way to the left of Labor -perhaps there are some other countries that would be a better place for you to live with like minded folk - let's see.... Cuba, Venezula, North Korea perhaps? In the meantime I guess the CPA is providing you with fellowship here.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You appear to be confused over the election outcome. Labor lost and the Coalition won. Tony Abbott is now PM as a result. If you don't take my word for it hop onto the AEC website and you will see that what I say is the truth.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You all seem a bit confused by your Labor/Greens leanings - there will be a weekly media briefing where boat arrivals (if any) data will be officially released by he minister. You won't be getting he daily update Labor provided.

text: If you renew your subscription to The Australian you can find out what News Ltd are reporting on this - they don't appear to have any concerns with the way the govt is handling this so far.

text: That said, you make an assumption that boats will sink and people will drown - clearly you became accustomed to that during the Labor handling of this issue. The coalition are all about preventing any of that happening at all, so let's all hope that is now a thing of the past.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Gee these Labor/Greens cheersquadders love a good conspiracy theory don't they. I've read a million of them since the Coalition won govt. This a good one above - a member of the navy or customs service is killed while on duty and it's covered up. What a laugh.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Turn back the boats when it is safe to do so is only one policy option available and will be assessed by the navy commander on the spot. If he/she deems it as unsafe it won't be undertaken and the boat will be taken to Christmas Island. Turning back the boats has occurred previously and may or may not be applied depending on the circumstance in each case. Give it a chance and it may just work.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Good to see you are honest enough to admit your'e only on here to shit stir and make it at as difficult as possible for the coalition to deliver on their election commitment.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Looking forward to your comment one day congratulating the coalition on achieving their promise to stop the boats in their first term - despite Labors best attempts to prevent that happening.
author: TimOfAltona

text: To suggest that the govt will keep arrivals secret is Labor induced conspiracy nonsense. By my reckoning there are several hundred people on Christmas Island who all have access to mobile phones, email and twitter who can (and probably will) report on any arrival activity. The govt will be confirming arrivals at their weekly briefings.Doubt very much they would deny arrivals if photos and the twittersphere has been alight during the week depicting arrivals.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Yep - as I said it's only a matter of time. Clearly there will still be opposition amongst Coalition MPs but providing the 60% of Labor MP's who voted against it last time come across then it should make it to the senate. More likely second term I'm picking.

text: Stopping the boats was a key election promise and now they have won the election they are getting down to the business of shutting the gate on illegal boat arrivals.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The consequences of this are that the country will be saved billions of dollars of tax payers money, potentially hundreds of lives will be saved from drowning and it permits the thousands of genuine refugees to proceed to Australia in the orderly refugee intake program.

text: This is of course bad news for the many Labor/Greens cheersquadders on here who are anxious to see the boats keep coming. Nothing would please them more that to see the hundreds of boats arriving since Labor opened the floodgates, to keep arriving.

text: I say give the Coalition a chance to get on with the job and do their best to fix this problem - perhaps even give them a bit of support - it will benefit us all and prevent the possibility of more drownings. Worthy cause one would think.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I think you are being somewhat melodramatic. Let's assume that the Coalition know what they are doing and give them a chance to prevent boat arrivals without condemning them before they even get going.
author: TimOfAltona

text: If they do stop the boats, I hoping you will be the first to congratulate them for a job well done and acknowledge that they have handled this significantly better than Labor.
author: TimOfAltona

text: After all it was Labor under Rudd that first opened the flood gates and caused the tens of thousands of arrivals and 1000+ people drowning at sea. The Coalition are going to do everything possible to close the gates on the biggest Labor stuff up in a generation.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You need to give them a chance to stop the boats - if they do so then those places won't be required. Contingency plans are the sign of a competent government. Something that Labor got caught out time and time again over this issue.
author: TimOfAltona

text: In fact, they derive so much joy from every boat that arrives that they flock to the Guardian comments sections to congratulate each other and themselves for their outstanding contribution to the Labor cause. "Bring on the boats" they shriek from the roof tops - "we told you the Coalition wouldn't stop the boats" say the cheersquadders who have blamed every boat arrival from roughly 10pm on election night on Tony Abbott.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The cheersquadders worst nightmare and causes them to wake at night in cold sweats is the Coalition actually may stop the boats. The Coalition may actually succeed in preventing men, women and children drowning at sea.

text: Tom, he has the knowledge and experience in co-ordinating large scale, multi agency operations. I doubt a civil servant would have the required background to pull off such a massive and critical operation across 12 large government agencies (incl navy, airforce and perhaps army) working to protect our northern borders and halting the people smuggling trade.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I expect you are still seething from the thrashing Labor received at the polls so let's get real here, there will be nothing, but nothing, Abbott or the Coalition Govt does that you will agree with. You and the rest of the Labor/Greens cheersquad will be slamming everything they say or do.

text: So while you're mired in bitterness and hatred, the coalition are getting on with the business of govt and quietly sorting out the many failures created by Labor in the past 6 years.

text: If you hop onto the Liberal website - www.liberal.org.au - it details how this will work and you will clearly see how the 12 government agencies are coming together under one operational and ministerial command.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Under Labor all these agencies were uncoordinated which lead to a breakdown of intelligence, response capability and overall effectiveness. The Coalition's plan looks like being fairly effective in combating people smugglers' - time will tell.

text: While you're on the Liberal website you may as well take the opportunity to join up and get your membership underway.This way you can be a part of the success of the Coalition govt over the next 9 years or so by actively participating in the actvities of your local Liberal branch.

text: Not at all - I was critical of the Steve Bracks decision and also critical of the coalition bandying around the word 'mandate' because nothing raises the hackles more than that word and it's too easily shot down.

text: Politically, he always supported the government of the day and bravely fought against the Nazis and Japanese in the 1940's and then switched his sights to the war on socialism in the 1950's.

text: Abbott always said if the tax review or the states pushed for GST revision nothing would happen in the first term - he would take any GST change proposals (if any at all) to the next election and allow the electorate to decide. Funny thing is it is Liberal WA and Labor ACT who are calling for GST revision.

text: Rudd did not make any immediate changes (like Abbott) to public service heads in 2007 - he waited for a few months. Howard got rid of some APS heads as did Keating when he came in.

text: Perhaps it may be better for you to focus on the problems down at camp Labor and propose how they will be able to pick themselves up and dust themselves off and try and get back into contention over the next few years.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Clearly he did not say that - that's your manufactured interpretation. He did say there would be sweeping changes to the public service which included cutting numbers (several thousand over time) and review structures and personnel. As per my comment above - Abbott needs to work in close partnership with key public service heads and it's his call entirely who he wants in those roles - all incoming change of governments do this.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The new government need to work in close partnership with senior public servants and they have to make the call on who's in and who's out to achieve that level of confidence.

author: TimOfAltona

text: So the message I hear is on one hand Abbott should be condemned for having not enough Liberal/National females in Cabinet but any females he could choose from are useless and a waste of time and space. Just read some of the comments about senior Liberal women from the Labor camp in these forums.

text: You gotta be kidding - so you would be happy with Labor coming away from the election with 38 seats (if they were lucky) with Gillard in charge. Would have all but ruled out Labor for a generation or more.

text: Good comment - the lefties on here will have nowhere to go soon - Abbott will be delivering on his promises and they'll still be thrashing around in their bitter and twisted world of denial and defeat.

She was a massive failure for Labor.

text: While you languish and long for a return to the bad old Gillard days, the new government is getting down to the business of government and working hard to mop up the failures of the Rudd-Gillard-Rudd years.

text: This why Australia voted them in. No amount of bitter and sordid vilification directed towards the government from a handful of losers in this thread who voted for Rudd changes the fact that the Coalition, with a massive majority in the Lower House and likely control of the senate in July, are only 3 weeks into a very long period of government, perhaps 9 years or more.

text: Australia specifically provided/donated Indonesia with superceded RAN patrol boats for anti- people smuggling duties - guess where Indonesia have deployed these vessels? In the north - well away from any people smuggling activity.

text: Complex lingusitic analysis has confirmed that this person Mark Norrie is clearly a sad ideological supporter of the failed communist regime in Cuba and has only just emerged from mourning the death of Venezula's Hugo Chavez. Dude you are so outed......

text: He's actually a key guest at the North Melbourne Grand Final breakfast in full view of the media and hundreds of thousands of footy fans around the country - hardly hiding is he?

text: Mate your talking crap - Indonesia requested Australian navy assistance because there were no Indonesian search and rescue assets in the area - Australian navy responded. It has nothing to do with any agreements between govts.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Hey I thought you were going along really well - you started with this is not a Labor v Coalition issue, needs to be addressed in a bipartisan manner - all good - and then you launched into your usual anti-Coalition rhetoric.
author: TimOfAltona

text: They are trying to prevent the boats departing Indonesian shores. It is widely recognised that Rudd opened up the floodgates when he dismantled the Howard Pacific solution and now this govt is trying to shut the gate again - exactly the same as Labor were doing when they lost govt a couple of weeks ago.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Perhaps it's time the Labor/Greens cheersquad give up on trying to use this for their own vilification agenda and get in and support the Coalition to do what it can to stop the boats and stop the drownings of men, women and as we saw yesterday many many children.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Australia has a proud tradition of humanely accepting hundreds of thousands of refugees from all corners of the world in the past 100 years and continue to do so today.
author: TimOfAltona

text: There was no boat turnaround - the boat was 6 nautical miles off the South Java coast when it started sinking. Indonesian search and rescue attended the scene and started recovering bodies from the water.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Someone has to tell the Indonesians to pull their head in and start seriously tackling the illegal boats - not leaving Australia to do all the heavy lifting while hundreds drown.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Alexander Downer may be a former Foreign Minister but he is now a private citizen, has been sine July 14 2008 - as much as Labor/Greens supporters want to represent him as a spokesperson for the government, he is entiled to his opinion and he is spot on with his observations.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You comment is a great example of why 90% of the comments posted by Labor/Greens cheersquad are irrelevant and superfluous to any debate. It's all mindless nonsense posted by bitter and twisted people who saw their beloved Labor/Greens government thrown out of office in spectacular fashion.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Bring on the boats, bring on the drownings, long may the people smugglers operation continue while there is a Coalition govt in office you say. Only Labor can 'stop the boats' you say.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The people smuggler kingpins have key people in these agencies on their payroll to allow them to operate with impunity - exactly the same MO as the drug cartels in Mexico. The profits from people smuggling operations run into millions of USD per year.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I'm looking forward the Coalition taking on the Indonesians over this and applying some pressure - we have a fair bit of leverage given we throw hundreds of millions of dollars of Australian taxpayers money at the Indonesians each year calling it 'aid'.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Time for Matelagawa to pull his head in and start shouldering some of the heavy lifting to stop the boats instead of leaving it all up to Australia to do.
author: TimOfAltona

text: It is an assumption - Indonesia asked for help from the Australian navy which entered Indonesian waters to effect the rescue - the big difference being that if we had a Labor government the people on the boat would have been transported all the way back to Christmas Island. Now that we have a competent govt in control, the people were returned to Indonesia.
author: TimOfAltona

text: No, Downer is actually spot on. The Indonesians have been taking us for a ride for a long time. We channel billions of dollars of 'aid' into the Indonesian govt each year and in return they send us illegal boats.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Bowen sounds the alarm on........."quick I'd better say something about this before the Australian people cotton on to how irrelevant the ALP are now - Kevin come back, Labor needs you"
author: TimOfAltona

text: As far as I recall Alexander Downer is a private citizen and is entitled to his opinion - you make out like he is still Foreign Minister and your rhetoric is full of exaggerations and mis-representations on a whole range of issuess which is pretty standard for the Labor/Greens cheersquadders on here.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Downer is right by the way - the Indonesians need to have respect for our sovereignty - it is Indonesian vessels that are illegally entering Australia's 24 nautical mile maritime zone and we have every right as a sovereign nation to protect our borders - exactly the same as the US Coast Guard do with illegal refugee Cuban boats entering US territorial waters and Italian Coast Guard do with illegal refugee Algerian and Libyan boats coming into Italian waters. It's called border protection - something that is lost on the labor cheer squad.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You seem to be a little angry, you only want to read commentary that is critical of the Govt, anything else is clearly unacceptable and you attack the author - perhaps you may like to move across to Independent Australia - it's full of Left fringe dwellers making comments like yours.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I sense your growing frustration. The left need Abbott visible on a daily basis to keep up their vilification. It's ripping the Left apart that they are being denied that daily dose of manufactured bile and hatred they so clearly enjoy participating in.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Labor/Greens cheersquad don't like Abbott as a small target - they would much prefer he be in the news day in day out so they can vilify him on anything and everything he says - I suspect they are getting a bit annoyed that he is denying them that pleasure - hence the frustration in many of these comments.

WAYNE Swan charged taxpayers more than $12,000 to fly him and two of his children to the AFL Grand final by VIP jet when he was acting prime minister in 2010. 
The following day the then treasurer and his advisers took a taxpayer-funded RAAF flight from Brisbane to Sydney to watch the NRL Grand Final. 
The Australian has checked Mr Swan's travel records, confirming he took the trips on October 2 and October 3, 2010.

text: Great to see PM Tony Abbott improving relations with Malaysia. These are important steps forward for our relations with Malaysia and will assist with trade relations along with other benefits.

text: Yiou Labor/Greens cheer squadders are hopeless - trying to whip up something that does not exist. I guess it gives you a little bit of satisfaction for the crushing of Labor on Sept 07.

text: All media outlets, print, radio & TV were reporting and providing oxygen to those issues - not just News Ltd. Were you reading the Fairfax and ABC reports?  You are so self-consumed and obssessed with News Ltd it's gotta be unhealthy.  The same question applies to you - had Murdoch and News Ltd been supporting Labor in the 2013 election would you be posting hundreds of rants condemning News Ltd for treating the Coalition unfairly?  Of course not.

text: Had Murdoch been backing the ALP then I'm pretty sure you would be silent on this, or would you be ranting that Murdoch was giving Labor an unfair advantage and should pull his head in? Doubt it.

text: ...as opposed to those who abhor ALP corruption and want it addressed. Have you been keeping up with the NSW ALP leader John Robertson and his links to McGurk and Obeid?

text: We are just waiting on the article that discusses the 60 odd claims from Labor MP's over the past few years that have been repaid, from Julia Gillard down.

text: Politicians of all persuasions have been caught up in expense claim repayments (Labor MPs for example, from PM Gillard down, have been caught up in expense claim reimbursements, around 60 I believe, over the past few years).

text: You so desperately want Abbott to be caught up in this way, but reality is he has done nothing outside the rules or the accepted practice of how these things are handled.

text: Where ambiguity exists repayment is the right thing to do and I'm guessing most MP's, Labor and Liberal will be examining past claims that may be construed as borderline with a view to repayment.

text: I think a prominent Labor MP who happens to be a avid cycling fan will be revisiting his claims for a 'cycling' study tour of France at tax payers expense which just happened to coincide with the final stage of the Tour de France

text: I suspect going forward the rules will be tightened to remove ambiguity, so even past PM's like Julia Gillard won't be caught out again as she was over Comm Car repayments due to unauthorised use of Commonwealth cars by her partner Tim Mathieson.

text: Not wondering at all - It's called a democratic election - you know, when a very bad government is thrown out of office by voters who want a new government to try and fix up all the mess of the past 6 years.

text: These 6 or 7 are still wounded from Labor's crushing defeat on Sept 7 so all they have left is to blindly lash out at the person they believe responsible for Labor's demise.

text: They totally fail to see that it was the ALP themselves who made the biggest contribution to their own downfall. Somehow the poisonous years of the Rudd v Gillard destabilisation have been swept under the carpet and they only have Tony Abbott in their sights.

text: Wasting their time and energy - Abbott is here to stay for a very long time. His presence and stature is growing each week, particularly now he is on the world stage.

text: In the meantime - Labor are missing in action - yet to emerge from their burrow since being decimated at the election and trying to work out who will be their interim leader until Rudd inevitably returns to the leadership down the track. Acting Leader Chris Bowen is certainly counting the numbers for Rudds eventual return. Plenty of turmoil and dysfunctionality ahead for team Labor.

text: Katharine Murphy and hundreds of other readers know full well the context of her use of the word recruit - not what you erroneously want it to be to suit your Labor/Greens Cheer Squad ranting.

text: Perhaps you should check out what Cuba's Havana Herald has written about this - maybe it will be leaning more towards what you crave from the media, failing that maybe give North Korea's Pyongyang Post a try?

text: Sorry, you'll need to be more specific - if for world leaders who are proven liars are you referring to Gillard's statement "There will be no carbon tax under a government I lead" and then for thieves you are referring to the investigation into Gillard's role in the AWU slush fund then I guess you perhaps answered your own question?

text: PM Abbott will go up there with the largest delegation of Australian business and political leaders ever to have talks in China. This is the way it should be.

text: Before the Labor Cheer Squad shoot this comment down in flames with their highly predictable anti-Abbott rants, this visit will build on the good work already done by Gillard, Labor & DFAT in furthering sino-Australian relationships before Gillard was deposed by her party. Not a bad effort from someone who by her own admission was not adept at Foreign affairs.

text: How about to wait until he has been PM for a bit longer before launch an attack on him for what he may do in the future on this issue. You know this is one of his passions - he's been going up to indigenous communities for something like 15 years now - way before media were showing any interest. Saying he only goes up there for photo opportunities really highlights your partisan ignorance.

text: I think you'll find that over the next 3 years Abbott will do more for indigenous matters than any other PM - he is totally committed to this cause.

text: Clearly that will upset you and other Labor supporters because you only want to see him fail and you will be quick to throw scorn on any progress he makes in this area.

text: She is gutsy telling it like it is and perhaps if more Labor MPs stood up to the factional deal making and epidemic of faceless men controlling the party, Labor will be a better party for it.

text: Why is Anna Burke still Speaker and doing Speaker's duties? I could swear we had a change of government recently and Tony Abbott is the new PM and Bronwyn Bishop is the new Speaker?

text: Not true - let's get back to the basics - both Labor and the Coalition are trying to stop the boats departing Indonesia - none of us want to see drownings at sea - the Coalition are going about it their way and I think we should give them a go and support any initiative that halts or severely curtails boat departures.

text: If you don't support the government's initiatives in Operation Sovereign Borders then in the absence of a better plan, you must be in favor of people risking the voyage by boat.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Your support for the government's initiatives is commendable. They are doing all they can to stop these boats departing Indonesia in the first place. Immigration Minister Scott Morrison has just returned from another visit to Indonesia where he met with senior Indonesian govt officials in working with them for more co-operation in preventing boat departures.
author: TimOfAltona

text: LOL - from the afternoon of the swearing in of the new government thefinnigans has been screaming out several times a day "call an election now" - in fact I recall he was claiming on a daily basis that "this is the worst government ever" even before the government was sworn in!!

text: I don't think it has even occurred to him that a) Labor has no leader to go to an election with and b) that an Australian Federal Government runs a term of 3 years - we do not call federal elections every few weeks.

text: Hey Alan, you realise don't you that your comment reflects perfectly why Labor was thrown out of office into the political gutter on Sept 7 and will remain there for at least 3 terms - that's 9 years Alan. 9 years.

text: My take on this is that most people complaining about this on here, alan included, don't really give a rats arse whether they hear about people in detention attempting self harm or not. They just see this as another chance to take another swing at the government and try and push their anti-Abbott rhetoric on pretty much any subject that comes up.

text: The Coalition are spot-on. These people in detention who attempt self harm will be cared for and megaphoning their action achieves nothing - unless you are a Labor cheer squad member who think this a great opportunity to once again criticise the government.

text: So an extension of what your are saying is that anyone who attempts self harm while in detention or custody in Australia should have their action publicised in the media?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Ok - each day in Australian prisons somewhere around 10 people attempt self harm in one form or another - let's have these reported each day in the media, just so everything is transparent and the governments are not hiding anything and the population informed.

text: I think you have got a bit confused - Morrison said it was never government policy to tow back the boats - not turn back the boats as you claim.

text: We are dealing with desperate people here and unfortunately some of these people may be encouraged to engage in these acts if they feel they will receive media exposure as a result.

text: There's a fantastic article on Chris Bowen (recently acting Leader of the ALP) and how he is defending Kevin Rudd against Roxon's attack and thinks Kevin is around for the long term.

text: I want to make one glaring observation regarding the comments, hundreds if not thousands of them posted in these threads by the Labor cheer squad during the election campaign.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Every comment posted was a personal attack on Tony Abbott - nothing was mentioned about Rudd at all. No one defending him, saying he was doing a good job or was a great leader for Labor - everyone was totally obsessed with Tony Abbott.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You keep on saying Gillard should never have been removed - obviously the rant of a masochist who delights in seeing Labor wiped out the election and coming away with 30 something seats.

text: So while the Labor cheer squad tear each other apart (just like their party) over Roxon's speech, the government is getting on with the business of governing and getting us out of the mess that 6 years of a divided and dysfunctional Labor government created for this country.

text: Daisy - Gillard and Roxon conspired to put her into a role Gillard knew full well she was going to pull the pin on before the election.This enabled Roxon to preserve her hefty ministerial pension which would otherwise have been dramatically reduced had she stayed around for the election and either gone into opposition or lost her seat.It was a stich up by Gillard looking after her friend.

text: That scenario is not out of the question when Shorten's polling starts to point south and Rudd's is pointing north once more. The very rules Rudd brought in to protect his own leadership do allow for leadership change under certain circumstances.

text: This is exactly why Labor are in the political wilderness - they look the other way when it comes to criticism and the failings of their own party and instead of facing up to it, they try and sweep it under the carpet and hope people don't notice.

text: Labor cheer squad need to acknowledge that things are not going all that well for Labor and perhaps discuss how they can turn it around instead of blindly attacking Tony Abbott 24/7.

text: The problem for Labor is if Rudd resigns they will effectively be handing the Coalition another seat in the lower house - Glasson did extraordinarily well in Griffth and will be a shoe in at a by-election.

text: Anotht labor cheer squadder who wants all the blame for Labor's demise to sit at the feet of the media - has no clue that Labor actually did themselves in.

text: I seem to recall only a couple of days ago the Labor Speaker of the House, Anna Burke relating something about the Faceless Men of the Labor party. Looks like both sides are calling it for what it is.

text: Now you and I both know you can only fit so much text into one commentary box and what you ask of me will take several boxes to list.

text: Had Murdoch supported Rudd and Labor had won all of you, every single one of you, would be silent on this. In your eyes Rupert could do no wrong - he would be your hero, a favourite son of the Labor party.

text: Or have I got it wrong and you would all still be flooding these threads condemning Murdoch for giving Labor an unfair advantage over the Coalition and should pull his head in and give the Coalition a chance?

text: Where's all the money to pay for all that? This was the problem all along - Labor spent all the money and kept borrowing billions to pay for things the country couldn't afford.

text: Labor are imploding before our very eyes and you guys are screaming for an election now - what for, to totally wipe labor off the electoral map and make the PUP the new alternative govt in Australia?

text: It could go either way in the next 12-18 months. If after the first 18 months the polling is favorable he should go on to lead them into the 2016 election.

text: I've always maintained that Malcolm Turnbull will eventually replace Abbott - but that may not be until the second or even third term - it's all up to the polls and how soon Labor can get their act together from here.

text: Good comment and I don't disagree. Travel rorting, some blatant some borderline, has been going on for years across all parties. They find the loopholes and away they go.

text: Good luck with that - I suspect the Coalition's 35 seat majority in the lower house and effective control of the senate from July 1 will put paid to any level of opposition Labor may muster.

text: I stress 'may' because if this rabble of an opposition keeps going the way it has in recent days with all the instability, dysfunction, infighting and public spats then you guys had better start aiming for 2019 for some kind of fight back. You'll have changed leaders at least once, if not twice by then.

text: Pretty much the only mess I can see is over at team Labor - it ain't a pretty sight. In fact frightening. Good thing Australian voters will keep them on the opposition benches for the next 9 or so years.

text: No point bursting blood vessels - you guys knew this was coming - half of you are carrying on as if this policy was only announced yesterday.If you have concerns, the government is requesting submissions on the carbon tax deconstruction bills from the public and interested organizations.

text: Labor leadership is in disarray, the factional in-fighting is going into overload, leaks and white-anting emerging once again, disaffected rank and file members upset over Shorten getting the gig over Albo, ALP members threatening to tear up their membership cards if Fitzgibbon gets a guernsey, Labor Speaker of the House very publicly damning Labor over the power of the faceless men, Obeid and ICAC, NSW Labor leader caught up in McGurk murder case, former National President of the ALP and HSU chief Williamson pleading guilty to ripping a million or so dollars out of the union, Craig Thomson going to court, Kevin Rudd circling; Bob Carr pulling the pin; Labor reduced to only 55 seats in the lower house and worst of all the Faceless Four - Shorten, Combet, Plibersek and Wong have been appointed to Labor's leadership by the faceless men. What a team!

text: No one should underestimate Tony Abbott - he is a very savvy and successful politician - after all he has seen off how many Labor leaders since he became Liberal leader? I've lost count

text: Refreshing to see David Marr construct an article which does not sink the boot into the Coalition, in fact the second paragraph admirably reflects the feelings of people after years of Labor government infighting, dysfunction and all round instability starting, according to Markus, when Gillard knifed Rudd in 2010 - must be a major annoyance to the regular Labor cheer squad on here. Well done David and Andrew Markus.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The Coalition were never going to transition into government without some early mistakes - as all new governments do - and in my opinion they have made 3 early errors -
author: TimOfAltona

text: 1. Flicking Steve Bracks from the NY Consul General post so quickly and without announcing who would replace him - the decision would easily backfire if they didn't have someone of the calibre of Bracks to replace him.2. Using the term 'mandate' when it comes to climate change and elimination of carbon tax. Nothing raises hackles more than a government claiming a mandate. It does not wash and is easily shot down in flames.3. Tony Abbott should be taking a harder line on the MP travel expense claim mess. Member's from both sides of parliament have been caught up in this and with opposition support which Bowen offered, the government should review the rules around entitlements and have the ambiguity removed. This will go a long way to changing negative views on politicians. Before everyone jumps on the government for 'allowing' this to happen - remember we have just emerged from 6 years of Labor government where bugger all was done about it as well. It's up to the Coalition to fix it up from here.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Not sure the public execution of two Iranian men from a crane in a carpark I came across on the outskirts of Tabriz a few years ago left me feeling any great affection for the country. Not a pleasant experience and makes you reflect on how hardline Islamic countries treat their citizens who transgress. I am not certain of their crime but bystanders told my Iranian friend they thought the men were drug traffickers - they looked like they were only about 20 years old.
author: TimOfAltona

text: This is the kind of news the Labor cheer squad can't stand. It eats them up to see the Coalition are significantly better fiscal managers than Labor and the Greens combined.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The cycle continues, Labor's socialist policies spend all the country's money, send us into massive deficits, try to bluff their way through ala Swan and Gillard, get thrown out of office and then the Coalition come back in to sort it all out and and create the long term wealth and prosperity.

text: Perhaps if you go away and return with one or two qualified arguments you may be taken a little more seriously and can add some credibility to the debate?

text: The Labor cheer squad have swarmed all over the first story like bees to pollen, flooding it with anti-Abbott, anti-Coalition rhetoric yet somehow the second story which advises how the government have done a good job with their costings is mysteriously ignored and seemingly avoided by the cheer squad.

text: They can't stand reading articles that show the government is doing a good job fiscally - it cuts them up to read it...so they think if they ignore it it will just go quietly go away and no one notices.

text: Black Hole, Black Hole, Black Hole screams Labor - the Coalition are hiding a massive Black Hole in their costings - how many times did we hear that? 100? 1000? 10,000 times?

text: Well guess what - Treasury announced that the Coalitions Budget costings are all clear and if anything it has understated the budget savings they will deliver from $6.09bn to $7.15bn.

text: Labor's Black Hole claim has crashed and burned along with any electoral prospects for 9 years or more as all the lies and deceit of the failed Labor campaign surface in spectacular fashion.

text: Labor/Greens cheer squadders will hate that because it raises the level of respect Australians already have for the PM - that's the last thing they want to see and it eats away at them - bit like when the coalition's budget costings were given the big tick of approval on Friday they all went into hiding.
